dc2b337f-4db5-4102-903d-b898fc97473a.name: Circular Economy Practices in Food Supply Chains
dc2b337f-4db5-4102-903d-b898fc97473a.name_en: Circular Economy Practices in Food Supply Chains
dc2b337f-4db5-4102-903d-b898fc97473a.description:
Circular Economy Practices in Food Supply Chains refers to the application of circular economy principles—such as resource efficiency, waste minimization, and closed-loop systems—within the context of food production, processing, distribution, and retail. This skill involves designing and managing food supply chains to reduce environmental impact, maximize the value extracted from resources, and minimize waste generation at every stage. Practitioners of this skill implement strategies like upcycling food by-products, optimizing logistics to reduce spoilage, promoting reusable or compostable packaging, and establishing partnerships for food redistribution or recycling. The skill requires a deep understanding of supply chain operations, sustainability standards, regulatory compliance (such as food waste legislation), and stakeholder engagement. It is highly relevant today as businesses face increasing pressure from consumers, governments, and investors to demonstrate sustainable practices and comply with evolving regulations. Immediate applications include redesigning procurement and inventory systems to prioritize circularity, collaborating with suppliers and customers to close material loops, and leveraging data analytics to identify inefficiencies. By adopting circular economy practices, organizations can achieve cost savings, enhance brand reputation, mitigate risks associated with resource scarcity, and contribute to global sustainability goals. This skill is essential for business leaders, supply chain managers, and sustainability professionals seeking to drive innovation and resilience in the food sector.

e20d6fd0-570d-4816-960d-7ce261a678c6.name: Circular Economy Strategy and Implementation
e20d6fd0-570d-4816-960d-7ce261a678c6.description:
Circular Economy Strategy and Implementation is the business-critical skill of designing, executing, and managing organizational transitions from linear (take-make-dispose) models to circular systems that prioritize resource efficiency, waste minimization, and long-term value creation. This skill involves the ability to assess current business processes, identify opportunities for circularity (such as product life extension, remanufacturing, recycling, and resource sharing), and develop actionable strategies that align with both sustainability goals and commercial objectives. Practitioners must be adept at stakeholder engagement, cross-functional collaboration, and change management to drive adoption across supply chains, product development, and customer engagement. Key competencies include conducting material flow analyses, lifecycle assessments, and circular business model innovation, as well as navigating regulatory frameworks (e.g., Extended Producer Responsibility, EU Circular Economy Action Plan) and sustainability reporting standards. Immediate applications include redesigning products for durability and recyclability, implementing closed-loop supply chains, and developing new revenue streams through product-as-a-service models. The skill is highly relevant today as organizations face increasing pressure from regulators, investors, and consumers to demonstrate environmental responsibility and resilience. Mastery of Circular Economy Strategy and Implementation enables businesses to reduce costs, mitigate risks associated with resource scarcity, and build competitive advantage through sustainable innovation.

a4764a0f-f52b-4c77-83e1-0966be42d528.name: Civil engineering
a4764a0f-f52b-4c77-83e1-0966be42d528.description: Civil engineering is a professional engineering discipline that deals with the design, construction, and maintenance of the physical and naturally built environment, including public works such as roads, bridges, canals, dams, airports, sewage systems, pipelines, structural components of buildings, and railways

196b0659-22eb-4aad-98a8-2fcc3313c23e.name: Claude
196b0659-22eb-4aad-98a8-2fcc3313c23e.description:
Claude is an AI assistant created by Anthropic, designed to be helpful, harmless, and honest. I'm built using a type of AI technology called a large language model (LLM), which means I've been trained on a diverse range of text data to understand and generate human language.

Claude can: 

Answer questions on a wide variety of topics
Assist with writing, editing, and brainstorming
Analyze data and solve problems
Engage in thoughtful conversation
Generate creative content

The Claude 3 model family, specifically Claude 3.7 Sonnet, has certain limitations. It doesn't browse the internet, can't access or modify files on a user's device (unless they are uploaded to the conversation), and its knowledge has a cutoff date at the end of October 2024.
Claude is designed to be a useful thinking partner that can adapt to different needs while maintaining safety guardrails against potentially harmful content. Its goal is to provide assistance that's both useful and aligned with human values.

28fe044c-c0f7-4269-b249-09f62f520383.name: ClearCase
28fe044c-c0f7-4269-b249-09f62f520383.description: ClearCase is a software configuration management tool used for version control. It manages changes across development lifecycles, from design to code to test. It is one of many version control systems available today.

945f12cc-a8ef-4eba-a47f-1db7544c44ce.name: ClickHouse
945f12cc-a8ef-4eba-a47f-1db7544c44ce.description: ClickHouse is an open-source, columnar online analytical processing (OLAP) database for real-time analytics. It started as an experimental project in 2009 and has since matured into a highly performant and linearly scalable analytical database. Its efficient query processing engine together with data compression makes it suitable to run interactive queries without pre-aggregation. ClickHouse is also a great storage choice for OpenTelemetry data. Its integration with Jaeger allows you to store massive volumes of traces and analyze them efficiently.  Ref: https://www.thoughtworks.com/radar/tools/summary/clickhouse

dfe389d2-db6c-4527-a93a-bde19c069971.name: Clojure
dfe389d2-db6c-4527-a93a-bde19c069971.description:
Clojure (/ˈkloʊʒər/, like closure) is a dynamic and functional dialect of the Lisp programming language on the Java platform.

Like most other Lisps, Clojure's syntax is built on S-expressions that are first parsed into data structures by a reader before being compiled. Clojure's reader supports literal syntax for maps, sets and vectors along with lists, and these are compiled to the mentioned structures directly. Clojure treats code as data and has a Lisp macro system. Clojure is a Lisp-1 and is not intended to be code-compatible with other dialects of Lisp, since it uses its own set of data structures incompatible with other Lisps. Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clojure

2810b616-4d03-415a-88e2-f802da3e3141.name: Cloud Workload Protection Platforms (CWPP)
2810b616-4d03-415a-88e2-f802da3e3141.description: A cloud workload protection platform is a comprehensive cybersecurity solution providing a series of protections across cloud environments in an organization connected to physical servers, serverless functions, virtual machines, and containers. With more environments comes more potential security risks.

67b238b5-a661-4299-b737-51b9fa8aee49.name: Cloud computing
67b238b5-a661-4299-b737-51b9fa8aee49.description:
Cloud computing is the delivery of different services through the Internet. These resources include tools and applications like data storage, servers, databases, networking, and software.

Rather than keeping files on a proprietary hard drive or local storage device, cloud-based storage makes it possible to save them to a remote database. As long as an electronic device has access to the web, it has access to the data and the software programs to run it.

Cloud computing is a popular option for people and businesses for a number of reasons including cost savings, increased productivity, speed and efficiency, performance, and security.

6376f455-4054-473c-b2df-f809d9c16a10.name: Cloud integration
6376f455-4054-473c-b2df-f809d9c16a10.description: At its most basic level, cloud integration means bringing multiple cloud environments together — either in a hybrid deployment or as multiple public clouds — so that they can operate as a single, cohesive IT infrastructure for an enterprise.

757ffd69-9f2c-44cd-9e73-7f65b7225eb2.name: Cloud security configuration management (CSCM)
757ffd69-9f2c-44cd-9e73-7f65b7225eb2.description: Cloud security configuration management (CSCM) is the process of managing the security settings of cloud-based resources to ensure they are secure and compliant. The process includes identifying misconfigurations, assessing risk, and remediating vulnerabilities.

9736218d-6c3c-4043-9cd3-265767db9dfe.name: Cloud security posture management (CSPM)
9736218d-6c3c-4043-9cd3-265767db9dfe.description: Cloud security posture management (CSPM) is the practice of controlling public cloud infrastructure risk. CSPM tools automate the detection and remediation of misconfigurations across cloud resources (e.g., Amazon EC2 instances).

8ea91130-5105-4bbb-b4b2-ae49f3122563.name: Cloud-Native Security Operations
8ea91130-5105-4bbb-b4b2-ae49f3122563.description:
Cloud-Native Security Operations is the practice of designing, implementing, and managing security controls and processes specifically tailored to cloud-native environments, such as those built on microservices, containers, serverless architectures, and orchestrated platforms like Kubernetes. This skill addresses the unique security challenges introduced by the dynamic, distributed, and ephemeral nature of cloud-native workloads, which differ significantly from traditional monolithic or on-premises systems. Practitioners must understand how to secure infrastructure-as-code (IaC), automate security policy enforcement, and integrate security into continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines to ensure rapid, consistent protection across all stages of the software development lifecycle. Key aspects include runtime threat detection, vulnerability management for container images, identity and access management (IAM) tailored to cloud-native resources, network segmentation using service meshes, and compliance monitoring in highly dynamic environments. Cloud-Native Security Operations also involves leveraging cloud provider security services, open-source tools (e.g., Falco, Aqua, Prisma Cloud), and integrating with Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) platforms for real-time visibility and incident response. This skill is critical today as organizations accelerate cloud adoption, requiring security teams to adapt to new paradigms and ensure robust protection without hindering agility or scalability. Typical use cases include securing Kubernetes clusters, automating compliance checks, detecting lateral movement in containerized environments, and responding to cloud-native security incidents in real time.

897e88a4-ff83-4358-83b4-3adabf9b894c.description: Cloudflare is one of the biggest networks on the Internet. People use Cloudflare for web application security and performance.

40f052c3-c935-4d3b-8552-21fb388a3428.name: Cloudformation
40f052c3-c935-4d3b-8552-21fb388a3428.description: AWS CloudFormation lets you model, provision, and manage AWS and third-party resources by treating infrastructure as code.

f5137903-8998-461d-8462-da7364d8eda6.name: CoPilot
f5137903-8998-461d-8462-da7364d8eda6.description:
Microsoft Copilot is a chatbot developed by Microsoft and launched on February 7, 2023. Based on a large language model, it is able to cite sources, create poems, and write songs. It is Microsoft’s primary replacement for the discontinued Cortana.

The service was introduced under the name Bing Chat, as a built-in feature for Microsoft Bing and Microsoft Edge. Over the course of 2023, Microsoft began to unify the Copilot branding across its various chatbot products. At its Build 2023 conference, Microsoft announced its plans to integrate Copilot into Windows 11, allowing users to access it directly through the taskbar. In January 2024, a dedicated Copilot key was announced for Windows keyboards.

6fc68ab7-5ef0-4bd1-a873-54ac7260458f.name: Coaching
6fc68ab7-5ef0-4bd1-a873-54ac7260458f.description: Coaching is a form of development in which an experienced person, called a coach, supports a learner or client in achieving a specific personal or professional goal by providing training and guidance.

dc6f6248-5ed8-489c-843b-80113d8710a5.name: Coaching
dc6f6248-5ed8-489c-843b-80113d8710a5.description: Coaching is a form of development in which an experienced person, called a coach, supports a learner or client in achieving a specific personal or professional goal by providing training and guidance.[1] The learner is sometimes called a coachee. Occasionally, coaching may mean an informal relationship between two people, of whom one has more experience and expertise than the other and offers advice and guidance as the latter learns; but coaching differs from mentoring by focusing on specific tasks or objectives, as opposed to more general goals or overall developmen

7b7bfeb5-609c-4d50-8a5d-b0347deb62e9.name: Coastal Engineering
7b7bfeb5-609c-4d50-8a5d-b0347deb62e9.description: Coastal engineering involves the practice of civil engineering, as well as the sciences of oceanography and coastal geology, to control erosion; place, construct, and monitor coastal structures; nourish beaches; and develop and maintain ports, harbors, and related navigation facilities.

76f835ae-393b-4a33-be12-229752b120c7.name: Coffeescript
76f835ae-393b-4a33-be12-229752b120c7.description:
CoffeeScript is a little language that compiles into JavaScript. Underneath that awkward Java-esque patina, JavaScript has always had a gorgeous heart. CoffeeScript is an attempt to expose the good parts of JavaScript in a simple way.

The golden rule of CoffeeScript is: “It’s just JavaScript.” The code compiles one-to-one into the equivalent JS, and there is no interpretation at runtime.

ccc9217c-9c31-4b0b-b5bc-739f9dc157a9.name: Cognitive Computing
ccc9217c-9c31-4b0b-b5bc-739f9dc157a9.description: Cognitive computing is an attempt to have computers mimic the way the human brain works. To accomplish this, cognitive computing uses artificial intelligence (AI) and other underlying technologies, including the following: Expert systems. Neural networks. Machine learning.

63039a3b-3934-4ac9-ba6c-8b8763370602.name: Cognitive Services
63039a3b-3934-4ac9-ba6c-8b8763370602.description: Cognitive Services are a set of machine learning algorithms that Microsoft has developed to solve problems in the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI). The goal of Cognitive Services is to democratize AI by packaging it into discrete components that are easy for developers to use in their own apps

99a09171-ee5e-4ebf-af1f-79665f74574f.name: Cold Chain Logistics Optimization for Perishable Foods
99a09171-ee5e-4ebf-af1f-79665f74574f.name_en: Cold Chain Logistics Optimization for Perishable Foods
99a09171-ee5e-4ebf-af1f-79665f74574f.description:
Cold Chain Logistics Optimization for Perishable Foods is a specialized technical skill focused on designing, managing, and improving the end-to-end logistics processes for temperature-sensitive food products. This skill encompasses the application of advanced analytical methods, real-time monitoring technologies, and process optimization techniques to ensure that perishable foods—such as dairy, meat, seafood, fruits, and vegetables—are transported and stored within strict temperature ranges from the point of origin (farm or production facility) to the final consumer. The primary objective is to minimize spoilage, maintain food safety and quality, comply with regulatory standards, and reduce operational costs. Practitioners must integrate knowledge of refrigeration systems, sensor networks (IoT), data analytics, and supply chain management. They are responsible for route planning, selecting appropriate packaging, monitoring temperature excursions, and responding to disruptions in real time. Immediate applications include optimizing delivery schedules for grocery retailers, ensuring pharmaceutical-grade cold storage for food exports, and deploying predictive analytics to anticipate and mitigate risks such as equipment failure or delays. This skill is currently critical due to increased consumer demand for fresh foods, stricter food safety regulations, and the globalization of food supply chains. Mastery of this skill directly impacts food waste reduction, cost efficiency, and public health outcomes, making it highly relevant in today's technical landscape.

6132c989-624a-4b7e-9a5a-17c93c4d7ddc.name: Cold Chain Monitoring and Optimization
6132c989-624a-4b7e-9a5a-17c93c4d7ddc.description:
Cold Chain Monitoring and Optimization is a critical technical skill focused on ensuring the integrity, safety, and quality of temperature-sensitive products—such as food, pharmaceuticals, and biologics—throughout their storage and transportation lifecycle. This skill involves the use of advanced monitoring technologies (e.g., IoT sensors, data loggers, real-time tracking systems) to continuously measure and record environmental parameters like temperature, humidity, and sometimes vibration or light exposure. Practitioners analyze this data to detect deviations, prevent spoilage, and maintain compliance with stringent regulatory standards (such as FDA, EU GDP, or HACCP). Optimization further encompasses the application of data analytics and process improvement methodologies to enhance the efficiency and reliability of cold chain logistics, reduce energy consumption, and minimize waste. Immediate applications include configuring alert systems for temperature excursions, implementing predictive maintenance for refrigeration equipment, and designing robust contingency protocols for supply chain disruptions. In today's globalized and highly regulated markets, this skill is indispensable for organizations seeking to protect product quality, reduce financial losses from spoilage, and uphold public health standards. Mastery of Cold Chain Monitoring and Optimization is essential for technical professionals in food safety, pharmaceutical logistics, and supply chain management, as it directly impacts operational efficiency, customer trust, and regulatory compliance.

7e64fd4d-2a4a-4437-8650-39c90ab958e1.name: Cold Outreach Personalization
7e64fd4d-2a4a-4437-8650-39c90ab958e1.description:
Cold Outreach Personalization is the practice of tailoring unsolicited communications—such as emails, LinkedIn messages, or direct mail—to specific individuals or organizations in order to increase the likelihood of engagement, response, and conversion. In today’s business environment, decision-makers and key stakeholders are inundated with generic outreach attempts, making it essential for professionals to stand out by demonstrating genuine understanding and relevance. This skill involves researching the recipient’s background, role, business challenges, and interests, and then crafting messages that resonate on a personal and professional level. Effective cold outreach personalization leverages data from public profiles, recent news, company updates, and mutual connections to create highly relevant touchpoints. It requires a blend of empathy, strategic communication, and analytical thinking to identify what matters most to the recipient and to articulate a clear value proposition. The immediate value of this skill lies in its ability to break through noise, foster trust, and initiate meaningful business relationships—whether for sales, partnerships, recruitment, or networking. Typical use cases include B2B sales prospecting, executive networking, investor relations, and talent acquisition. Mastery of cold outreach personalization directly impacts response rates, pipeline growth, and overall business development success, making it a critical competency for professionals in client-facing and growth-oriented roles.

44c212fb-0ecb-4921-8bd7-8ed9c923a930.name: Cold calling
44c212fb-0ecb-4921-8bd7-8ed9c923a930.description: Cold calling is a form of sales solicitation from businesses to customers who've never interacted with the salesperson making the call. It generally refers to phone-based conversations (hence cold calling) but technically covers in-person door-to-door interactions, too.

dbff6580-36c5-4d8d-bdca-0ac19bcbb34f.name: Common Lisp
dbff6580-36c5-4d8d-bdca-0ac19bcbb34f.description:
Common Lisp (CL) is a dialect of the Lisp programming language, published in American National Standards Institute (ANSI) standard document ANSI INCITS 226-1994 (S2018) (formerly X3.226-1994 (R1999)).[2] The Common Lisp HyperSpec, a hyperlinked HTML version, has been derived from the ANSI Common Lisp standard.

The Common Lisp language was developed as a standardized and improved successor of Maclisp. By the early 1980s several groups were already at work on diverse successors to MacLisp: Lisp Machine Lisp (aka ZetaLisp), Spice Lisp, NIL and S-1 Lisp. Common Lisp sought to unify, standardise, and extend the features of these MacLisp dialects. Common Lisp is not an implementation, but rather a language specification. Several implementations of the Common Lisp standard are available, including free and open-source software and proprietary products.[5] Common Lisp is a general-purpose, multi-paradigm programming language. It supports a combination of procedural, functional, and object-oriented programming paradigms. As a dynamic programming language, it facilitates evolutionary and incremental software development, with iterative compilation into efficient run-time programs. This incremental development is often done interactively without interrupting the running application.  Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Lisp

f5c96ae6-1e6d-4e3c-b732-b960d33ee2ea.name: Communication
f5c96ae6-1e6d-4e3c-b732-b960d33ee2ea.description: The ability to concisely get ideas across, convince others around them to get behind these ideas, and build as well as maintain strong relationships through dialogue. Communication also includes the ability to listen.

659a5e15-b0e7-4070-a548-648a29aff85a.name: Competent performance
659a5e15-b0e7-4070-a548-648a29aff85a.description: Competent performance refers to the ability to perform a required task at a targeted level of proficiency. To be competent, you must be able to react to a situation and follow behaviors you have found to succeed in the past. Competency is a set of demonstrable characteristics and skills that enable and improve the efficiency or performance of a job. It is a series of knowledge, abilities, skills, experiences and behaviors, which leads to effective performance in an individual's activities

cdda183c-6543-4a9c-8dbf-8d76f80e6f62.name: Competitive Intelligence Gathering
cdda183c-6543-4a9c-8dbf-8d76f80e6f62.description:
Competitive Intelligence Gathering is the systematic process of collecting, analyzing, and interpreting information about competitors, market trends, and the broader business environment to inform strategic decision-making. In today's fast-paced and highly competitive markets, this skill is crucial for organizations seeking to maintain or improve their market position. Practitioners of competitive intelligence gathering use a variety of methods, including monitoring public sources, analyzing financial reports, tracking digital footprints, attending industry events, and leveraging specialized databases. The goal is to identify competitors’ strengths, weaknesses, strategies, product launches, pricing changes, and customer sentiment, enabling businesses to anticipate market shifts and respond proactively. This skill is immediately relevant as it empowers sales teams to tailor pitches, helps product managers identify gaps or opportunities, and supports executives in risk mitigation and strategic planning. Effective competitive intelligence gathering requires not only technical proficiency in data collection and analysis but also ethical judgment to ensure compliance with legal standards and corporate policies. Typical use cases include preparing for sales negotiations, benchmarking performance, supporting merger and acquisition decisions, and informing marketing campaigns. By integrating insights from competitive intelligence, organizations can make informed, timely decisions that strengthen their positioning and drive sustainable growth in the current business landscape.

5deb743f-385e-4c1f-8563-01f655917d49.name: Complex Contract Structuring
5deb743f-385e-4c1f-8563-01f655917d49.description:
Complex Contract Structuring is the advanced business skill of designing, negotiating, and formalizing multifaceted agreements that address the needs of multiple stakeholders in dynamic, high-value sales environments. This skill is crucial in today's business landscape, where transactions often involve intricate legal, financial, and operational considerations. Practitioners must balance risk allocation, compliance requirements, and commercial objectives while ensuring flexibility and mutual benefit for all parties involved. Key aspects include the ability to identify and integrate diverse interests, anticipate potential points of contention, and craft terms that allow for adaptability in changing market or regulatory conditions. Effective complex contract structuring requires a deep understanding of contract law, negotiation tactics, and industry-specific standards, as well as the capacity to collaborate with legal, financial, and operational experts. Typical use cases include structuring long-term supply agreements, joint ventures, strategic partnerships, and multi-party service contracts. The skill is especially valuable in sectors such as technology, energy, and professional services, where deal complexity and stakeholder diversity are high. Mastery of complex contract structuring enables organizations to secure competitive advantages, minimize disputes, and foster sustainable, win-win business relationships in the present-day marketplace.

92f5cf65-5797-4270-9c89-6fcc683329ca.name: Compliance investigation
92f5cf65-5797-4270-9c89-6fcc683329ca.description: A compliance investigation occurs when an organization suspects that someone has violated an applicable law or regulation. It might involve potential fraud, waste, or abuse, or it might relate to regulations such as environmental quality or workplace standards.

ed3ef610-cf99-4b5c-98fb-b31ffeb12590.name: Computer Vision
ed3ef610-cf99-4b5c-98fb-b31ffeb12590.description: Computer vision is a field of artificial intelligence (AI) that uses machine learning and neural networks to teach computers and systems to derive meaningful information from digital images, videos and other visual inputs—and to make recommendations or take actions when they see defects or issues.

26633e7f-88d0-4027-8d02-e92aa05dc200.name: Computer simulation
26633e7f-88d0-4027-8d02-e92aa05dc200.description: Computer simulation is the process of mathematical modelling, performed on a computer, which is designed to predict the behaviour of, or the outcome of, a real-world or physical system. The reliability of some mathematical models can be determined by comparing their results to the real-world outcomes they aim to predict. Computer simulations have become a useful tool for the mathematical modeling of many natural systems in physics (computational physics), astrophysics, climatology, chemistry, biology and manufacturing, as well as human systems in economics, psychology, social science, health care and engineering. Simulation of a system is represented as the running of the system's model. It can be used to explore and gain new insights into new technology and to estimate the performance of systems too complex for analytical solutions.  Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_simulation

f723a3b6-2647-4ebe-942f-d625e158584b.name: Computer troubleshooting
f723a3b6-2647-4ebe-942f-d625e158584b.description: Computer troubleshooting is the process of diagnosing and solving computer errors or technical problems.

27a578c6-814a-4f02-8e93-fe9f1fce7999.name: Computer vision
27a578c6-814a-4f02-8e93-fe9f1fce7999.description:
Computer vision tasks include methods for acquiring, processing, analyzing and understanding digital images, and extraction of high-dimensional data from the real world in order to produce numerical or symbolic information, e.g. in the forms of decisions. Understanding in this context means the transformation of visual images (the input to the retina in the human analog) into descriptions of the world that make sense to thought processes and can elicit appropriate action. This image understanding can be seen as the disentangling of symbolic information from image data using models constructed with the aid of geometry, physics, statistics, and learning theory.

The scientific discipline of computer vision is concerned with the theory behind artificial systems that extract information from images. The image data can take many forms, such as video sequences, views from multiple cameras, multi-dimensional data from a 3D scanner, 3D point clouds from LiDaR sensors, or medical scanning devices. The technological discipline of computer vision seeks to apply its theories and models to the construction of computer vision systems.

Sub-domains of computer vision include scene reconstruction, object detection, event detection, activity recognition, video tracking, object recognition, 3D pose estimation, learning, indexing, motion estimation, visual servoing, 3D scene modeling, and image restoration.  Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_vision

1c90af93-134d-4f1f-ae12-d87b0bb9bcd4.name: Consensus Building in Complex Sales
1c90af93-134d-4f1f-ae12-d87b0bb9bcd4.description:
Consensus Building in Complex Sales is the strategic process of facilitating agreement among multiple, diverse stakeholders involved in high-value or multifaceted sales transactions. In today’s business environment, enterprise sales cycles often involve numerous decision-makers from different departments, each with unique priorities, risk tolerances, and success metrics. This skill requires the ability to identify and align these varied interests, manage conflicting agendas, and foster collaborative decision-making to accelerate deal closure and enhance customer satisfaction. Practitioners must demonstrate advanced interpersonal communication, negotiation, and stakeholder management abilities, leveraging empathy and active listening to surface concerns and build trust. They must also be adept at mapping stakeholder influence, navigating organizational politics, and articulating the value proposition in ways that resonate with each party’s objectives. Consensus building is especially critical in B2B sales, technology adoption, and solution selling, where the complexity of offerings and the scale of investment demand broad organizational buy-in. Effective consensus builders use structured frameworks, such as stakeholder analysis and decision-mapping, to guide discussions, address objections, and ensure all voices are heard. The immediate value of this skill lies in its ability to reduce sales cycle times, minimize deal risk, and create champions within client organizations, leading to stronger relationships and higher rates of post-sale satisfaction and retention.

464f60e2-796f-4769-b485-f147a3f733e5.name: Consensus Building in Enterprise Sales
464f60e2-796f-4769-b485-f147a3f733e5.description:
Consensus Building in Enterprise Sales is the strategic process of aligning the interests, priorities, and decision-making criteria of multiple stakeholders within a client organization to facilitate the successful progression and closure of complex sales deals. In today's enterprise sales environment, purchasing decisions are rarely made by a single individual; instead, they involve cross-functional buying committees, each with distinct goals, pain points, and levels of influence. This skill requires sales professionals to identify key stakeholders, map their roles and influence, uncover and address conflicting interests, and foster collaboration among diverse groups. Effective consensus building involves facilitating transparent communication, managing objections, and creating shared value propositions that resonate across departments such as IT, finance, operations, and executive leadership. It also demands the ability to anticipate and mitigate internal resistance, navigate organizational politics, and maintain momentum throughout lengthy sales cycles. Mastery of this skill is critical for driving deal progression, reducing sales cycle times, and increasing win rates in enterprise sales contexts. Typical use cases include orchestrating stakeholder workshops, mediating between champions and detractors, and leveraging internal advocates to build broad-based support for a solution. In the current business climate, where risk aversion and scrutiny of large investments are high, consensus building is essential for ensuring that all relevant parties are aligned and committed to moving forward.

f46091e8-1cac-47d3-a3f2-0cdf3ed4f8b7.name: Consumer Communication for Food Transparency
f46091e8-1cac-47d3-a3f2-0cdf3ed4f8b7.description:
Consumer Communication for Food Transparency is a critical business skill focused on effectively conveying information about food sourcing, production processes, ingredient origins, and supply chain traceability to consumers. In today's market, consumers are increasingly demanding transparency from food brands regarding where their products come from, how they are made, and the ethical and environmental standards adhered to throughout the supply chain. This skill involves crafting clear, accurate, and accessible messages that build trust and foster informed decision-making among consumers. It requires a deep understanding of regulatory requirements, industry certifications (such as organic, non-GMO, or fair trade), and the ability to translate complex traceability data into consumer-friendly language. Practitioners must be adept at utilizing multiple communication channels, including product labeling, digital platforms, social media, and customer service interactions, to ensure consistent and transparent messaging. The skill is immediately relevant as food safety concerns, sustainability, and ethical sourcing are top priorities for modern consumers, directly influencing brand reputation and purchasing decisions. Typical use cases include developing transparency campaigns, responding to consumer inquiries about product origins, and managing crisis communications related to food recalls or supply chain disruptions. Mastery of this skill enables businesses to differentiate themselves in a competitive market, comply with evolving regulations, and build long-term consumer loyalty by demonstrating accountability and openness.

96bd5147-b6ae-4e57-bb29-aa9cd712e230.name: Context Modelling

02c85ef3-c844-4dfd-8a24-c7b53fd5e98b.name: Cost–benefit analysis
02c85ef3-c844-4dfd-8a24-c7b53fd5e98b.description:
Cost–benefit analysis (CBA), sometimes also called benefit–cost analysis, is a systematic approach to estimating the strengths and weaknesses of alternatives. It is used to determine options which provide the best approach to achieving benefits while preserving savings in, for example, transactions, activities, and functional business requirements. A CBA may be used to compare completed or potential courses of action, and to estimate or evaluate the value against the cost of a decision, project, or policy. It is commonly used to evaluate business or policy decisions (particularly public policy), commercial transactions, and project investments. For example, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission must conduct cost-benefit analyses before instituting regulations or deregulations.: 6 

CBA has two main applications:

To determine if an investment (or decision) is sound, ascertaining if – and by how much – its benefits outweigh its costs.
To provide a basis for comparing investments (or decisions), comparing the total expected cost of each option with its total expected benefits.
CBA is related to cost-effectiveness analysis. Benefits and costs in CBA are expressed in monetary terms and are adjusted for the time value of money; all flows of benefits and costs over time are expressed on a common basis in terms of their net present value, regardless of whether they are incurred at different times. Other related techniques include cost–utility analysis, risk–benefit analysis, economic impact analysis, fiscal impact analysis, and social return on investment (SROI) analysis.  Ref:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cost%E2%80%93benefit_analysis

035b5971-2926-463b-af10-5b73e14d874d.name: Creativity
035b5971-2926-463b-af10-5b73e14d874d.description: Creativity is defined as the tendency to generate or recognize ideas, alternatives, or possibilities that may be useful in solving problems, communicating with others, and entertaining ourselves and others.

3106aff2-9d3f-4d5b-bbc7-3c407e8dddb3.name: Crisis Management
3106aff2-9d3f-4d5b-bbc7-3c407e8dddb3.description: Crisis management is the application of strategies designed to help an organization deal with a sudden and significant negative event, while maintaining business continuity. Crisis management involves implementing policies and procedures to defend, mitigate and prevent a crisis.

f6a66b2e-c0b9-4098-97fc-376bce64e9c4.name: Critical Data Interpretation and Decision-Making
f6a66b2e-c0b9-4098-97fc-376bce64e9c4.description:
Critical Data Interpretation and Decision-Making is a foundational business skill that involves the rigorous analysis, synthesis, and application of data-driven insights to inform and guide organizational choices. In today's data-rich business environment, this skill is essential for managers, analysts, and executives who must navigate complex datasets, extract actionable intelligence, and make timely decisions that directly impact business performance. Practitioners of this skill are adept at evaluating quantitative and qualitative data from diverse sources—such as financial reports, customer analytics, market research, and operational metrics—while considering context, reliability, and potential biases. They utilize business intelligence tools (e.g., Tableau, Power BI), statistical methods, and data visualization techniques to uncover trends, correlations, and anomalies. The skill also encompasses the ability to critically question data sources, validate findings, and communicate insights clearly to stakeholders with varying levels of data literacy. Effective critical data interpretation reduces the risk of costly errors, supports evidence-based strategy development, and enables rapid response to market changes or operational challenges. Typical use cases include optimizing supply chains, identifying new market opportunities, evaluating investment options, and monitoring key performance indicators (KPIs) to drive continuous improvement. This skill is immediately relevant as organizations increasingly rely on data to maintain competitiveness, ensure compliance, and foster innovation in a rapidly evolving business landscape.

0edd805d-b10f-4bd9-b8ca-38c54b49d6e9.name: Critical thinking
0edd805d-b10f-4bd9-b8ca-38c54b49d6e9.description: Critical thinking is the analysis of available facts, evidence, observations, and arguments in order to form a judgement by the application of rational, skeptical, and unbiased analyses and evaluation. The application of critical thinking includes self-directed, self-disciplined, self-monitored, and self-corrective habits of the mind, thus a critical thinker is a person who practices the skills of critical thinking or has been trained and educated in its disciplines. Philosopher Richard W. Paul said that the mind of a critical thinker engages the person's intellectual abilities and personality traits. Critical thinking presupposes assent to rigorous standards of excellence and mindful command of their use in effective communication and problem solving, and a commitment to overcome egocentrism and sociocentrism.  Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_thinking

afc3c2c7-789b-4914-922c-f92f879ca172.name: Cross-Border Logistics Compliance for Food Products
afc3c2c7-789b-4914-922c-f92f879ca172.name_en: Cross-Border Logistics Compliance for Food Products
afc3c2c7-789b-4914-922c-f92f879ca172.description:
Cross-Border Logistics Compliance for Food Products is a critical business skill that ensures the lawful and efficient movement of food products across international borders. This skill involves a deep understanding of the complex and evolving regulatory frameworks governing the import and export of food, including food safety standards, customs documentation, sanitary and phytosanitary (SPS) measures, labeling requirements, and traceability protocols. Practitioners must navigate a landscape shaped by international agreements (such as the WTO SPS Agreement), bilateral trade deals, and country-specific regulations, all while maintaining the integrity and safety of perishable goods. Immediate applications include coordinating with customs brokers, ensuring accurate and timely documentation, managing cold chain logistics, and responding to regulatory changes or border disruptions. The skill is especially relevant today due to heightened scrutiny on food safety, increased global trade, and the need for rapid adaptation to shifting regulatory environments (e.g., post-Brexit changes, pandemic-related border controls). Mastery of this skill minimizes delays, reduces the risk of non-compliance penalties, and protects brand reputation by ensuring products reach markets safely and legally. It is indispensable for businesses involved in international food trade, logistics providers, compliance officers, and supply chain managers seeking to maintain seamless operations in a highly regulated and dynamic global marketplace.

2685a1ab-71c6-4fea-b00f-3efb789d8136.name: Cross-Cultural Sales Communication
2685a1ab-71c6-4fea-b00f-3efb789d8136.description:
Cross-Cultural Sales Communication is the ability to effectively engage, persuade, and negotiate with stakeholders from diverse cultural backgrounds in the context of multinational enterprise sales. This skill is crucial in today’s globalized business environment, where sales professionals routinely interact with clients, partners, and decision-makers from various countries, each with distinct communication styles, business etiquettes, and cultural norms. Mastery of this skill involves not only fluency in language but also a deep understanding of cultural sensitivities, non-verbal cues, and the ability to adapt sales messages to resonate with different audiences. Practitioners must be adept at building trust across cultures, navigating potential misunderstandings, and demonstrating respect for local customs and values while advancing organizational goals. Immediate applications include conducting international sales pitches, managing cross-border negotiations, and fostering long-term client relationships in multicultural settings. The skill is highly relevant today as remote collaboration, virtual meetings, and global supply chains have become standard, making cultural agility a key differentiator in securing deals and maintaining competitive advantage. Typical use cases include tailoring product presentations for Asian versus European markets, handling objections in culturally appropriate ways, and aligning sales strategies with local decision-making processes. In sum, Cross-Cultural Sales Communication is indispensable for sales professionals seeking to thrive in the complex, interconnected world of modern business.

d14cf31e-0d3d-4d11-a2e9-f078782bad07.description:
Cross-Functional AI Collaboration is the business-critical skill of facilitating effective cooperation between technical teams (such as data scientists, machine learning engineers, and IT specialists) and non-technical stakeholders (including business leaders, product managers, marketing, operations, and compliance teams) to accelerate the adoption and value realization of artificial intelligence solutions. This skill involves translating complex AI concepts into actionable business strategies, aligning project objectives with organizational goals, and ensuring that AI initiatives are both technically feasible and commercially viable. Practitioners must bridge communication gaps, foster mutual understanding, and manage cross-disciplinary workflows, often using agile methodologies and collaborative platforms (e.g., Jira, Slack, Miro). Key aspects include stakeholder alignment, requirements gathering, risk management, and change management, as well as ethical considerations such as bias mitigation and transparency. Immediate applications include deploying AI-powered automation in business processes, integrating predictive analytics into decision-making, and ensuring regulatory compliance in AI projects. Effective cross-functional AI collaboration leads to faster project delivery, higher adoption rates, and measurable business impact, while minimizing misunderstandings and project failures. This skill is essential for organizations seeking to leverage AI for competitive advantage in today's rapidly evolving business landscape, where the ability to unite diverse expertise around shared objectives is a key driver of innovation and operational excellence.

f1173b10-c1d6-44f6-9346-73ad55a3f48f.name: Cross-Functional Data Collaboration
f1173b10-c1d6-44f6-9346-73ad55a3f48f.description:
Cross-Functional Data Collaboration is the practice of enabling seamless data sharing, integration, and cooperative analysis across multiple departments within an organization. In today's business environment, data is generated and utilized by diverse teams—such as marketing, finance, operations, and product development—each with unique perspectives and requirements. This skill involves establishing processes, communication protocols, and governance structures that break down traditional data silos, ensuring that valuable data assets are accessible, interpretable, and actionable by all relevant stakeholders. Practitioners must be adept at leveraging collaborative tools (e.g., shared dashboards, cloud-based data warehouses, data catalogs), facilitating interdepartmental meetings, and aligning on common data definitions and metrics. They must also navigate data privacy, compliance, and security considerations, ensuring that data sharing adheres to organizational policies and regulatory requirements. Effective cross-functional data collaboration drives better decision-making, accelerates innovation, and maximizes the return on data investments by enabling holistic insights that no single department could achieve alone. Typical use cases include joint business intelligence projects, integrated customer journey analysis, and enterprise-wide performance monitoring. This skill is currently critical as organizations increasingly rely on data-driven strategies and must respond rapidly to market changes, making cross-functional data collaboration a cornerstone of agile, high-performing businesses.

7672acf2-0e1b-4413-9827-9e246631f0c0.name: Cross-Functional Team Leadership
7672acf2-0e1b-4413-9827-9e246631f0c0.description:
Cross-Functional Team Leadership is the ability to effectively guide, coordinate, and motivate teams composed of members from diverse functional backgrounds—such as sales, marketing, engineering, finance, and operations—to achieve shared objectives in complex organizational environments. This skill is critically important in today’s fast-paced business landscape, where projects and sales initiatives often require collaboration across multiple departments to deliver integrated solutions and drive organizational success. Effective cross-functional leaders possess a deep understanding of each team’s unique perspectives, priorities, and expertise, enabling them to bridge communication gaps, resolve conflicts, and align disparate goals toward a common vision. They facilitate open dialogue, foster mutual respect, and leverage the strengths of each discipline to enhance creativity and problem-solving. In practice, cross-functional team leadership involves setting clear goals, defining roles and responsibilities, managing interdependencies, and ensuring accountability across all team members. It also requires strong stakeholder management, adaptability, and the ability to navigate organizational politics. This skill is especially valuable in sales and project environments where rapid decision-making, resource allocation, and customer-centric solutions are paramount. Leaders who excel in this area drive higher team performance, innovation, and successful project delivery by harnessing the collective intelligence and capabilities of the entire organization.

296fcb46-bfe7-404a-ac52-c52ac39ac29f.name: Cross-functional collaboration
296fcb46-bfe7-404a-ac52-c52ac39ac29f.description: Cross-functional collaboration is the process where individuals from different departments in an organization with different areas of expertise come together to achieve a common goal. This collaboration could be organic or project-based.

ac9183da-a6fd-49eb-994e-c0916e9ae9ac.name: Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS)
ac9183da-a6fd-49eb-994e-c0916e9ae9ac.description: Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) is a mechanism that allows restricted resources on a web page to be requested from another domain outside the domain from which the first resource was served. A web page may freely embed cross-origin images, stylesheets, scripts, iframes, and videos.

eff479f0-f4e4-4a4f-aa66-71fe862a9dbd.name: Cross-selling and upselling
eff479f0-f4e4-4a4f-aa66-71fe862a9dbd.description: Cross-selling is the process of offering a customer products that are compatible with the ones they're purchasing. What's the difference between cross-selling and upselling? Upselling is the practice of selling a more expensive product to a customer, while cross-selling is offering supplementary products.

b4e26d4f-4132-4d79-b9f8-e5fe86f83419.name: Crossplane
b4e26d4f-4132-4d79-b9f8-e5fe86f83419.description:
Crossplane is an open source Kubernetes extension that transforms your Kubernetes cluster into a universal control plane.

Crossplane lets you manage anything, anywhere, all through standard Kubernetes APIs. Crossplane can even let you order a pizza directly from Kubernetes. If it has an API, Crossplane can connect to it.

With Crossplane, platform teams can create new abstractions and custom APIs with the full power of Kubernetes policies, namespaces, role based access controls and more. Crossplane brings all your non-Kubernetes resources under one roof.

Custom APIs, created by platform teams, allow security and compliance enforcement across resources or clouds, without exposing any complexity to the developers. A single API call can create multiple resources, in multiple clouds and use Kubernetes as the control plane for everything.  Ref: https://docs.crossplane.io/v1.17/

f62b51ca-db28-4d46-88ba-0029115d3b59.name: Crucible
f62b51ca-db28-4d46-88ba-0029115d3b59.description: Crucible is a collaborative code review application by Australian software company Atlassian. Like other Atlassian products, Crucible is a Web-based application primarily aimed at enterprise, and certain features that enable peer review of a codebase may be considered enterprise social software.

3f10a4c9-8385-4ebc-88ea-341f3af49cdd.name: Cryptography
3f10a4c9-8385-4ebc-88ea-341f3af49cdd.description: Cryptography is associated with the process of converting ordinary plain text into unintelligible text and vice-versa. It is a method of storing and transmitting data in a particular form so that only those for whom it is intended can read and process it. Cryptography not only protects data from theft or alteration, but can also be used for user authentication.

9621016b-ba1e-468a-91d3-7ec2dccd2d02.name: Cucumber
9621016b-ba1e-468a-91d3-7ec2dccd2d02.description: It’s simple. Whether open source or commercial, our collaboration tools will boost your engineering team's performance by employing Behavior-Driven Development (BDD).

a2926825-f78f-47ac-a4d2-f34b11e948ab.name: Cultural competence
a2926825-f78f-47ac-a4d2-f34b11e948ab.description: Cultural competency means being aware of your own cultural beliefs and values and how these may be different from other cultures—including being able to learn about and honor the different cultures of those you work with.

c4872cf0-70a0-4c67-9483-5f55438f13c9.name: Curiosity
c4872cf0-70a0-4c67-9483-5f55438f13c9.description: an eager desire to learn and often to learn what does not concern one

1513a86c-bee0-4489-b7c5-0e64295caf69.name: Customer Advocacy Program Development
1513a86c-bee0-4489-b7c5-0e64295caf69.description:
Customer Advocacy Program Development is the strategic process of designing, implementing, and managing initiatives that empower satisfied customers to actively promote a business’s products or services. This skill involves identifying and nurturing loyal customers, creating structured opportunities for them to share positive experiences, and leveraging their advocacy to drive referrals, enhance brand reputation, and generate new business opportunities. In today’s competitive marketplace, peer recommendations and authentic testimonials are highly influential in purchasing decisions, making customer advocacy programs a critical component of modern business growth strategies. Practitioners must be adept at segmenting customer bases to identify potential advocates, crafting compelling engagement campaigns, and providing incentives or recognition that motivate participation. The skill also encompasses the use of digital platforms and social media to amplify customer voices, as well as the measurement and analysis of advocacy program outcomes to ensure alignment with business objectives. Effective customer advocacy program development requires cross-functional collaboration with marketing, sales, and customer success teams to ensure a seamless customer experience and consistent messaging. Typical use cases include launching referral programs, organizing customer advisory boards, and facilitating user-generated content campaigns. Ultimately, this skill enables organizations to transform customer satisfaction into a sustainable engine for organic growth, increased loyalty, and competitive differentiation in the current business landscape.

771a22d0-db28-4a1e-bf47-2301f78829c6.name: Customer Advocacy Program Development
771a22d0-db28-4a1e-bf47-2301f78829c6.description:
Customer Advocacy Program Development is the strategic process of designing, implementing, and optimizing formal initiatives that encourage enterprise clients to actively promote a company’s products or services. This skill is critical in today’s business landscape, where peer recommendations and authentic customer voices significantly influence purchasing decisions and brand loyalty. Practitioners of this skill identify and nurture satisfied customers, transforming them into advocates who provide testimonials, participate in case studies, speak at industry events, and refer new business. The development process involves segmenting the customer base to identify potential advocates, crafting value propositions and incentives that motivate participation, and establishing clear processes for engagement and recognition. It also requires close collaboration with sales, marketing, and product teams to ensure advocacy efforts align with broader business goals. Effective Customer Advocacy Program Development leverages data analytics to measure program impact, such as increased referrals, higher renewal rates, and improved Net Promoter Scores (NPS). Use cases include launching ambassador programs, managing reference pools for sales cycles, and orchestrating customer advisory boards. In the current business environment, this skill is essential for driving organic growth, reducing customer acquisition costs, and building resilient, trust-based relationships with enterprise clients.

4bf38af2-d85f-4380-bcb3-018aed7cecd3.name: Customer Journey Mapping
4bf38af2-d85f-4380-bcb3-018aed7cecd3.description:
Customer Journey Mapping is a strategic business skill focused on visualizing and analyzing the end-to-end experience that customers have with a brand, product, or service. This process involves identifying all key touchpoints, channels, and interactions that a customer encounters from initial awareness through post-purchase engagement. By mapping these journeys, organizations gain a holistic understanding of customer behaviors, motivations, pain points, and emotional responses at each stage of the buying process. This insight enables businesses to identify gaps, inefficiencies, and opportunities for improvement in their sales, marketing, and customer service strategies. In today's highly competitive and customer-centric marketplace, Customer Journey Mapping is crucial for designing seamless, personalized experiences that drive customer satisfaction, loyalty, and advocacy. It supports cross-functional collaboration by aligning teams around a shared view of the customer experience and informs data-driven decision-making for targeted interventions. Typical use cases include optimizing digital user flows, reducing customer churn, improving onboarding processes, and tailoring marketing campaigns to specific customer segments. The skill requires proficiency in research methods such as interviews, surveys, and data analytics, as well as the ability to synthesize qualitative and quantitative insights into actionable journey maps. Mastery of Customer Journey Mapping empowers organizations to proactively address customer needs, differentiate their offerings, and achieve measurable business outcomes.

3e265aee-4020-4a9f-8635-ee905a21d621.name: Customer Lifetime Value Assessment (in Sales Context)
3e265aee-4020-4a9f-8635-ee905a21d621.name_en: Customer Lifetime Value Assessment (in Sales Context)
3e265aee-4020-4a9f-8635-ee905a21d621.description:
Customer Lifetime Value (CLV) Assessment in the sales context is the process of estimating the total net revenue a business can expect from a customer account throughout the entire duration of their relationship. This skill is critical in modern sales operations as it enables organizations to prioritize resources, tailor engagement strategies, and optimize account management for maximum profitability. CLV assessment involves analyzing historical purchase data, customer behavior, retention rates, and predictive analytics to forecast future buying patterns and revenue streams. By understanding the long-term value of each customer, sales professionals can segment accounts more effectively, identify high-potential opportunities, and justify investments in customer retention or upselling initiatives. This skill is immediately relevant in today’s competitive business environment, where customer acquisition costs are rising and sustainable growth depends on maximizing the value of existing relationships. Practical applications include informing account-based marketing strategies, guiding sales pipeline prioritization, and supporting negotiations with data-driven insights. CLV assessment also underpins key decisions in resource allocation, customer support, and loyalty program design. Mastery of this skill requires proficiency in data analysis, financial modeling, and the use of CRM and analytics tools. Ultimately, CLV assessment empowers sales teams to move beyond short-term transactions and focus on building long-term, mutually beneficial customer partnerships.

fc0eb636-fa28-48b9-956e-d9c89c5373ae.name: Customer Orientation
fc0eb636-fa28-48b9-956e-d9c89c5373ae.description: Customer orientation is a business approach that puts the needs of the customer over the needs of the business. Customer-oriented companies understand that the business won't thrive unless it consistently improves customer focus. It's a way of thinking that aligns your business goals with your customers' goals.

6e3da15d-4816-4030-8497-e6465d08cc01.name: Customer Service
6e3da15d-4816-4030-8497-e6465d08cc01.description: Customer service is the provision of service to customers before, during, and after a purchase. This makes it an important part of the value chain of clients. Each industry requires different levels of customer service, but in the end, the idea of a well-performed service is that of increasing revenues.

5e735ae5-f904-4313-ad26-45063b9c3e4c.name: Customer Success Metrics for Enterprise Accounts
5e735ae5-f904-4313-ad26-45063b9c3e4c.name_en: Customer Success Metrics for Enterprise Accounts
5e735ae5-f904-4313-ad26-45063b9c3e4c.description:
Customer Success Metrics for Enterprise Accounts is the specialized skill of identifying, tracking, analyzing, and leveraging quantitative and qualitative indicators that measure the health, value realization, and overall success of large, strategic customer relationships. In the context of enterprise accounts, these metrics go beyond basic customer satisfaction to encompass complex, multi-dimensional data points such as Net Promoter Score (NPS), Customer Health Score, product adoption rates, expansion and renewal rates, time-to-value, and executive engagement. Practitioners of this skill must be adept at collaborating with cross-functional teams to define success criteria tailored to each enterprise client, aligning metrics with both the customer’s business objectives and the vendor’s strategic goals. This skill is critical for proactively identifying risks and opportunities within high-value accounts, enabling customer success managers (CSMs) to drive retention, upsell, and advocacy. It also involves presenting actionable insights to internal stakeholders and customer executives, often using dashboards and business reviews to demonstrate ROI and business impact. In today’s business environment, where enterprise customers expect measurable outcomes and personalized engagement, mastery of customer success metrics is essential for maintaining competitive advantage, reducing churn, and fostering long-term partnerships. Typical use cases include quarterly business reviews (QBRs), executive reporting, and designing interventions to improve customer health and satisfaction.

15fdfaa1-299c-4efc-bd0f-8436babfd258.name: Customer Success Planning
15fdfaa1-299c-4efc-bd0f-8436babfd258.description:
Customer Success Planning is a strategic business skill focused on proactively designing, implementing, and managing tailored plans that ensure clients achieve their desired outcomes with a company's products or services. This skill is essential in today's competitive business environment, where customer retention, satisfaction, and long-term value realization are critical drivers of growth and profitability. Practitioners of Customer Success Planning work closely with clients to understand their unique goals, challenges, and success metrics, then develop actionable roadmaps that align product capabilities with client needs. This involves regular check-ins, progress tracking, and the identification of opportunities for expansion, such as renewals and upsells. Effective Customer Success Planning requires a deep understanding of customer journey mapping, stakeholder management, and the ability to leverage data-driven insights to anticipate risks and proactively address issues before they escalate. In practice, this skill is applied through the creation of success plans, executive business reviews, and the orchestration of cross-functional teams to deliver on customer commitments. It is highly relevant in SaaS, B2B, and service-oriented industries, where ongoing value delivery is paramount. By ensuring customers realize measurable value, organizations can foster loyalty, reduce churn, and drive sustainable revenue growth, making Customer Success Planning a cornerstone of modern business operations.

f81e9b77-1d71-4b05-b141-86f7173360fc.description: The ability to understand the needs of the target customer and to design a product that meets those needs, as well as the ability to provide excellent customer service and support.

d25ae84b-1bff-4604-b152-5958f34a28e5.name: Cypress
d25ae84b-1bff-4604-b152-5958f34a28e5.description: Cypress is a frontend test automation tool for regression testing of web applications. Cypress runs on Windows, Linux, and macOS. Cypress app is open-source software released under the MIT License, while the Cypress Cloud is a web application. Cypress has been compared to Selenium.

c66d3350-65aa-4a30-b630-7a43d1894efe.name: DNS
c66d3350-65aa-4a30-b630-7a43d1894efe.description:
The Domain Name System (DNS) is a hierarchical and distributed naming system for computers, services, and other resources in the Internet or other Internet Protocol (IP) networks. It associates various information with domain names (identification strings) assigned to each of the associated entities. Most prominently, it translates readily memorized domain names to the numerical IP addresses needed for locating and identifying computer services and devices with the underlying network protocols.[1] The Domain Name System has been an essential component of the functionality of the Internet since 1985.

The Domain Name System delegates the responsibility of assigning domain names and mapping those names to Internet resources by designating authoritative name servers for each domain. Network administrators may delegate authority over subdomains of their allocated name space to other name servers. This mechanism provides distributed and fault-tolerant service and was designed to avoid a single large central database. In addition, the DNS specifies the technical functionality of the database service that is at its core. It defines the DNS protocol, a detailed specification of the data structures and data communication exchanges used in the DNS, as part of the Internet protocol suite.   Ref:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_Name_System

e96ca445-b05a-43bc-ad90-692bedfbe868.name: DaoCloud
e96ca445-b05a-43bc-ad90-692bedfbe868.description: DaoCloud is a leading cloud native tech company focusing on helping enterprises for digital transformation with innovative technologies, products, solutions and consulting services. DaoCloud has been building a huge ecosystem in China with communities and partners.

d0497870-0ce3-49ee-9b4e-e1e59919f795.name: Dart
d0497870-0ce3-49ee-9b4e-e1e59919f795.description:
Dart is a client-optimized language for developing fast apps on any platform. Its goal is to offer the most productive programming language for multi-platform development, paired with a flexible execution runtime platform for app frameworks.

Languages are defined by their technical envelope—the choices made during development that shape the capabilities and strengths of a language. Dart is designed for a technical envelope that is particularly suited to client development, prioritizing both development (sub-second stateful hot reload) and high-quality production experiences across a wide variety of compilation targets (web, mobile, and desktop).  Ref:  https://dart.dev/overview

fb4ba2be-7cd0-4a7f-a98b-d0dff9fd14d4.name: Data Analysis Expressions (DAX)
fb4ba2be-7cd0-4a7f-a98b-d0dff9fd14d4.description: Data Analysis Expressions (DAX) is a formula expression language used in Analysis Services, Power BI, and Power Pivot in Excel. DAX formulas include functions, operators, and values to perform advanced calculations and queries on data in related tables and columns in tabular data models.

49eaaa21-3024-46f1-b6bc-769833ad85f5.name: Data Anonymization and De-identification Techniques
49eaaa21-3024-46f1-b6bc-769833ad85f5.description:
Data Anonymization and De-identification Techniques encompass the methods, tools, and best practices used to remove or obscure personally identifiable information (PII) and sensitive data from datasets, enabling organizations to share, analyze, and utilize data while protecting individual privacy and complying with regulatory requirements. This skill is critical in today's data-driven landscape, where organizations must balance the need for data utility with stringent privacy obligations under frameworks such as GDPR, HIPAA, and CCPA. Practitioners must understand and apply a range of techniques, including data masking, pseudonymization, generalization, suppression, and differential privacy, each with distinct trade-offs between data utility and risk of re-identification. Mastery of this skill requires familiarity with risk assessment methodologies (such as k-anonymity, l-diversity, and t-closeness), as well as hands-on experience with specialized tools (e.g., ARX, IBM Data Privacy Passports, Google Cloud DLP). Immediate applications include preparing datasets for machine learning, enabling secure data sharing with partners, supporting clinical research, and facilitating compliance audits. Effective anonymization and de-identification are foundational for ethical AI development, open data initiatives, and secure cloud migration. The skill also involves understanding attack vectors (e.g., linkage attacks), evaluating residual risk, and implementing ongoing monitoring to ensure data remains de-identified as external data sources evolve. As organizations increasingly leverage data for innovation, this skill is essential for enabling responsible analytics and collaboration without compromising individual privacy.

650a4f8e-d5b7-4e47-9f02-daa4098649f4.name: Data Breach Response Planning and Execution
650a4f8e-d5b7-4e47-9f02-daa4098649f4.name_en: Data Breach Response Planning and Execution
650a4f8e-d5b7-4e47-9f02-daa4098649f4.description:
Data Breach Response Planning and Execution is a critical technical skill that encompasses the design, implementation, and management of processes and protocols to effectively address data breaches in real time. This skill involves developing comprehensive incident response plans that align with current regulatory requirements (such as GDPR, HIPAA, or CCPA), organizational policies, and industry best practices. Practitioners must be adept at coordinating cross-functional teams—including IT, legal, compliance, communications, and executive leadership—to ensure a swift, coordinated, and compliant response to security incidents involving unauthorized access, disclosure, or loss of sensitive data. Key activities include threat detection, breach containment, forensic analysis, evidence preservation, root cause identification, and timely notification to affected parties and regulatory bodies. The skill also covers post-incident review, lessons learned, and the continuous improvement of response strategies. Immediate applications include minimizing operational disruption, reducing reputational and financial risk, and ensuring legal and contractual obligations are met. Effective execution requires familiarity with security information and event management (SIEM) tools, incident management platforms, and secure communication channels. In today's environment of escalating cyber threats and stringent data protection laws, this skill is essential for safeguarding organizational assets, maintaining customer trust, and demonstrating due diligence to stakeholders and regulators.

3d7b854e-110b-428a-acef-a2de2f601a45.name: Data Ethics and Bias Mitigation
3d7b854e-110b-428a-acef-a2de2f601a45.description:
Data Ethics and Bias Mitigation is a critical technical skill focused on identifying, evaluating, and addressing ethical concerns and biases within data-driven systems, particularly in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) applications. This skill encompasses the understanding and application of ethical frameworks, regulatory requirements (such as GDPR, CCPA), and industry standards to ensure that data collection, processing, and algorithmic decision-making are conducted responsibly and transparently. Practitioners in this area are adept at recognizing sources of bias—such as sampling bias, measurement bias, and algorithmic bias—and implementing strategies to reduce or eliminate their impact. This involves techniques like fairness-aware modeling, bias audits, explainable AI (XAI), and the use of de-biasing algorithms. The skill also requires collaboration with cross-functional teams to establish data governance policies, conduct impact assessments, and communicate ethical risks to stakeholders. Immediate applications include auditing datasets for representativeness, monitoring deployed models for disparate impact, and ensuring compliance with emerging AI ethics guidelines. The value of this skill lies in supporting organizational trust, legal compliance, and social responsibility, while enhancing the fairness and reliability of technical systems. In today’s environment, where AI systems influence critical decisions in finance, healthcare, hiring, and more, Data Ethics and Bias Mitigation is essential for building equitable and accountable technology.

b3e9e4d4-c8c2-4c93-bf88-66c62f5ab9ab.name: Data Mining
b3e9e4d4-c8c2-4c93-bf88-66c62f5ab9ab.description: Data mining is the process of searching and analyzing a large batch of raw data in order to identify patterns and extract useful information. Companies use data mining software to learn more about their customers. It can help them to develop more effective marketing strategies, increase sales, and decrease costs.

0c34898c-e59f-459c-823f-f14d7507623e.name: Data Privacy Compliance in Food Systems
0c34898c-e59f-459c-823f-f14d7507623e.name_en: Data Privacy Compliance in Food Systems
0c34898c-e59f-459c-823f-f14d7507623e.description:
Data Privacy Compliance in Food Systems is the technical skill set required to ensure that personal and sensitive data collected, processed, and transmitted throughout digitalized food supply chains is handled in accordance with relevant data protection laws, industry standards, and best practices. As food systems become increasingly reliant on digital technologies—such as IoT sensors, blockchain traceability, cloud-based inventory management, and consumer-facing apps—vast amounts of data are generated, including supplier information, employee records, and consumer purchase histories. This skill involves understanding and applying regulations such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), and sector-specific guidelines to safeguard data at every stage of the food supply chain. Practitioners must be adept at conducting privacy impact assessments, implementing data minimization and anonymization techniques, managing consent, and ensuring secure data storage and transfer. They must also coordinate with IT, legal, and operational teams to develop and enforce privacy policies, respond to data breaches, and maintain audit trails for compliance verification. Immediate applications include protecting consumer trust, avoiding regulatory penalties, and enabling secure data sharing between supply chain partners. This skill is critical today as food companies face heightened scrutiny from regulators and consumers alike, making robust data privacy compliance a non-negotiable aspect of technical operations in the food sector.

279eb48c-1f86-4b78-a5a8-1fa5e63d1eea.name: Data Privacy Engineering
279eb48c-1f86-4b78-a5a8-1fa5e63d1eea.description:
Data Privacy Engineering is the technical discipline focused on designing, building, and maintaining systems that ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and lawful processing of personal and sensitive data. This skill is critical in today's digital landscape, where organizations must comply with a complex web of global privacy regulations such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), and other emerging frameworks. Data Privacy Engineering involves embedding privacy-by-design principles into software development lifecycles, architecting systems to minimize data exposure, and implementing robust technical controls such as encryption, access management, data minimization, and anonymization. Practitioners must collaborate with legal, compliance, and security teams to translate regulatory requirements into actionable technical safeguards, conduct privacy impact assessments, and ensure ongoing monitoring and auditing of data flows. Typical use cases include building consent management platforms, designing secure data storage and transfer mechanisms, and automating data subject rights (DSR) processes such as access, deletion, and portability. The skill also encompasses the evaluation and integration of privacy-enhancing technologies (PETs), such as differential privacy and homomorphic encryption, to reduce risk while enabling data-driven innovation. Data Privacy Engineering is essential for safeguarding consumer trust, reducing the risk of data breaches and regulatory penalties, and enabling organizations to responsibly leverage data for business value in a rapidly evolving regulatory environment.

83d72bae-14e8-4ccd-9bc2-2212abe52d98.name: Data Privacy Impact Assessment
83d72bae-14e8-4ccd-9bc2-2212abe52d98.description:
Data Privacy Impact Assessment (DPIA) is a structured, systematic process used to evaluate and mitigate privacy risks associated with the collection, processing, storage, and sharing of personal data within technical systems and business processes. DPIAs are a critical requirement under global data protection regulations such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), and other regional privacy laws. The primary purpose of a DPIA is to identify potential impacts on individuals’ privacy rights, assess the necessity and proportionality of data processing activities, and implement controls to reduce risks to an acceptable level. This skill involves mapping data flows, analyzing data lifecycle stages, and evaluating the technical and organizational measures in place to protect data. Practitioners must collaborate with cross-functional teams—including IT, legal, security, and business stakeholders—to ensure that privacy risks are identified early in project lifecycles and that mitigation strategies are integrated into system design (privacy by design). DPIAs are essential for launching new technologies, products, or services that involve sensitive or large-scale data processing, and for responding to regulatory inquiries or audits. The skill requires familiarity with privacy risk assessment methodologies, threat modeling, data minimization techniques, and documentation best practices. Immediate applications include supporting compliance, reducing the likelihood of data breaches, and building trust with customers and regulators by demonstrating proactive privacy management.
