84e3a447-0108-4250-b12a-76609ba28bbe.name: Food Waste Reduction Initiatives in Supply Chains
84e3a447-0108-4250-b12a-76609ba28bbe.name_en: Food Waste Reduction Initiatives in Supply Chains
84e3a447-0108-4250-b12a-76609ba28bbe.description:
Food Waste Reduction Initiatives in Supply Chains is a critical business skill focused on designing, implementing, and managing strategies to minimize food loss and waste at every stage of the supply chain, from production and processing to distribution, retail, and consumption. This skill involves a deep understanding of supply chain operations, inventory management, demand forecasting, and collaboration with stakeholders including suppliers, logistics providers, retailers, and consumers. Practitioners leverage data analytics, process optimization, and innovative technologies to identify inefficiencies and points of waste, then develop targeted interventions such as improved storage solutions, smarter logistics, surplus food redistribution, and consumer education campaigns. The skill also requires knowledge of regulatory frameworks, sustainability standards, and reporting mechanisms relevant to food waste. In the current business landscape, reducing food waste is immediately important due to its direct impact on cost savings, operational efficiency, and corporate social responsibility. It addresses pressing environmental concerns by lowering greenhouse gas emissions and conserving resources, while also enhancing brand reputation and meeting consumer demand for sustainable practices. Typical use cases include implementing real-time inventory tracking to prevent spoilage, establishing partnerships with food banks for surplus redistribution, and optimizing procurement to align with actual demand. Mastery of this skill enables organizations to achieve both economic and environmental benefits, making it a vital competency for modern supply chain and sustainability professionals.

337b8e80-f8d5-449d-9eab-27162cc58db6.description: A state's foreign policy or external policy (as opposed to internal or domestic policy) is its objectives and activities in relation to its interactions with other states, unions, and other political entities, whether bilaterally or through multilateral platforms. The Encyclopedia Britannica notes that a government's foreign policy may be influenced by "domestic considerations, the policies or behaviour of other states, or plans to advance specific geopolitical designs

b9285ede-ea50-4c1a-a9fa-2f55137c2a4c.name: Forth
b9285ede-ea50-4c1a-a9fa-2f55137c2a4c.description: Forth is a procedural, concatenative, stack-oriented programming language and interactive development environment designed by Charles H. "Chuck" Moore and first used by other programmers in 1970. Although not an acronym, the language's name in its early years was often spelled in all capital letters as FORTH. The FORTH-79 and FORTH-83 implementations, which were not written by Moore, became de facto standards, and an official standardization of the language was published in 1994 as ANS Forth. A wide range of Forth derivatives existed before and after ANS Forth. The free software Gforth implementation is actively maintained, as are several commercially supported systems.  Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forth_(programming_language)

f535974c-84d8-43cc-a8cd-382f1595eb98.name: Fortran
f535974c-84d8-43cc-a8cd-382f1595eb98.description:
Fortran (/ˈfɔːrtræn/; formerly FORTRAN) is a third generation, compiled, imperative programming language that is especially suited to numeric computation and scientific computing.

Fortran was originally developed by IBM. It first compiled correctly in 1958. Fortran computer programs have been written to support scientific and engineering applications, such as numerical weather prediction, finite element analysis, computational fluid dynamics, geophysics, computational physics, crystallography and computational chemistry. It is a popular language for high-performance computing and is used for programs that benchmark and rank the world's fastest supercomputers.   Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortran

237994d4-ba17-4ff0-a941-f5d399f91bb1.name: Foundation Engineering
237994d4-ba17-4ff0-a941-f5d399f91bb1.description:
It is the engineering field of study devoted to the design of those structures which support other structures, most typically buildings, bridges or transportation infrastructure. It is at the periphery of Civil, Structural and Geotechnical Engineering disciplines and has distinct focus on soil-structure interaction.

It is also called as ground sill, which transfers loads to the ground. It is generally broken into two categories.

Shallow foundation
Deep foundation

ea1c8115-c8eb-427f-b8ab-0e7a20fe24d4.name: Friendliness
ea1c8115-c8eb-427f-b8ab-0e7a20fe24d4.description:
FriendlinessFriendliness refers to the ability to put up a warm personality that makes you approachable, easy to relate with and without any hostility.

Aside being warm and devoid of hostility, a friendly person is someone who has a great level of respect for others. He is not snobbish but respects people’s feelings, ideas, and beliefs. Even if they do not respect them, they don’t make it obvious to them.

At times, to be friendly means putting up a pretense that you love or admire someone even if you don’t. This includes being able to show patience and care, as well as spending enough time with people.

Friendliness is more of a character than a skill. However, it can be learnt and improved upon as well.

9656761d-c588-427b-9afa-2dc2dfa73110.name: Functional Architecture
9656761d-c588-427b-9afa-2dc2dfa73110.description: Functional Architecture is a term that originates out of enterprise architecture. It deals with how systems function to carry out end-to-end processes in order to maximize efficiency. Like most topics involving ERP systems, there are a few schools of thought when it comes to systems design.

596b88ed-56e0-425c-a991-8f933179af5b.name: Functional requirement
596b88ed-56e0-425c-a991-8f933179af5b.description:
In software engineering and systems engineering, a functional requirement defines a function of a system or its component, where a function is described as a summary (or specification or statement) of behavior between inputs and outputs.

Functional requirements may involve calculations, technical details, data manipulation and processing, and other specific functionality that define what a system is supposed to accomplish. Behavioral requirements describe all the cases where the system uses the functional requirements, these are captured in use cases. Functional requirements are supported by non-functional requirements (also known as "quality requirements"), which impose constraints on the design or implementation (such as performance requirements, security, or reliability). Generally, functional requirements are expressed in the form "system must do <requirement>," while non-functional requirements take the form "system shall be <requirement>." The plan for implementing functional requirements is detailed in the system design, whereas non-functional requirements are detailed in the system architecture.

As defined in requirements engineering, functional requirements specify particular results of a system. This should be contrasted with non-functional requirements, which specify overall characteristics such as cost and reliability. Functional requirements drive the application architecture of a system, while non-functional requirements drive the technical architecture of a system.

In some cases a requirements analyst generates use cases after gathering and validating a set of functional requirements. The hierarchy of functional requirements collection and change, broadly speaking, is: user/stakeholder request → analyze → use case → incorporate. Stakeholders make a request; systems engineers attempt to discuss, observe, and understand the aspects of the requirement; use cases, entity relationship diagrams, and other models are built to validate the requirement; and, if documented and approved, the requirement is implemented/incorporated. Each use case illustrates behavioral scenarios through one or more functional requirements. Often, though, an analyst will begin by eliciting a set of use cases, from which the analyst can derive the functional requirements that must be implemented to allow a user to perform each use case.  Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_requirement

93f88349-788b-46c4-ac11-18fffa9056b1.name: Functional testing
93f88349-788b-46c4-ac11-18fffa9056b1.description: Functional testing is a type of testing that seeks to establish whether each application feature works as per the software requirements. Each function is compared to the corresponding requirement to ascertain whether its output is consistent with the end user's expectations.

98f3c861-ef0a-47f2-8aa9-33a431de71a6.name: GenAI Model Abuse Prevention
98f3c861-ef0a-47f2-8aa9-33a431de71a6.description:
GenAI Model Abuse Prevention is a critical technical skill focused on identifying, mitigating, and managing the risks associated with the malicious use and abuse of generative AI models. As organizations increasingly deploy large language models and other generative AI systems in production environments, the potential for misuse—such as prompt injection, data leakage, model inversion, generation of harmful or biased content, and unauthorized access—poses significant threats to security, compliance, and brand reputation. This skill encompasses the implementation of robust safeguards, including input/output filtering, adversarial testing, red teaming, and continuous monitoring for anomalous or policy-violating behaviors. Practitioners must be adept at integrating technical controls such as rate limiting, content moderation APIs, and user authentication, as well as leveraging threat intelligence to stay ahead of emerging attack vectors. Additionally, GenAI Model Abuse Prevention requires a strong understanding of regulatory frameworks (e.g., GDPR, NIST AI Risk Management Framework), organizational policies, and ethical considerations to ensure compliance and responsible AI deployment. Typical use cases include securing customer-facing chatbots, protecting proprietary data in enterprise AI applications, and enforcing usage policies in AI-powered content generation platforms. This skill is immediately relevant and essential today, as the rapid adoption of generative AI technologies has outpaced the development of standardized safeguards, making proactive abuse prevention a cornerstone of secure and trustworthy AI operations.

d61eb521-86b4-4d06-bb38-c6fc83215984.name: GenAI Output Traceability
d61eb521-86b4-4d06-bb38-c6fc83215984.description:
GenAI Output Traceability is the technical capability to systematically track, document, and audit the outputs generated by artificial intelligence models—particularly generative AI systems such as large language models, image generators, and code synthesis tools. This skill encompasses the design and implementation of mechanisms that capture metadata about model inputs, outputs, versioning, prompt history, and the contextual parameters influencing each generation event. It is essential for ensuring accountability, transparency, and compliance with regulatory requirements such as the EU AI Act, as well as internal governance standards. Practitioners must be proficient in integrating traceability features into AI pipelines, leveraging tools such as audit logs, cryptographic hashes, data lineage frameworks, and model registries. They must also understand how to balance traceability with privacy, security, and performance considerations. Immediate applications include supporting incident investigations, enabling reproducibility of AI-driven decisions, facilitating external audits, and providing evidence for responsible AI claims. GenAI Output Traceability is increasingly critical in sectors like finance, healthcare, and legal, where explainability and auditability are mandated. The skill also involves familiarity with relevant standards (e.g., ISO/IEC 42001), and the ability to collaborate with compliance, data governance, and engineering teams to operationalize traceability at scale. Mastery of this skill is vital for organizations seeking to deploy generative AI responsibly and maintain trust with stakeholders.

941d9567-1819-4396-9faa-99e8295ca47b.name: GenAI Output Validation and Monitoring
941d9567-1819-4396-9faa-99e8295ca47b.description:
GenAI Output Validation and Monitoring is a critical technical skill focused on the continuous oversight, assessment, and quality assurance of outputs generated by generative AI systems (such as large language models, image generators, and code synthesis tools). This skill encompasses the design, implementation, and operation of processes and tools that systematically evaluate AI-generated content for accuracy, safety, ethical compliance, and alignment with organizational or regulatory standards. Practitioners must be adept at leveraging automated and manual validation techniques, including prompt engineering, output filtering, adversarial testing, and human-in-the-loop review. The skill also involves real-time monitoring of deployed AI systems to detect and mitigate harmful, biased, or unintended outputs, using metrics such as toxicity scores, factual consistency, and user feedback loops. Immediate applications include content moderation, compliance checks, brand safety assurance, and the prevention of misinformation or data leakage. GenAI Output Validation and Monitoring is essential for organizations deploying generative AI in production environments, ensuring responsible AI use and maintaining trust with users and stakeholders. It requires familiarity with monitoring frameworks, audit trails, explainability tools, and incident response protocols specific to AI outputs. This skill is currently indispensable due to the rapid adoption of generative AI technologies and the heightened scrutiny around their societal and business impacts.

029e8baf-6663-4c5f-b2fe-913f4791354d.name: GenAI Security Risk Assessment
029e8baf-6663-4c5f-b2fe-913f4791354d.description:
GenAI Security Risk Assessment is the systematic process of identifying, evaluating, and mitigating security risks unique to generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) systems. As organizations rapidly adopt GenAI models for tasks such as content creation, code generation, and decision support, new security challenges emerge that differ significantly from traditional IT or machine learning systems. This skill involves understanding and analyzing attack vectors specific to GenAI, such as prompt injection, model inversion, data poisoning, output manipulation, and adversarial attacks. Practitioners must assess risks related to model confidentiality, integrity, and availability, as well as the potential for misuse, data leakage, and unauthorized access to proprietary or sensitive training data. The skill requires familiarity with threat modeling tailored to GenAI architectures (e.g., large language models, diffusion models), evaluation of supply chain vulnerabilities (including third-party model and dataset provenance), and the application of security controls such as input validation, output monitoring, and robust access management. Effective GenAI Security Risk Assessment also considers compliance with emerging standards and regulations (e.g., NIST AI Risk Management Framework, EU AI Act), and integrates with broader organizational security practices, including incident response and continuous monitoring. Immediate applications include pre-deployment risk reviews, ongoing monitoring of deployed GenAI systems, and the development of mitigation strategies to ensure safe, responsible, and resilient AI adoption. This skill is critical today as GenAI systems become integral to business operations, amplifying both their value and their risk profile.

ac7bd65d-4c7f-47e6-b892-70064ed0007e.name: GenAI Security and Abuse Prevention
ac7bd65d-4c7f-47e6-b892-70064ed0007e.description:
GenAI Security and Abuse Prevention is a critical technical skill focused on identifying, mitigating, and managing the unique security risks and abuse vectors associated with generative AI systems. As organizations rapidly adopt large language models (LLMs), image generators, and other GenAI technologies, new threats have emerged, including prompt injection, data leakage, model inversion, unauthorized content generation, and the facilitation of phishing, misinformation, or other malicious activities. This skill encompasses the ability to design, implement, and monitor robust safeguards such as input/output filtering, adversarial testing, red-teaming, and the integration of AI-specific security frameworks (e.g., OWASP Top 10 for LLMs). Practitioners must understand the technical underpinnings of GenAI models, including how they process, store, and generate data, as well as the attack surfaces unique to these systems. Key competencies include threat modeling for GenAI pipelines, abuse detection using automated and manual review processes, and the application of responsible AI principles to ensure compliance with organizational policies and regulatory requirements (e.g., GDPR, NIST AI RMF). Immediate applications include securing customer-facing chatbots, protecting proprietary data from model leakage, and preventing the generation of harmful or non-compliant content. This skill is essential for technical professionals tasked with deploying GenAI in production environments, as it directly addresses the urgent need to safeguard organizational assets, maintain user trust, and comply with evolving legal and ethical standards in today's AI-driven landscape.

f6f60a45-0741-49d2-a55d-e68d300106a4.name: GenAI UX and UI Prototyping
f6f60a45-0741-49d2-a55d-e68d300106a4.description: GenAI UX/UI Prototyping is the practice of utilizing generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) tools to conceptualize, design, test, and refine user experience (UX) and user interface (UI) designs rapidly. It leverages AI-driven technologies such as natural language prompts, automated design generation, adaptive user experience simulations, and predictive analytics to accelerate design iteration, enhance creativity, and produce user-centric digital products.

c0792ca0-9088-4046-ae80-d83f0525ec8c.name: GenAI assisted software test development
c0792ca0-9088-4046-ae80-d83f0525ec8c.description: GenAI Assisted Software Test Development involves the utilization of generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) technologies to design, generate, automate, and enhance software testing processes. It combines human expertise in software testing methodologies with advanced AI capabilities to accelerate test creation, improve test coverage, predict defect patterns, and optimize quality assurance (QA) workflows.

57a85563-d942-49cb-8867-a294e58e3d9f.name: Generative artificial intelligence
57a85563-d942-49cb-8867-a294e58e3d9f.description: Generative artificial intelligence (also generative AI or GenAI[1]) is artificial intelligence capable of generating text, images, or other media, using generative models.[2][3][4] Generative AI models learn the patterns and structure of their input training data and then generate new data that has similar characteristics.

c8da44a4-33f9-41ce-9a04-035334ec8109.name: Generosity
c8da44a4-33f9-41ce-9a04-035334ec8109.description: Generosity is the willingness to share your time, resources, knowledge, or skills with others without expecting anything in return. Being generous can have a range of positive effects on your well-being, motivation, creativity, and relationships.

78dc8621-e953-4d56-94af-f8e5a2503c89.name: Geotechnical Engineering
78dc8621-e953-4d56-94af-f8e5a2503c89.description: Geotechnical engineering is the study of the behaviour of soils under the influence of loading forces and soil-water interactions. This knowledge is applied to the design of foundations, retaining walls, earth dams, clay liners, and geosynthetics for waste containment.

f1d39bd1-3928-4761-84db-5c18caae5823.name: Gherkin
f1d39bd1-3928-4761-84db-5c18caae5823.description: Gherkin is a language that developers use to define tests in Cucumber. Since this language uses plain English, it's meant to describe use cases for a software system in a way that can be read and understood by almost anyone.

77bab918-87cb-45e2-9a65-8229c5161ebc.name: Git
77bab918-87cb-45e2-9a65-8229c5161ebc.description:
Git is a free and open source distributed version control system designed to handle everything from small to very large projects with speed and efficiency.

Git is easy to learn and has a tiny footprint with lightning fast performance. It outclasses SCM tools like Subversion, CVS, Perforce, and ClearCase with features like cheap local branching, convenient staging areas, and multiple workflows.

f0a521fb-c707-425d-8347-9cdf228f83e4.name: GitHub Actions
f0a521fb-c707-425d-8347-9cdf228f83e4.description: GitHub Actions is a continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) platform that allows you to automate your build, test, and deployment pipeline. You can create workflows that build and test every pull request to your repository, or deploy merged pull requests to production.

318e6402-7a66-402b-9b91-8c635da80a55.name: GitHub
318e6402-7a66-402b-9b91-8c635da80a55.description: GitHub is an increasingly popular programming resource used for code sharing. It's a social networking site for programmers that many companies and organizations use to facilitate project management and collaboration.

8c7da164-ff12-4516-a0f1-6dd2dfa18274.name: GitLab
8c7da164-ff12-4516-a0f1-6dd2dfa18274.description: GitLab is an open source code repository and collaborative software development platform for large DevOps and DevSecOps projects. GitLab is free for individuals. GitLab offers a location for online code storage and capabilities for issue tracking and CI/CD.

554b10db-600e-453d-aaa0-9c86b1c69e47.name: Gitflow
554b10db-600e-453d-aaa0-9c86b1c69e47.description: Gitflow is an alternative Git branching model that involves the use of feature branches and multiple primary branches. It was first published and made popular by Vincent Driessen at nvie.

74b8afa2-3f7c-4e8e-a109-78309f5ffe12.name: Global Account Management
74b8afa2-3f7c-4e8e-a109-78309f5ffe12.description:
Global Account Management is a critical business skill focused on the strategic oversight and coordination of relationships with multinational clients across multiple geographies. This skill involves managing complex, high-value accounts that operate in diverse markets, often requiring tailored solutions that address varying regulatory, cultural, and operational requirements. Professionals skilled in Global Account Management act as the primary point of contact for global clients, ensuring consistent service delivery, harmonized communication, and alignment of business objectives across regions. They are responsible for developing and executing account strategies that maximize value for both the client and the organization, leveraging cross-border sales opportunities, and fostering long-term partnerships. Key aspects include understanding global supply chains, navigating international compliance and legal frameworks, and orchestrating internal teams across countries to deliver integrated solutions. Effective Global Account Managers must possess strong negotiation skills, cultural intelligence, and the ability to manage virtual teams and complex stakeholder networks. In today's interconnected business environment, this skill is immediately relevant for companies seeking to expand their global footprint, retain major clients, and drive revenue growth through coordinated, client-centric approaches. Typical use cases include managing global contracts, leading international sales initiatives, and serving as the liaison between multinational clients and internal business units to ensure seamless service and value delivery.

3deabc27-e7ca-49a2-bedd-469b1c790e9a.description: Go, also called Golang or Go language, is an Open Source programming language that Google developed. Software developers use Go in an array of operating systems and frameworks to develop web applications, cloud and networking services, and other types of software.

326eb2ac-51b3-45ef-9e54-93df8d7b63a4.name: Google Cloud
326eb2ac-51b3-45ef-9e54-93df8d7b63a4.description: Google Cloud consists of a set of physical assets, such as computers and hard disk drives, and virtual resources, such as virtual machines (VMs), that are contained in Google's data centers around the globe. Each data center location is in a region.

89011ed9-542f-43e6-a75f-bd668108eb4f.name: Google Lighthouse
89011ed9-542f-43e6-a75f-bd668108eb4f.description: Google Lighthouse is a free, open-source tool that can help you improve your website's speed, performance, and overall experience. Generating Lighthouse reports makes it easier to enhance the quality of your web pages. There are a few different ways you can use the tool. You can run it via: Chrome DevTools.

7e59cd72-d29c-4d60-99da-5319484a8c46.name: Google Play app publishing
7e59cd72-d29c-4d60-99da-5319484a8c46.description: The Google Play Custom App Publishing API lets your enterprise customers publish private apps (also called custom apps) to their managed Google Play store directly from your EMM console or IDE, eliminating the need for IT admins to access the Google Play Console each time they publish a private app to their organization.

007e52d6-a428-4438-a117-bccf58a81243.name: Grafana
007e52d6-a428-4438-a117-bccf58a81243.description: Grafana is a multi-platform open source analytics and interactive visualization web application. It can produce charts, graphs, and alerts for the web when connected to supported data sources.

04dcc37c-482c-413f-836e-268d572cc784.name: GraphQL
04dcc37c-482c-413f-836e-268d572cc784.description: GraphQL is a query language for APIs and a runtime for fulfilling those queries with your existing data. GraphQL provides a complete and understandable description of the data in your API, gives clients the power to ask for exactly what they need and nothing more, makes it easier to evolve APIs over time, and enables powerful developer tools.

f141b4bb-e6c6-4a14-8533-e34a8bce72b4.name: Green Software Engineering
f141b4bb-e6c6-4a14-8533-e34a8bce72b4.description:
Green Software Engineering is the practice of designing, developing, deploying, and maintaining software systems with a primary focus on minimizing their environmental impact. This skill integrates sustainability principles into the software development lifecycle, emphasizing energy efficiency, resource optimization, and carbon footprint reduction. Practitioners apply techniques such as efficient algorithm design, code optimization, and judicious use of cloud resources to reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions associated with software operation. Green Software Engineering also involves selecting sustainable hosting options, leveraging renewable energy-powered data centers, and utilizing tools for measuring and reporting software-related emissions (e.g., the Software Carbon Intensity (SCI) specification). It requires familiarity with regulatory requirements, such as the EU Green Deal and emerging sustainability standards, ensuring compliance and supporting organizational ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) goals. Typical use cases include optimizing backend services to reduce server load, refactoring legacy applications for lower energy usage, and integrating sustainability metrics into DevOps pipelines. This skill is increasingly important today as organizations face mounting pressure from regulators, customers, and investors to demonstrate environmental responsibility. By embedding sustainability into technical decision-making, Green Software Engineering enables companies to reduce operational costs, enhance brand reputation, and contribute meaningfully to global climate action.

9c0c2195-2db0-4b3c-b935-e0ce471b26e8.name: Groovy
9c0c2195-2db0-4b3c-b935-e0ce471b26e8.description: Apache Groovy is a powerful, optionally typed and dynamic language, with static-typing and static compilation capabilities, for the Java platform aimed at improving developer productivity thanks to a concise, familiar and easy to learn syntax. It integrates smoothly with any Java program, and immediately delivers to your application powerful features, including scripting capabilities, Domain-Specific Language authoring, runtime and compile-time meta-programming and functional programming.

349efc41-8fea-45b1-afc0-880836efe281.name: HTML
349efc41-8fea-45b1-afc0-880836efe281.description: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the code that is used to structure a web page and its content. For example, content could be structured within a set of paragraphs, a list of bulleted points, or using images and data tables.

8405cff2-3ee8-4655-a457-508b640d868c.name: HTML5
8405cff2-3ee8-4655-a457-508b640d868c.description: HTML5 is the latest version of HTML and supports new markup language functionalities such as multimedia, new tags and elements as well as new APIs. HTML5 also supports audio and video

2258790d-47d8-4658-a2c8-d0e5d8ca144a.name: HTTP
2258790d-47d8-4658-a2c8-d0e5d8ca144a.description: The Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) is the foundation of the World Wide Web, and is used to load web pages using hypertext links. HTTP is an application layer protocol designed to transfer information between networked devices and runs on top of other layers of the network protocol stack.

3a2ba2ee-6544-482f-b970-866ecd969ed6.name: HTTP/2
3a2ba2ee-6544-482f-b970-866ecd969ed6.description:
HTTP/2 (originally named HTTP/2.0) is a major revision of the HTTP network protocol used by the World Wide Web. It was derived from the earlier experimental SPDY protocol, originally developed by Google. HTTP/2 was developed by the HTTP Working Group (also called httpbis, where "bis" means "twice") of the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF). HTTP/2 is the first new version of HTTP since HTTP/1.1, which was standardized in RFC 2068 in 1997. The Working Group presented HTTP/2 to the Internet Engineering Steering Group (IESG) for consideration as a Proposed Standard in December 2014,[6][7] and IESG approved it to publish as Proposed Standard on February 17, 2015 (and was updated in February 2020 in regard to TLS 1.3 and again in June 2022). The initial HTTP/2 specification was published as RFC 7540 on May 14, 2015.[10]

The standardization effort was supported by Chrome, Opera, Firefox, Internet Explorer 11, Safari, Amazon Silk, and Edge browsers. Most major browsers had added HTTP/2 support by the end of 2015. About 97% of web browsers used have the capability (and 100% of "tracked desktop" web browsers).[13] As of July 2023, 36% (after topping out at just over 50%) of the top 10 million websites support HTTP/2.

Its successor is HTTP/3, a major revision that builds on the concepts established by HTTP/2.   Ref:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP/2

b3d9145b-a5c6-44de-9e09-f06a72ed267f.name: HTTP/3
b3d9145b-a5c6-44de-9e09-f06a72ed267f.description:
HTTP/3 is the third major version of the Hypertext Transfer Protocol used to exchange information on the World Wide Web, complementing the widely-deployed HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2. Unlike previous versions which relied on the well-established TCP (published in 1974), HTTP/3 uses QUIC, a multiplexed transport protocol built on UDP. On 6 June 2022, IETF published HTTP/3 as a Proposed Standard in RFC 9114.

HTTP/3 uses similar semantics compared to earlier revisions of the protocol, including the same request methods, status codes, and message fields, but encodes them and maintains session state differently. However, partially due to the protocol's adoption of QUIC, HTTP/3 has lower latency and loads more quickly in real-world usage when compared with previous versions: in some cases over four times as fast than with HTTP/1.1 (which, for many websites, is the only HTTP version deployed).

As of April 2024, HTTP/3 is at least partially supported by 97% of all web browser installations and 98% of mobile web browser installations tracked by "Can I Use", a website that tracks and provides information on web technologies compatibility with different web browsers. HTTP/3 is supported by 29% of the top 10 million websites. It has been supported by Chromium (and derived projects including Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Samsung Internet, and Opera) since April 2020 and by Mozilla Firefox since May 2021. Safari 14 implemented the protocol but it remains disabled by default.  Ref:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP/3

9c777678-1500-4e22-bb33-efb05a6129ca.name: Hazelcast
9c777678-1500-4e22-bb33-efb05a6129ca.description:
Hazelcast is a distributed computation and storage platform for consistently low-latency querying, aggregation and stateful computation against event streams and traditional data sources. It allows you to quickly build resource-efficient, real-time applications. You can deploy it at any scale from small edge devices to a large cluster of cloud instances.

Hazelcast can process data on a set of networked and clustered computers that pool together their random access memories (RAM) to let applications share data with other applications running in the cluster. When data is stored in RAM, applications run a lot faster since it does not need to be retrieved from disk and put into RAM prior to processing. Using Hazelcast, you can store and process your data in RAM, spread and replicate it across a cluster of machines; replication gives you resilience to failures of cluster members.

Hazelcast is implemented in Java language and has clients for Java, C++, .NET, REST, Python, Go and Node.js. Hazelcast also speaks Memcached and REST protocols.

Your cloud-native applications can easily use Hazelcast. It is flexible enough to use as a data and computing platform out-of-the-box or as a framework for your own cloud-native applications and microservices.

Hazelcast is designed to be lightweight and easy to use. Since it is delivered as a compact library, it easily plugs into your software solution.

It is designed to scale up to hundreds of members and thousands of clients. When you add new members, they automatically discover the cluster and linearly increase both the memory and processing capacity. The members maintain a TCP connection between each other and all communication is performed through this layer. Each cluster member is configured to be the same in terms of functionality. The oldest member (the first member created in the cluster) automatically performs the stored and streaming data assignment to cluster members. If the oldest member dies, the second oldest member takes over.

Hazelcast offers simple scalability, partitioning (sharding), and re-balancing out-of-the-box. It does not require any extra coordination processes. NoSQL and traditional databases are difficult to scale out and manage. They require additional processes for coordination and high availability. With Hazelcast, when you start another process to add more capacity, data and backups are automatically and evenly balanced.

584b63cc-787a-446b-b977-756b448237f0.name: Helm
584b63cc-787a-446b-b977-756b448237f0.description: A Helm chart is a package that contains all the resources you need to deploy an application to a Kubernetes cluster. This package has YAML files for deployments, services, secrets, and config maps that set up your application as needed.

0f0dd972-7872-4300-ac76-b58f13b37d50.name: Hibernate
0f0dd972-7872-4300-ac76-b58f13b37d50.description: Hibernate is an open source Object-Relational Persistence and Query service for any Java Application. Hibernate maps Java classes to database tables and from Java data types to SQL data types and relieves the developer from most common data persistence related programming tasks.

5772dc8f-9ca7-42c1-85a5-a40d7d45dd16.name: Hiring process
5772dc8f-9ca7-42c1-85a5-a40d7d45dd16.description: The hiring process is the process of reviewing applications, selecting the right candidates to interview, testing candidates, choosing between candidates to make the decision and performing various pre-employment tests and checks.

f9043017-9bbb-4f84-bede-be0b0bb02d96.name: Hubspot
f9043017-9bbb-4f84-bede-be0b0bb02d96.description: Hubspot products and services aim to provide tools for customer relationship management, social media marketing, content management, lead generation, web analytics, search engine optimization, live chat, and customer support.

699e9579-56de-478f-8a5b-2607cdf04abc.name: Human Resource Management
699e9579-56de-478f-8a5b-2607cdf04abc.description: Human resource management is the strategic and coherent approach to the effective and efficient management of people in a company or organization such that they help their business gain a competitive advantage. It is designed to maximize employee performance in service of an employer's strategic objectives.

2876800e-e32c-4e41-ac93-e7e511872fe3.name: Human-centered AI (HCAI)
2876800e-e32c-4e41-ac93-e7e511872fe3.description: Human-centered AI (HCAI) is a common AI design principle that calls for AI to continuously benefit from human input.

27eba290-813a-4966-b868-7988e7854564.name: Human-in-the-Loop AI Oversight
27eba290-813a-4966-b868-7988e7854564.description:
Human-in-the-Loop (HITL) AI Oversight is a critical technical skill focused on integrating human judgment and intervention into automated AI systems to ensure responsible, accountable, and reliable outcomes. This skill involves designing, implementing, and maintaining workflows where humans review, validate, or override AI-generated decisions, particularly in high-stakes or sensitive domains such as healthcare diagnostics, financial services, autonomous vehicles, and content moderation. Practitioners must understand the limitations of current AI models, including issues of bias, explainability, and robustness, and establish protocols for escalation, exception handling, and continuous feedback. HITL AI Oversight requires proficiency in monitoring AI outputs, setting up alerting systems, and using tools such as model monitoring dashboards (e.g., Evidently AI, Fiddler), annotation platforms, and audit trails to track decision rationale. It also encompasses knowledge of regulatory and ethical frameworks (e.g., GDPR, AI Act), risk assessment, and incident response. Immediate applications include preventing automation errors, ensuring compliance with legal standards, and maintaining user trust by providing transparency and recourse. This skill is essential today as organizations deploy AI in production environments where unchecked automation can lead to significant harm or reputational risk. Effective HITL AI Oversight balances the efficiency of automation with the nuanced understanding and accountability that only human reviewers can provide.

4d24cd57-04b7-4df1-9bd5-c601b65364e3.name: Humility
4d24cd57-04b7-4df1-9bd5-c601b65364e3.description: Humility is an attribute that means you're free from egotism and arrogance. Instead, being humble means you tend to think of others more, including how your actions can affect those you work with and the customers and clients you serve

44999c00-af0b-41f3-85cd-b3bc1c0c8925.name: Hybrid Cloud
44999c00-af0b-41f3-85cd-b3bc1c0c8925.description: A hybrid cloud—sometimes called a cloud hybrid—is a computing environment that combines an on-premises datacenter (also called a private cloud) with a public cloud, allowing data and applications to be shared between them. Some people define hybrid cloud infrastructure to include "multicloud" configurations where an organization uses more than one public cloud in addition to their on-premises datacenter.

53ce354a-8ca5-4e58-8c27-6189fbc41d5c.name: Hydraulic and Hydrological Analysis
53ce354a-8ca5-4e58-8c27-6189fbc41d5c.description: Hydrologic analyses are performed to quantify the volumetric flow rate of water draining from a watershed (i.e., drainage area) over time. The amount of water that flows from a watershed depends on the characteristics of the watershed (e.g., size, land cover, antecedent moisture, and steepness) and the presence of water (e.g., the intensity and duration of a precipitation event, or regulation from a dam). Hydraulic analyses are performed to determine the depth of flow, flow velocity, and forces from flowing water on a surface or at hydraulic structures. These studies are necessary components in the hydraulic design and analysis of structures.

c5a80e93-dd68-4714-8ec2-334c7996b80e.name: Hystrix
c5a80e93-dd68-4714-8ec2-334c7996b80e.description: Hystrix is a latency and fault tolerance library designed to isolate points of access to remote systems, services and 3rd party libraries, stop cascading failure and enable resilience in complex distributed systems where failure is inevitable.

f605c29f-dfdc-4288-bd6f-901255cf4cc7.name: IBM DB2
f605c29f-dfdc-4288-bd6f-901255cf4cc7.description: Db2 is a family of data management products developed by IBM, including the relational database management system (RDBMS) first introduced in 1983 on its Multiple Virtual Storage (MVS) mainframe.

66d3cb9b-3591-4ca9-b438-c5c95df2ba20.name: IDE
66d3cb9b-3591-4ca9-b438-c5c95df2ba20.description: An integrated development environment (IDE) is a software application that helps programmers develop software code efficiently.

6b27d2d0-c08b-44d8-b553-4af9fab2ef9d.name: IFS Applications
6b27d2d0-c08b-44d8-b553-4af9fab2ef9d.description: IFS is a leading global enterprise software vendor to industries where asset management, manufacturing, field service management, supply chain management, or project management are core disciplines. More than 2,100 companies in over 60 countries rely on IFS Applications, a component-based suite for product & asset lifecycle management that can be configured for ERP, EAM, project-based ERP, field service management, or a combination of all four. IFS Applications has been evolving to meet changing customer needs since 1983 and is configured for agility, usability, and low total cost of ownership in its targeted industries.

212f470b-9d03-488f-8ae7-6ddcddb0a653.name: ISO 25010
212f470b-9d03-488f-8ae7-6ddcddb0a653.description: ISO25010 describes two quality models: The quality in use model composed of five characteristics (some of which are further sub-divided into sub-characteristics) that relate to the outcome of interaction when a product is used in a particular context of use.

298d3028-b77f-4c74-9f9b-8490d55fec0b.name: ISO9126
298d3028-b77f-4c74-9f9b-8490d55fec0b.description: The fundamental objective of the ISO/IEC 9126 standard is to address some of the well-known human biases that can adversely affect the delivery and perception of a software development project. These biases include changing priorities after the start of a project or not having any clear definitions of "success". By clarifying, then agreeing on the project priorities and subsequently converting abstract priorities (compliance) to measurable values (output data can be validated against schema X with zero intervention), ISO/IEC 9126 tries to develop a common understanding of the project's objectives and goals.

66d94596-96bb-4577-84f4-3e662393d8ee.name: ISTQB
66d94596-96bb-4577-84f4-3e662393d8ee.description: ISTQB Certified Tester is a standardized qualification for software testers and the certification is offered by the ISTQB. The qualifications are based on a syllabus, and there is a hierarchy of qualifications and guidelines for accreditation and examination. More than 1 million ISTQB exams have been delivered and over 721,000 certifications issued; the ISTQB consists of 67 member boards worldwide representing more than 100 countries as of April 2021.[

cbe7c456-ef6f-43d0-acca-cc43fb1b31d9.name: IT Energy Efficiency Optimization
cbe7c456-ef6f-43d0-acca-cc43fb1b31d9.description:
IT Energy Efficiency Optimization is the systematic practice of analyzing, designing, and managing IT infrastructure and operations to minimize energy consumption while maintaining or improving performance, reliability, and scalability. This skill is crucial in today’s digital landscape, where data centers, cloud services, and enterprise networks are significant energy consumers and contributors to organizational carbon footprints. Practitioners leverage a combination of hardware and software strategies, such as server virtualization, workload consolidation, dynamic resource allocation, and the deployment of energy-efficient hardware (e.g., low-power CPUs, SSDs). They also utilize monitoring and analytics tools to track real-time power usage effectiveness (PUE), identify inefficiencies, and implement corrective actions. Key competencies include understanding power management protocols, optimizing cooling systems, and integrating renewable energy sources where feasible. IT Energy Efficiency Optimization directly supports sustainability goals, regulatory compliance (such as ISO 50001 or EU directives), and cost reduction by lowering utility expenses and extending equipment lifespan. Typical use cases include optimizing data center layouts, automating power-down of idle resources, and implementing green IT policies across distributed environments. This skill is immediately relevant as organizations face increasing pressure to reduce environmental impact and operational costs, making it a core competency for IT architects, system administrators, and sustainability officers.

62179be5-a3b0-4608-8d2a-b6833c71fc06.name: ITIL service design
62179be5-a3b0-4608-8d2a-b6833c71fc06.description: ITIL service design is the second stage of the ITIL service management lifecycle. Service design provides guidelines and best practices for designing new IT processes and services and preparing them for a live environment.

2663a5b9-11d4-4f43-8629-7c4648cdaf24.name: Identity and access management (IAM)
2663a5b9-11d4-4f43-8629-7c4648cdaf24.description: Identity and access management (IAM) ensures that the right people and job roles in your organization (identities) can access the tools they need to do their jobs. Identity management and access systems enable your organization to manage employee apps without logging into each app as an administrator. Identity and access management systems enable your organization to manage a range of identities including people, software, and hardware like robotics and IoT devices.

4145a399-5470-4e0f-8e36-b9206856ca7c.name: Improvisation
4145a399-5470-4e0f-8e36-b9206856ca7c.description: Improvisation, often shortened to improv, is the activity of making or doing something not planned beforehand, using whatever can be found.

a83c7f04-e9c6-4e8d-bcdf-fc77cc7ce3d1.name: Industrial design
a83c7f04-e9c6-4e8d-bcdf-fc77cc7ce3d1.description: Industrial design is a process of design applied to physical products that are to be manufactured by mass production.[1][2] It is the creative act of determining and defining a product's form and features, which takes place in advance of the manufacture or production of the product. It consists purely of repeated, often automated, replication,[3][4] while craft-based design is a process or approach in which the form of the product is determined by the product's creator largely concurrent with the act of its production

17dc42f3-020c-43a6-9703-adb5867cf08d.name: Influencer Marketing
17dc42f3-020c-43a6-9703-adb5867cf08d.description: Collaborating with industry or social media influencers to promote your products or services to their followers.

ef038a5f-cf3b-459c-ae9f-0cb2932d000d.name: Influencer and Gatekeeper Identification
ef038a5f-cf3b-459c-ae9f-0cb2932d000d.description:
Influencer and Gatekeeper Identification is the process of systematically recognizing and mapping individuals within an organization who possess the power to sway decisions (influencers) or control access to key stakeholders and decision-makers (gatekeepers). In today’s complex business environments, organizations are rarely hierarchical in a straightforward way; instead, decision-making is often distributed across formal and informal networks. This skill is crucial for sales teams, business development professionals, and consultants who must efficiently navigate organizational politics to reach the right people and drive outcomes. Practitioners leverage a combination of research, observation, and interpersonal engagement to discern who holds real influence—whether through formal authority, expertise, or social capital—and who acts as a gatekeeper, managing information flow and access. Mastery of this skill enables professionals to tailor their communication strategies, build targeted relationships, and avoid wasted efforts on less impactful contacts. It also involves understanding organizational charts, informal power structures, and the dynamics of stakeholder alignment. Immediate applications include accelerating sales cycles, improving stakeholder engagement, and increasing the likelihood of successful negotiations or project approvals. In the current business landscape, where remote work and matrixed organizations are common, the ability to quickly and accurately identify influencers and gatekeepers is more important than ever for achieving business objectives.

755a0903-31cb-431a-93a8-810387dab03a.name: Information architecture (IA)
755a0903-31cb-431a-93a8-810387dab03a.description: Information architecture (IA) focuses on organizing, structuring, and labeling content in an effective and sustainable way. The goal is to help users find information and complete tasks.

ed20fbd1-dcf7-4bca-a103-fc39acb0585f.name: Information graphics (Infographic)
ed20fbd1-dcf7-4bca-a103-fc39acb0585f.description:
Infographics (a clipped compound of "information" and "graphics") are graphic visual representations of information, data, or knowledge intended to present information quickly and clearly. They can improve cognition by using graphics to enhance the human visual system's ability to see patterns and trends. Similar pursuits are information visualization, data visualization, statistical graphics, information design, or information architecture. Infographics have evolved in recent years to be for mass communication, and thus are designed with fewer assumptions about the readers' knowledge base than other types of visualizations. Isotypes are an early example of infographics conveying information quickly and easily to the masses.[6]

Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infographic

55f76657-f3b1-431b-af4f-eed577ce1961.name: Information security
55f76657-f3b1-431b-af4f-eed577ce1961.description: Information security is a set of practices intended to keep data secure from unauthorized access or alterations. Here's a broad look at the policies, principles, and people used to protect data.

1b47d96b-f427-4b51-a1a0-cd3be50e7922.name: Infrastructure Architecture
1b47d96b-f427-4b51-a1a0-cd3be50e7922.description: Infrastructure Architecture is a structured and modern approach for supporting an organization and facilitating innovation within an enterprise. It concerns modeling the hardware elements across an enterprise and the relationship between them.

42dda0c4-b256-4fc4-bd57-cb92e003d8c7.name: Infrastructure as Code (IaC)
42dda0c4-b256-4fc4-bd57-cb92e003d8c7.description: Infrastructure as code (IaC) uses DevOps methodology and versioning with a descriptive model to define and deploy infrastructure, such as networks, virtual machines, load balancers, and connection topologies. Just as the same source code always generates the same binary, an IaC model generates the same environment every time it deploys.

735190d4-058c-4771-b93a-4f1a92729cc5.name: Innovative Storage and Preservation Techniques for Agriculture
735190d4-058c-4771-b93a-4f1a92729cc5.name_en: Innovative Storage and Preservation Techniques for Agriculture
735190d4-058c-4771-b93a-4f1a92729cc5.description:
Innovative Storage and Preservation Techniques for Agriculture is a critical business skill that focuses on the identification, evaluation, and implementation of advanced methods for storing and preserving agricultural products. This skill is essential in today’s global food supply chain, where minimizing post-harvest losses, reducing food waste, and maintaining product quality directly impact profitability, sustainability, and food security. Practitioners must be knowledgeable about a range of modern technologies such as controlled atmosphere storage, cold chain logistics, vacuum sealing, modified atmosphere packaging, and the use of natural preservatives. They must also understand regulatory requirements, food safety standards, and the economic implications of adopting new storage solutions. In the business context, this skill enables organizations to extend shelf life, access new markets, and respond to consumer demand for fresher, safer, and higher-quality products. It also supports resilience against supply chain disruptions and climate-related risks by ensuring that agricultural outputs are preserved efficiently from farm to market. Typical use cases include designing cost-effective storage infrastructure, integrating IoT-based monitoring systems for real-time quality control, and developing business models that leverage reduced spoilage for competitive advantage. Mastery of this skill is vital for agribusiness managers, supply chain professionals, and entrepreneurs seeking to enhance operational efficiency and sustainability in the agricultural sector.

262c4695-0309-4ae0-a97e-f5b2db118af0.name: Integration architecture
262c4695-0309-4ae0-a97e-f5b2db118af0.description: Integration architecture is comprised of structures which allow for the interoperability of different IT components. Modern application architecture means that companies use a wide variety of applications that perform tasks and contribute data.

d7222aee-57e4-414f-9d68-22a34a57c7be.name: Intellectual property (IP) law
d7222aee-57e4-414f-9d68-22a34a57c7be.description:
Intellectual property (IP) lawyers protect and enforce the rights and creations of inventors, authors, artists, and businesses. IP law encompasses copyrighting, trademarking, patenting, and protecting trade secrets for tangible products like inventions, and intangible ones like brand names, slogans, or symbols. Lawyers in this field have three main responsibilities: the first is to counsel their clients on the best way to protect their intellectual property; the second is to protect their intellectual property by registering a trademark, copyright, or patent; and the third is to enforce intellectual property rights against infringement.

Both law schools and state bars may offer either specialty programs or certificates to specialize in the field.

a9fc1a71-88a3-425b-b638-5afac5855adf.name: IntelliJ
a9fc1a71-88a3-425b-b638-5afac5855adf.description: IntelliJ IDEA (/ɪnˈtɛlɪdʒeɪ aɪˈdiːə/[2]) is an integrated development environment (IDE) written in Java for developing computer software written in Java, Kotlin, Groovy, and other JVM-based languages. It is developed by JetBrains (formerly known as IntelliJ) and is available as an Apache 2 Licensed community edition,[3] and in a proprietary commercial edition. Both can be used for commercial development

cbd98e45-f86f-49db-925b-95466ca77ed6.name: Intelligent applications
cbd98e45-f86f-49db-925b-95466ca77ed6.description: Intelligent applications use one or more AI techniques to learn from external, alternative data sources.

d8e22417-066a-4a83-94c7-6881b08dea78.name: Internal Controls
d8e22417-066a-4a83-94c7-6881b08dea78.description: Internal control is a process, effected by an entity's board of directors, management and other personnel, designed to provide reasonable assurance: That information is reliable, accurate and timely. Of compliance with applicable laws, regulations, contracts, policies and procedures.

acbab502-ae93-4762-b599-5dad6d502f8c.name: International finance
acbab502-ae93-4762-b599-5dad6d502f8c.description: International finance is the branch of financial economics broadly concerned with monetary and macroeconomic interrelations between two or more countries.

8a07defd-9a49-4a29-954f-0ae0e44aa6fd.name: International relations
8a07defd-9a49-4a29-954f-0ae0e44aa6fd.description: International relations (IR), sometimes referred to as international studies and international affairs, is the scientific study of interactions between sovereign states.[2] In a broader sense, it concerns all activities between states—such as war, diplomacy, trade, and foreign policy—as well as relations with and among other international actors, such as intergovernmental organisations (IGOs), international nongovernmental organisations (INGOs), international legal bodies, and multinational corporations (MNCs)

c9f1c64e-c350-4e50-b10b-d71ced8ff462.name: Internet Protocol Security (IPsec)
c9f1c64e-c350-4e50-b10b-d71ced8ff462.description:
In computing, Internet Protocol Security (IPsec) is a secure network protocol suite that authenticates and encrypts packets of data to provide secure encrypted communication between two computers over an Internet Protocol network. It is used in virtual private networks (VPNs).

IPsec includes protocols for establishing mutual authentication between agents at the beginning of a session and negotiation of cryptographic keys to use during the session. IPsec can protect data flows between a pair of hosts (host-to-host), between a pair of security gateways (network-to-network), or between a security gateway and a host (network-to-host).[1] IPsec uses cryptographic security services to protect communications over Internet Protocol (IP) networks. It supports network-level peer authentication, data origin authentication, data integrity, data confidentiality (encryption), and replay protection (protection from replay attacks).  Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPsec

00c8c330-2c33-4b4b-b7fd-2f02b6324e9e.name: Interoperability of Food Supply Chain Data Platforms
00c8c330-2c33-4b4b-b7fd-2f02b6324e9e.name_en: Interoperability of Food Supply Chain Data Platforms
00c8c330-2c33-4b4b-b7fd-2f02b6324e9e.description:
Interoperability of Food Supply Chain Data Platforms is the technical capability to enable seamless, secure, and accurate data exchange between diverse digital systems used throughout the food supply chain. This skill encompasses the design, implementation, and management of standardized protocols, data formats, and integration frameworks that allow disparate platforms—such as farm management systems, logistics tracking, inventory databases, and retail analytics—to communicate and share information in real time. In today's complex and globalized food industry, interoperability is crucial for enhancing traceability, ensuring food safety, and improving operational efficiency. It allows stakeholders to track products from farm to fork, respond rapidly to recalls or contamination events, and optimize inventory and logistics through data-driven decision-making. Key aspects include understanding and applying data standards (such as GS1, ISO 22005, or blockchain-based traceability), utilizing APIs and middleware for system integration, and ensuring data security and privacy compliance. Typical use cases involve integrating supplier data with retailer platforms, automating compliance reporting, and enabling transparent consumer information. Mastery of this skill requires both technical knowledge of integration technologies and a deep understanding of food supply chain processes, making it immediately relevant for IT professionals, supply chain managers, and food safety specialists working to modernize and secure the food ecosystem.

864ac515-db8d-4323-8f99-ecb086537cf5.name: Interoperable Food Logistics Systems Integration
864ac515-db8d-4323-8f99-ecb086537cf5.description:
Interoperable Food Logistics Systems Integration is the technical skill of designing, implementing, and maintaining seamless data and process connectivity between diverse logistics platforms within the food supply chain. This skill is crucial in today's environment, where food logistics operations often involve multiple stakeholders—such as producers, distributors, retailers, and third-party logistics providers—each using different software systems and data standards. Practitioners must ensure that disparate systems (e.g., warehouse management, transportation management, inventory tracking, and temperature monitoring) can communicate efficiently, securely, and in real time. This involves leveraging industry standards such as EDI (Electronic Data Interchange), APIs, and IoT protocols, as well as understanding data mapping, middleware solutions, and system architecture. The skill is immediately relevant due to the increasing demand for supply chain transparency, regulatory compliance (such as food safety traceability), and the need to optimize logistics efficiency to reduce waste and costs. Typical use cases include integrating cold chain monitoring data with transportation management systems to ensure food safety, synchronizing inventory data across suppliers and retailers, and enabling real-time tracking of shipments. Mastery of this skill enables organizations to respond rapidly to disruptions, improve collaboration, and deliver fresher products to consumers, making it a cornerstone of modern, resilient food logistics operations.

3d4d98f5-7742-417d-8296-97f95f648c8b.name: Intrusion Detection System (IDS)
3d4d98f5-7742-417d-8296-97f95f648c8b.description: An Intrusion Detection System (IDS) is a monitoring system that detects suspicious activities and generates alerts when they are detected. Based upon these alerts, a security operations center (SOC) analyst or incident responder can investigate the issue and take the appropriate actions to remediate the threat.

67f08007-5f7a-40ce-907a-4fcc92379e45.name: Intrusion Detection & Prevention Systems (IDS/IPS)
67f08007-5f7a-40ce-907a-4fcc92379e45.description: Intrusion detection is the process of monitoring your network traffic and analyzing it for signs of possible intrusions, such as exploit attempts and incidents that may be imminent threats to your network. For its part, intrusion prevention is the process of performing intrusion detection and then stopping the detected incidents, typically done by dropping packets or terminating sessions. These security measures are available as intrusion detection systems (IDS) and intrusion prevention systems (IPS).

3ea74a61-94c0-4310-9a6b-8ec4b2d6945b.name: IoT Deployment for Smart Food Logistics
3ea74a61-94c0-4310-9a6b-8ec4b2d6945b.name_en: IoT Deployment for Smart Food Logistics
3ea74a61-94c0-4310-9a6b-8ec4b2d6945b.description:
IoT Deployment for Smart Food Logistics is the technical skill of designing, implementing, and managing Internet of Things (IoT) solutions specifically tailored to the food logistics sector. This skill encompasses the integration of sensor networks, real-time data acquisition, wireless communication protocols, and cloud-based analytics to enable end-to-end visibility and automation throughout the food supply chain. Practitioners must understand how to select and configure IoT devices such as temperature, humidity, and location sensors to monitor perishable goods during storage and transportation. The skill also involves setting up secure data transmission, integrating IoT platforms with logistics management systems, and ensuring compliance with food safety regulations. Immediate applications include real-time tracking of shipments, automated alerts for temperature excursions, predictive maintenance of refrigeration units, and digital traceability for food provenance. This skill is currently critical for reducing spoilage, improving operational efficiency, and meeting regulatory demands for transparency and traceability in food logistics. It requires a strong grasp of network architecture, device interoperability, data security, and the unique challenges of food logistics environments. Mastery of this skill enables organizations to leverage IoT technologies for smarter, safer, and more efficient food supply chains, delivering tangible value in today's highly competitive and regulated marketplace.

d6231780-48da-4090-a8e5-81653ca8867d.name: IoT-Enabled Temperature Control in Food Logistics
d6231780-48da-4090-a8e5-81653ca8867d.name_en: IoT-Enabled Temperature Control in Food Logistics
d6231780-48da-4090-a8e5-81653ca8867d.description:
IoT-Enabled Temperature Control in Food Logistics is a technical skill focused on the deployment, integration, and management of Internet of Things (IoT) technologies to monitor and regulate temperature conditions throughout the food supply chain. This skill is currently of critical importance due to stringent food safety regulations, the increasing complexity of global food distribution networks, and the need to minimize spoilage and waste of temperature-sensitive products such as dairy, meat, seafood, and pharmaceuticals. Practitioners must understand how to implement sensor networks that provide real-time temperature data from storage facilities, transport vehicles, and distribution centers. The skill encompasses configuring IoT devices, establishing secure data transmission protocols, and integrating sensor data with centralized monitoring platforms or cloud-based analytics systems. It also involves setting up automated alerts and control mechanisms to maintain optimal temperature ranges, ensuring compliance with standards such as HACCP and FSMA. Immediate applications include cold chain management, rapid response to temperature excursions, and data-driven optimization of logistics operations. Mastery of this skill enables organizations to enhance product quality, reduce liability, and improve operational transparency. It requires familiarity with IoT hardware, wireless communication protocols (e.g., LoRaWAN, Zigbee), data analytics, and the unique challenges of food logistics environments, such as variable power sources and harsh conditions.

d9a85e03-ade7-4865-ae0f-fabf1f1fe50e.name: J2EE
d9a85e03-ade7-4865-ae0f-fabf1f1fe50e.description: J2EE stands for Java 2 Platform, Enterprise Edition. J2EE is the standard platform for developing applications in the enterprise and is designed for enterprise applications that run on servers. J2EE provides APIs that let developers create workflows and make use of resources such as databases or web services.

3e307f23-ab69-464f-a52e-06c557ae08e8.name: JBoss application serve
3e307f23-ab69-464f-a52e-06c557ae08e8.description: JBoss application server is an open-source platform, developed by Red Hat, used for implementing Java applications and a wide variety of other software applications. You can build and deploy Java services to be scaled to fit the size of your business. When you integrate a JBoss application server with WildFly 10 you can unlock several cool features, like messaging, high-availability clustering, and distributed caching.

9773456b-2b3e-40b5-8f94-f6569d1fe4da.name: JSON
9773456b-2b3e-40b5-8f94-f6569d1fe4da.description: JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) is a standard text-based format for representing structured data based on JavaScript object syntax. It is commonly used for transmitting data in web applications (e.g., sending some data from the server to the client, so it can be displayed on a web page, or vice versa)

eb18aea8-6707-4a5e-90af-4e74af8bdc87.name: JSONPath
eb18aea8-6707-4a5e-90af-4e74af8bdc87.description: JSONPath is a query language for JSON, similar to XPath for XML. It allows you to select and extract data from a JSON document. You use a JSONPath expression to traverse the path to an element in the JSON structure.

6a01528e-6db3-4b96-b367-72b220fef487.name: JUnit
6a01528e-6db3-4b96-b367-72b220fef487.description: JUnit is a unit testing open-source framework for the Java programming language. Java Developers use this framework to write and execute automated tests. In Java, there are test cases that have to be re-executed every time a new code is added.

07e13092-95ac-4c17-91bb-63e7c7308373.name: JVM
07e13092-95ac-4c17-91bb-63e7c7308373.description: Java Virtual Machine (JVM) is a engine that provides runtime environment to drive the Java Code or applications. It converts Java bytecode into machines language. JVM is a part of Java Runtime Environment (JRE). In other programming languages, the compiler produces machine code for a particular system. However, Java compiler produces code for a Virtual Machine known as Java Virtual Machine.

b6c69089-bb48-48e7-b87b-237bd74788ef.name: Jakarta Faces, formerly Jakarta Server Faces and JavaServer Faces (JSF)
b6c69089-bb48-48e7-b87b-237bd74788ef.description:
Jakarta Faces, formerly Jakarta Server Faces and JavaServer Faces (JSF) is a Java specification for building component-based user interfaces for web applications.[2] It was formalized as a standard through the Java Community Process as part of the Java Platform, Enterprise Edition. It is an MVC web framework that simplifies the construction of user interfaces (UI) for server-based applications by using reusable UI components in a page.[3]

JSF 2.x uses Facelets as its default templating system. Users of the software may also use XUL or Java.[4] JSF 1.x uses JavaServer Pages (JSP) as its default templating system.  Ref:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakarta_Faces
b6c69089-bb48-48e7-b87b-237bd74788ef.description_en: Jakarta Faces, formerly Jakarta Server Faces and JavaServer Faces (JSF)

d9edb24d-52c2-4d4a-a978-7a1023e32f52.name: Jakarta Servlet, formerly Java Servlet
d9edb24d-52c2-4d4a-a978-7a1023e32f52.description: A Jakarta Servlet, formerly Java Servlet is a Java software component that extends the capabilities of a server. Although servlets can respond to many types of requests, they most commonly implement web containers for hosting web applications on web servers and thus qualify as a server-side servlet web API. Such web servlets are the Java counterpart to other dynamic web content technologies such as PHP and ASP.NET.  Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakarta_Servlet

77ff4575-ec3c-4947-ba0c-ae786b249e08.name: Java EE
77ff4575-ec3c-4947-ba0c-ae786b249e08.description: The Java Platform, Enterprise Edition (Java EE) is a collection of Java APIs owned by Oracle that software developers can use to write server-side applications. It was formerly known as Java 2 Platform, Enterprise Edition, or J2EE.

2f2e4ba0-ab04-4c4e-98bc-6ec3968ef61b.name: Java Message Service (JMS)
2f2e4ba0-ab04-4c4e-98bc-6ec3968ef61b.description: The Java Message Service (JMS) was designed to make it easy to develop business applications that asynchronously send and receive business data and events. It defines a common enterprise messaging API that is designed to be easily and efficiently supported by a wide range of enterprise messaging products.

222c2ad5-2849-4f6c-ae0b-4ddc1461db27.name: Java Server Faces (JSF)
222c2ad5-2849-4f6c-ae0b-4ddc1461db27.description: Designed to be flexible, JavaServer Faces technology leverages existing, standard UI and web-tier concepts without limiting developers to a particular mark-up language, protocol, or client device.

df5cbf46-9389-493d-af72-79c2477953b1.name: Java development
df5cbf46-9389-493d-af72-79c2477953b1.description: Java is an object-oriented programming language that produces software for multiple platforms. When a programmer writes a Java application, the compiled code (known as bytecode) runs on most operating systems (OS), including Windows, Linux and Mac OS. Java derives much of its syntax from the C and C++ programming languages.

5bd21d2b-8699-4aca-bdb0-3dc443211cee.name: JavaScript
5bd21d2b-8699-4aca-bdb0-3dc443211cee.description: JavaScript is a text-based programming language used both on the client-side and server-side that allows you to make web pages interactive. Where HTML and CSS are languages that give structure and style to web pages, JavaScript gives web pages interactive elements that engage a user.

d2726f43-16a1-42c4-8623-8d4d56ca085e.name: JavaServer Pages (JSP)
d2726f43-16a1-42c4-8623-8d4d56ca085e.description: JavaServer Pages (JSP) is a Java standard technology that enables you to write dynamic, data-driven pages for your Java web applications. JSP is built on top of the Java Servlet specification. The two technologies typically work together, especially in older Java web applications.

cd0e6dd6-0ee7-4807-a1e3-80d2ab2d28df.name: Jenkins
cd0e6dd6-0ee7-4807-a1e3-80d2ab2d28df.description: Jenkins is a platform for creating a Continuous Integration/Continuous Delivery (CI/CD) environment. The system offers many different tools, languages, and automation tasks to aid in pipeline creation when developing and deploying programs.

dd50c56f-7e8f-4f4f-8f82-a3bad14952cd.name: Jest
dd50c56f-7e8f-4f4f-8f82-a3bad14952cd.description: Jest is a delightful JavaScript Testing Framework with a focus on simplicity. It works with projects using: Babel, TypeScript, Node, React, Angular, Vue and more!

6b594d0a-ffab-4461-b9fd-b3a71df328f9.name: JetBrains
6b594d0a-ffab-4461-b9fd-b3a71df328f9.description: JetBrains open-sourced the core functionality of IntelliJ IDEA by offering the free Community Edition.

072e1adb-09c9-4ff4-b608-c21bdefe9f66.name: Jetbrains All Products Pack
072e1adb-09c9-4ff4-b608-c21bdefe9f66.description: The "All Products Pack" is a subscription-based offering that provides access to all JetBrains desktop tools, including 10 IDEs, 3 extensions, and 2 profilers. 10 IDEs. IntelliJ IDEA for Java, Kotlin, Groovy. Rider for .NET, C#, ASP.NET.

c973811b-d1a4-4714-889d-8c2b4312bc16.name: Jini
c973811b-d1a4-4714-889d-8c2b4312bc16.description: Jini is a service-oriented architecture that defines a programming model that both exploits and extends Java technology. This programming model enables the construction of secure, distributed systems consisting of federations of well-behaved network services.

99609000-a3e4-41ce-a15e-8dbec667b9a0.name: Jira
99609000-a3e4-41ce-a15e-8dbec667b9a0.description: Jira is an application lifecycle management (ALM) and Agile project management tool from Atlassian. It is used for bug tracking, issue tracking, test management and project management. Jira is one of the company's main offerings along with Confluence, the company's team collaboration platform.

48be88a9-f491-4190-bf19-7bd4140a01a5.name: Job advertisement
48be88a9-f491-4190-bf19-7bd4140a01a5.description: Job advertisement is an announcement that informs people that a certain job position is available. It is written in an engaging tone and it contains information not only about the job position, but also about your company and the benefits you offer.

a0e19918-e98b-4877-b45b-c303657b4614.name: Job analysis
a0e19918-e98b-4877-b45b-c303657b4614.description:
Job analysis refers to a systematic process of collecting all information about a specific job, including skill requirements, roles, responsibilities and processes in order to create a valid job description. Job analysis also gives an overview of the physical, emotional & related human qualities required to execute the job successfully.

Job analysis is an important step in ensuring that the right candidate is selected. Job analysis helps the employer in recruitment and selection, performance management, choosing compensation and benefits, etc. It helps the employees to have a clear picture of what is actually required of them

51afabfe-6ba2-4f7e-884d-ed8da060c14b.name: Joy of Creation
51afabfe-6ba2-4f7e-884d-ed8da060c14b.description: Joy of Creation is the ability to find deep satisfaction, enthusiasm, and fulfillment in the process of bringing new ideas, objects, or experiences into existence. This skill involves a strong appreciation for creativity, an intrinsic motivation to explore and experiment, and a positive engagement with the challenges and rewards of creating something original. Individuals with a high "Joy of Creation" can harness their imagination, maintain focus, and sustain energy throughout creative projects, resulting in both personal satisfaction and, often, inspiring outcomes for others.

7418902f-c506-4086-9e54-4a142c006d73.name: Jupyter Notebook ML
7418902f-c506-4086-9e54-4a142c006d73.description: The Jupyter Notebook is an open-source web platform that allows developers to create and share documents that consist of narrative text, live code, visualizations, and equations.

a4c1b924-96d3-4741-a2a9-49058bdac9cd.name: Kali Linux
a4c1b924-96d3-4741-a2a9-49058bdac9cd.description: Kali Linux is a Debian-based Linux distribution specifically designed for digital forensics and penetration testing. It comes pre-loaded with many tools and programs, making it an indispensable resource for cybersecurity professionals, ethical hackers, and enthusiasts.

e044f24b-d0a6-477b-858d-1fecce4bfa4c.name: Kanban
e044f24b-d0a6-477b-858d-1fecce4bfa4c.description: Kanban (Japanese for sign) is an inventory control system used in just-in-time (JIT) manufacturing to track production and order new shipments of parts and materials. Kanban was developed by Taiichi Ohno, an industrial engineer at Toyota, and uses visual cues to prompt the action needed to keep a process flowing.

74424823-5e5f-4c1b-a18f-c4c6d5d07725.name: Keras
74424823-5e5f-4c1b-a18f-c4c6d5d07725.description: Keras is an open-source machine learning library that offers a user-friendly Python interface for building artificial neural networks. With Keras, developers can easily construct, train, and deploy their own deep learning models.

a302aa68-235e-4738-a491-a1b2f43468ab.name: Key Account Retention Strategies
a302aa68-235e-4738-a491-a1b2f43468ab.description:
Key Account Retention Strategies refer to the systematic approaches, methodologies, and best practices employed by organizations to maintain and nurture relationships with their most valuable enterprise clients. In the current business landscape, where customer acquisition costs are rising and competition is intense, retaining high-value accounts is critical for sustaining long-term revenue and profitability. This skill involves understanding the unique needs, business objectives, and pain points of key accounts, and proactively delivering tailored solutions, value-added services, and exceptional customer experiences to ensure satisfaction and loyalty. Practitioners of this skill leverage data-driven insights, regular business reviews, and strategic engagement plans to identify potential risks of churn and address them before they escalate. They also coordinate cross-functional teams to resolve issues quickly, advocate for the client within their organization, and continuously demonstrate the ROI of the partnership. Effective key account retention strategies often include personalized communication, executive sponsorship, co-innovation initiatives, and the development of joint success metrics. This skill is immediately relevant today as organizations face economic uncertainty, shifting client expectations, and the need to maximize customer lifetime value. Use cases include SaaS vendors managing enterprise contracts, B2B service providers maintaining multi-year agreements, and manufacturers supporting strategic distribution partners. Mastery of key account retention strategies directly impacts renewal rates, upsell opportunities, and overall business growth.
