98c5cc78-5836-40c7-bd52-a8aae5aee8c3.name: Key management
98c5cc78-5836-40c7-bd52-a8aae5aee8c3.description: Key management is the management of cryptographic keys in a cryptosystem. In order to achieve security in a system, cryptographic algorithms are used to generate keys which are later encrypted and decrypted to provide the requested information in a secure way.

b33c9b3f-baf2-464a-b0ab-1db0f438bf96.name: Keycloak
b33c9b3f-baf2-464a-b0ab-1db0f438bf96.description: Keycloak is an open-source software product to allow single sign-on with identity and access management aimed at modern applications and services.

586dfa7a-4a87-4e4f-ac8f-46806a2e2d17.name: Kibana
586dfa7a-4a87-4e4f-ac8f-46806a2e2d17.description:
Kibana is an open-source data visualization and exploration tool designed to work with Elasticsearch, forming a crucial part of the Elastic Stack (formerly known as the ELK Stack, which includes Elasticsearch, Logstash, and Kibana). Proficiency in Kibana involves the ability to transform large volumes of complex data into interactive visualizations and dashboards. This skill enables users to perform real-time analytics, monitor applications, and gain operational insights by presenting data in a comprehensible and actionable format.

A key aspect of working with Kibana is understanding how to effectively query and analyze data stored in Elasticsearch. This includes crafting searches, utilizing filters, and employing Kibana's Query Language (KQL) to retrieve and manipulate relevant datasets. Users skilled in Kibana can create a variety of visualizations—such as line graphs, bar charts, pie charts, heat maps, and geo-maps—that help in identifying patterns, trends, and anomalies within the data.

Additionally, expertise in Kibana encompasses the ability to design and manage comprehensive dashboards. This involves aggregating multiple visualizations to provide an overarching view of system metrics, logs, or other critical data points. Skilled users can customize dashboards for different stakeholders, set up real-time data feeds, and implement interactive features like drill-downs and time filters to enhance data exploration and analysis.

Advanced Kibana skills may also include leveraging features like Machine Learning for anomaly detection and predictive analytics, using Canvas for creating dynamic, infographic-style presentations, and utilizing Timelion for complex time-series data analysis. Knowledge of security features—such as role-based access control and encrypted communications—is essential for managing Kibana in enterprise environments. Mastery of Kibana empowers individuals and organizations to harness their data effectively, facilitating informed decision-making and optimizing operational performance.

1a1068d5-7e57-4a2c-9e8b-a75df63baafc.name: Knowledge graphs (KGs)
1a1068d5-7e57-4a2c-9e8b-a75df63baafc.description: Knowledge graphs (KGs) are machine-readable data structures that describe the relationship between heterogeneous data via a network of nodes and links.

0ba43f44-ecb4-4963-827f-93db5bd94214.name: Knowledge management
0ba43f44-ecb4-4963-827f-93db5bd94214.description: Knowledge management (KM) is the process of organizing, creating, using, and sharing collective knowledge within an organization. Successful knowledge management includes maintaining information in a place where it is easy to access, like a wiki or employee intranet.

9a1608f9-0488-4477-8ded-cf7b7ed8b9bb.name: LLM
9a1608f9-0488-4477-8ded-cf7b7ed8b9bb.description: A large language model (LLM) is a type of language model notable for its ability to achieve general-purpose language understanding and generation. LLMs acquire these abilities by using massive amounts of data to learn billions of parameters during training and consuming large computational resources during their training and operation.[1] LLMs are artificial neural networks (mainly Transformers [2]) and are (pre-)trained using self-supervised learning and semi-supervised learning.

57964a33-af39-45c5-81df-c626e5ab6e73.name: Langchain4j
57964a33-af39-45c5-81df-c626e5ab6e73.description:
The goal of LangChain4j is to simplify integrating AI/LLM capabilities into Java applications.

Here's how:

Unified APIs: LLM providers (like OpenAI or Google Vertex AI) and embedding (vector) stores (such as Pinecone or Vespa) use proprietary APIs. LangChain4j offers a unified API to avoid the need for learning and implementing specific APIs for each of them. To experiment with a different LLM or embedding store, you can easily switch between them without the need to rewrite your code. LangChain4j currently supports over 10 popular LLM providers and more than 15 embedding stores. Think of it as a Hibernate, but for LLMs and embedding stores.
Comprehensive Toolbox: During the past year, the community has been building numerous LLM-powered applications, identifying common patterns, abstractions, and techniques. LangChain4j has refined these into practical code. Our toolbox includes tools ranging from low-level prompt templating, memory management, and output parsing to high-level patterns like Agents and RAGs. For each pattern and abstraction, we provide an interface along with multiple ready-to-use implementations based on proven techniques. Whether you're building a chatbot or developing a RAG with a complete pipeline from data ingestion to retrieval, LangChain4j offers a wide variety of options.
Numerous Examples: These examples showcase how to begin creating various LLM-powered applications, providing inspiration and enabling you to start building quickly.
LangChain4j began development in early 2023 amid the ChatGPT hype. We noticed a lack of Java counterparts to the numerous Python and JavaScript LLM libraries and frameworks, and we had to fix that! Although "LangChain" is in our name, the project is a fusion of ideas and concepts from LangChain, Haystack, LlamaIndex, and the broader community, spiced up with a touch of our own innovation.

We actively monitor community developments, aiming to quickly incorporate new techniques and integrations, ensuring you stay up-to-date. The library is under active development. While some features from the Python version of LangChain are still being worked on, the core functionality is in place, allowing you to start building LLM-powered apps now!

Ref: https://github.com/langchain4j/langchain4j

935459fa-4903-46df-84e3-1d10209393e7.name: Language server protocol (LSP)
935459fa-4903-46df-84e3-1d10209393e7.description: The language server protocol (LSP) is the product of standardizing the messages exchanged between a development tool and a language server process. Using language servers or demons is not a new or novel idea

20ec7040-045c-4794-8c00-90879fe082e4.name: Language-Integrated Query (LINQ)
20ec7040-045c-4794-8c00-90879fe082e4.description: Language-Integrated Query (LINQ) is the name for a set of technologies based on the integration of query capabilities directly into the C# language. Traditionally, queries against data are expressed as simple strings without type checking at compile time or IntelliSense support. Furthermore, you have to learn a different query language for each type of data source: SQL databases, XML documents, various Web services, and so on. With LINQ, a query is a first-class language construct, just like classes, methods, and events.

dca5011c-2a38-4f63-8c94-aa6079542963.name: Laravel
dca5011c-2a38-4f63-8c94-aa6079542963.description: Laravel is a PHP web application framework with expressive, elegant syntax. We’ve already laid the foundation — freeing you to create without sweating the small things.

9d09d559-ed1f-4be3-b065-b4f4eba2fd3f.name: Last-Mile Delivery Optimization for Fresh Produce
9d09d559-ed1f-4be3-b065-b4f4eba2fd3f.name_en: Last-Mile Delivery Optimization for Fresh Produce
9d09d559-ed1f-4be3-b065-b4f4eba2fd3f.description:
Last-Mile Delivery Optimization for Fresh Produce is a critical business skill focused on enhancing the efficiency, reliability, and cost-effectiveness of delivering perishable goods from distribution centers or retail hubs to end consumers or retail outlets. This skill is especially vital in today's fast-paced, consumer-driven market, where demand for fresh, high-quality produce is high and customer expectations for rapid delivery are increasing. The skill encompasses the application of advanced logistics strategies, real-time data analytics, route planning, and temperature-controlled transportation to minimize delivery times, reduce spoilage, and ensure product freshness upon arrival. Practitioners must balance operational costs with service quality, leveraging technologies such as GPS tracking, IoT-enabled sensors for temperature and humidity monitoring, and dynamic scheduling systems to respond to traffic, weather, and demand fluctuations. Key use cases include grocery delivery services, farm-to-table supply chains, and urban food distribution networks, where even minor delays or mishandling can lead to significant financial losses and reputational damage. Mastery of this skill directly impacts customer satisfaction, waste reduction, and profitability, making it a top priority for businesses in the fresh produce sector. It also requires close coordination with suppliers, logistics partners, and customer service teams to ensure seamless, transparent, and accountable delivery processes.

Skill Areas: Organizational, Technical, Process

6fead5a2-8322-428b-81ed-d274e793ea93.name: Leadership in Sustainable Food Systems
6fead5a2-8322-428b-81ed-d274e793ea93.description:
Leadership in Sustainable Food Systems is the capacity to guide, influence, and drive organizations or initiatives toward the adoption and integration of sustainable practices within the food sector. This skill is critically important in today’s context, where food systems face mounting pressures from climate change, resource scarcity, shifting consumer expectations, and evolving regulatory frameworks. Effective leaders in this domain possess a deep understanding of sustainability principles—such as environmental stewardship, social responsibility, and economic viability—and are adept at translating these into actionable strategies that align with organizational goals and stakeholder values. They must navigate complex supply chains, foster cross-sector collaboration, and champion innovation in areas like regenerative agriculture, waste reduction, and ethical sourcing. The skill also involves engaging diverse stakeholders, including producers, consumers, regulators, and investors, to build consensus and drive collective action. Leaders must stay abreast of current regulations, certifications (e.g., organic, fair trade), and reporting standards, ensuring compliance while also anticipating future trends. Typical use cases include leading sustainability transformation projects, developing responsible sourcing policies, implementing circular economy initiatives, and communicating sustainability progress to internal and external audiences. Ultimately, this skill is vital for organizations seeking to remain competitive, resilient, and socially responsible in the rapidly evolving landscape of global food systems.

6fead5a2-8322-428b-81ed-d274e793ea93.description_en: Leadership in Sustainable Food Systems is the capacity to guide, influence, and drive organizations or initiatives toward the adoption and integration of sustainable practices within the food sector. This skill is critically important in today’s context, where food systems face mounting pressures from climate change, resource scarcity, shifting consumer expectations, and evolving regulatory frameworks. Effective leaders in this domain possess a deep understanding of sustainability principles—such as environmental stewardship, social responsibility, and economic viability—and are adept at translating these into actionable strategies that align with organizational goals and stakeholder values. They must navigate complex supply chains, foster cross-sector collaboration, and champion innovation in areas like regenerative agriculture, waste reduction, and ethical sourcing. The skill also involves engaging diverse stakeholders, including producers, consumers, regulators, and investors, to build consensus and drive collective action. Leaders must stay abreast of current regulations, certifications (e.g., organic, fair trade), and reporting standards, ensuring compliance while also anticipating future trends. Typical use cases include leading sustainability transformation projects, developing responsible sourcing policies, implementing circular economy initiatives, and communicating sustainability progress to internal and external audiences. Ultimately, this skill is vital for organizations seeking to remain competitive, resilient, and socially responsible in the rapidly evolving landscape of global food systems.

4ceb0289-2a40-4ef5-9b68-7a62f2e2df63.name: Lisp
4ceb0289-2a40-4ef5-9b68-7a62f2e2df63.description: Lisp (historically LISP, an abbreviation of "list processing") is a family of programming languages with a long history and a distinctive, fully parenthesized prefix notation. 6891b4b5-0dcc-46e6-89e2-e8b996153e53.name: Load Testing
6891b4b5-0dcc-46e6-89e2-e8b996153e53.description:
Software Load Testing

Software load testing is a specialized skill focused on evaluating how software applications perform under expected and peak user load conditions. It involves a comprehensive process of designing, executing, and analyzing tests that simulate real-world user interactions to ensure that the application remains reliable, responsive, and scalable when subjected to varying levels of demand.

Key aspects of software load testing include:

Test Planning and Design: Crafting detailed test plans that outline objectives, scope, and methodologies. This involves defining realistic user scenarios, determining load patterns, and setting performance benchmarks and key performance indicators (KPIs) such as response time, throughput, and error rates.

Tool Proficiency: Expertise in utilizing load testing tools and frameworks like Apache JMeter, LoadRunner, Gatling, or BlazeMeter. This includes scripting complex user behaviors, configuring test environments, and automating test executions to replicate multiple concurrent users.

Simulation of Real-World Load: Creating test scenarios that accurately mimic the behavior of actual users, including login processes, data entry, transactions, and other interactive functions. This ensures that the test results are representative of real operational conditions.

Performance Monitoring: Continuously monitoring system resources during tests, such as CPU usage, memory consumption, network bandwidth, and database performance. This helps in identifying how different components of the application and infrastructure respond under load.

Data Analysis and Bottleneck Identification: Analyzing test results to detect performance issues like slow response times, high error rates, or system crashes. This involves interpreting logs, error messages, and performance metrics to pinpoint the root causes of bottlenecks.

Scalability Assessment: Evaluating the application's ability to scale up or down based on user demand. This includes testing the application's performance when additional resources are added or when the load is reduced.

Reporting and Communication: Preparing comprehensive reports that detail the testing process, findings, and recommendations. Effective communication with stakeholders, including developers, project managers, and clients, is essential to address performance issues and plan improvements.

Optimization Recommendations: Providing actionable insights for enhancing application performance. This may involve suggesting code optimizations, architectural changes, hardware upgrades, or configuration adjustments to improve scalability and reliability.

Knowledge of System Architecture: Understanding the underlying architecture of the software, including servers, databases, APIs, and third-party integrations. This knowledge is crucial for designing effective tests and interpreting results accurately.

Compliance and Best Practices: Ensuring that load testing practices adhere to industry standards, regulatory requirements, and organizational policies. Staying updated with the latest best practices and technologies in performance testing.

Continuous Integration and Deployment (CI/CD) Integration: Incorporating load testing into the CI/CD pipeline to enable continuous performance assessment throughout the development lifecycle. This helps in early detection of performance issues and reduces the risk of late-stage failures.

Adaptability and Problem-Solving: Being able to adjust testing strategies based on evolving requirements, technological changes, or unexpected test outcomes. Strong analytical and problem-solving skills are essential to address complex performance challenges.

By mastering software load testing, professionals ensure that applications can handle real-world demands efficiently, providing a seamless and satisfactory experience to end-users even under heavy load conditions. This skill is vital for maintaining the reputation of software products and services, reducing downtime, and preventing revenue loss due to performance-related issues.

e24d168d-66ab-4662-83b0-68d4b533ac43.name: Logistics
e24d168d-66ab-4662-83b0-68d4b533ac43.description:
Logistics is the part of supply chain management that deals with the efficient forward and reverse flow of goods, services, and related information from the point of origin to the point of consumption according to the needs of customers. Logistics management is a component that holds the supply chain together. The resources managed in logistics may include tangible goods such as materials, equipment, and supplies, as well as food and other consumable items.

In military logistics, it is concerned with maintaining army supply lines with food, armaments, ammunition, and spare parts apart from the transportation of troops themselves. Meanwhile, civil logistics deals with acquiring, moving, and storing raw materials, semi-finished goods, and finished goods. For organisations that provide garbage collection, mail deliveries, public utilities, and after-sales services, logistical problems must be addressed.

Logistics deals with the movements of materials or products from one facility to another; it does not include material flow within the production or assembly plants, such as production planning or single-machine scheduling.[2] Logistics occupies a significant amount of the operational cost of an organisation or country. Logistical costs of organizations in the United States incurred about 11% of United States national gross domestic product (GDP) as of 1997. In the European Union, logistics costs were 8.8% to 11.5% of GDP as of 1993.

Dedicated simulation software can model, analyze, visualize, and optimize logistics' complexity. Minimizing resource use is a common motivation in all logistics fields. A professional working in logistics management is called a logistician.  Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistics

4bebdb50-002a-45bd-acb0-8f79494d7ad7.name: Looker
4bebdb50-002a-45bd-acb0-8f79494d7ad7.description: Looker is a business intelligence platform. It provides a data exploration and dashboarding interface for users, an IDE for data modelers, and rich embedding and API features for developers.

bdce758d-a889-483b-a13b-5c4b4817921a.name: Low-code development platform
bdce758d-a889-483b-a13b-5c4b4817921a.description:
A low-code development platform (LCDP) provides a development environment used to create application software, generally through a graphical user interface (as opposed to only writing code, though some coding is possible and may be required). A low-coded platform may produce entirely operational applications, or require additional coding for specific situations. Low-code development platforms are typically on a high abstraction level, and can reduce the amount of traditional time spent, enabling accelerated delivery of business applications. A common benefit is that a wider range of people can contribute to the application's development, not only those with coding skills, but good governance is needed to be able to adhere to common rules and regulations. LCDPs can also lower the initial cost of setup, training, deployment, and maintenance.

Low-code development platforms trace their roots back to fourth-generation programming language and the rapid application development tools of the 1990s and early 2000s. Similar to these predecessor development environments, LCDPs are based on the principles of model-driven architecture, automatic code generation, and visual programming. The concept of end-user development also existed previously, although LCDPs brought some new ways of approaching this development. The low-code development platform market traces its origins back to 2011. The specific name "low-code" was not put forward until 9 June, 2014, when it was used by the industry analyst Forrester Research. Along with no-code development platforms, low-code was described as "extraordinarily disruptive" in Forbes magazine in 2017.    Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low-code_development_platform

05f5611d-f391-4b4d-87b5-24b608e52640.name: Low-code
05f5611d-f391-4b4d-87b5-24b608e52640.description: Low-code is an application development method that elevates coding from textual to visual. Rather than a technical coding environment, low-code operates in a model-driven, drag-and-drop interface.

6eb1db68-cb02-4cd4-b951-b2fd06a3f67c.description: MATLAB is short for “matrix laboratory.” It is a high-level programming language and platform that works with matrices and arrays rather than individual numbers. 75bcbb56-98df-4de3-90ed-c2a2592211fa.name: MCP Model Context Protocol
75bcbb56-98df-4de3-90ed-c2a2592211fa.description:
MCP (Model Context Protocol) is a sophisticated communication framework designed to standardize and optimize the interaction between AI models and context providers. This protocol addresses the fundamental challenge of efficiently supplying AI systems with rich, structured contextual information needed for more accurate, relevant, and personalized responses.
Core Principles
The Model Context Protocol is built on several key principles:
Bidirectional Communication: Unlike traditional one-way input systems, MCP establishes a two-way communication channel between AI models and context providers, allowing for dynamic context discovery and refinement during processing.
Context Separation: MCP clearly separates context information from user queries, enabling more precise context management and preventing context collapse in complex applications.
Structured Metadata: The protocol enforces a consistent schema for metadata that describes the nature, source, reliability, and temporal aspects of contextual information.
Progressive Enhancement: Context can be delivered in layers of increasing specificity, allowing models to request additional details only when needed.
Transactional Context: MCP supports context sessions that persist across multiple interactions, maintaining state while allowing for explicit context switching.

Practical Applications
MCP is particularly valuable in these scenarios:
Enterprise AI Systems: Where models need access to organizational knowledge, permissions, and business logic.
Multi-Modal AI: Systems processing various input types (text, images, voice) that require unified context management.
Autonomous Systems: Robots or vehicles that must maintain situational awareness across various sensors and information sources.
Personal AI Assistants: Applications that personalize responses based on user profiles, preferences, and interaction history.
Development Environments: IDEs and coding assistants that need to understand project structure, coding standards, and build environments.

0325531d-ff07-4448-b487-dda7a1cf78c2.name: MEVN Stack
0325531d-ff07-4448-b487-dda7a1cf78c2.description: MEVN Stack is a JavaScript technology stack that contains four separate programs for building website and mobile applications. The MEVN Stack comprises MongoDB, Express. js, VueJS, and Node. js.

840d4196-7016-420a-aa19-678574c68cae.name: MQTT
840d4196-7016-420a-aa19-678574c68cae.description: MQTT (originally an initialism of MQ Telemetry Transport[a]) is a lightweight, publish-subscribe, machine to machine network protocol for message queue/message queuing service. It is designed for connections with remote locations that have devices with resource constraints or limited network bandwidth, such as in the Internet of Things (IoT). It must run over a transport protocol that provides ordered, lossless, bi-directional connections—typically, TCP/IP, but also possibly over QUIC.[4] It is an open OASIS standard and an ISO recommendation (ISO/IEC 20922).  Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MQTT

3af9abb0-167e-492d-a5ac-8b27adeccd71.name: MS Azure Cloud Architecture
3af9abb0-167e-492d-a5ac-8b27adeccd71.description: Azure Architecture is a new way of building cloud apps and services. Azure Architecture helps you design the right cloud solution for your business. It does this by having you think about how your solution will operate throughout its lifecycle. This article gives you an overview of what Azure Architecture is, how it differs from classic service-based architecture and how to adopt it in your projects.

c17d3370-68e0-4a7e-bb4e-39255219e040.name: MS Azure Cloud Operation
c17d3370-68e0-4a7e-bb4e-39255219e040.description:
“A cloud operating model is the collection of processes and procedures that define how you want to operate technology in the cloud“.

This definition is under the context that Azure tries to describe the differences between the cloud based operating model and traditional on-prem based operating model. From on-prem to cloud, some key factors have changed (e.g. physical hardware management changed to cloud resource management, CAPEX changed to OPEX, etc), while the other factors remain the same (e.g. business strategy alignment, people, security and compliance, etc). The detail-level information are available at How’s a cloud operating model different?

4eb019bb-9929-45b6-aa03-0a864cf9b289.name: MS Azure Power Platform
4eb019bb-9929-45b6-aa03-0a864cf9b289.description:
The Azure Power Platform offers several key features and benefits, including low-code development, integration with other systems, AI capabilities, real-time data visualization and analysis, and cost-effectiveness. It also integrates with other Microsoft Azure services, such as Azure Functions, Azure Logic Apps, and Azure Event Grid, allowing for more complex workflows and customizations.

1. Introduction

The Azure Power Platform is a suite of tools and services provided by Microsoft that enables businesses to build, deploy, and manage custom applications and workflows without requiring extensive programming knowledge. The platform provides low-code development tools that allow users to create custom solutions quickly and efficiently.

2. What is the Azure Power Platform?

The Azure Power Platform is a collection of three core services: Power BI, Power Apps, and Power Automate.

Power BI: A business intelligence tool that allows users to create interactive reports and dashboards that can be shared with others. It provides real-time data visualization and analysis capabilities that help businesses make informed decisions based on data insights.

Power Apps: A low-code development platform that allows users to create custom business applications quickly and efficiently. It provides pre-built templates and drag-and-drop components that simplify the development process.

Power Automate: A workflow automation tool that allows users to automate repetitive tasks and processes. It provides pre-built connectors to popular services such as SharePoint, OneDrive, and Dynamics 365 and custom connectors that can be built using the Power Platform's API.  Ref: https://www.c-sharpcorner.com/article/an-overview-of-the-azure-power-platform-tools-benefits-and-getting-started/

f8f555ec-6b9d-4d15-abea-da8042d63624.name: Machine Learning for Cybersecurity Operations
f8f555ec-6b9d-4d15-abea-da8042d63624.description:
Machine Learning for Cybersecurity Operations is the application of advanced machine learning (ML) techniques to automate, enhance, and scale the detection, analysis, and mitigation of cybersecurity threats in real time. This skill involves leveraging supervised, unsupervised, and deep learning models to identify patterns, anomalies, and indicators of compromise within vast and complex data streams generated by modern IT environments. Practitioners use ML algorithms to power threat intelligence platforms, intrusion detection systems (IDS), security information and event management (SIEM) solutions, and automated incident response workflows. Key competencies include data preprocessing, feature engineering for security datasets, model selection and evaluation, and the integration of ML pipelines with existing security infrastructure. The skill also requires a strong understanding of adversarial tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), as well as the ability to interpret model outputs for actionable insights. Immediate applications include malware classification, phishing detection, user and entity behavior analytics (UEBA), anomaly detection in network traffic, and automated triage of security alerts. By enabling proactive threat identification and rapid response, this skill is critical for organizations seeking to strengthen their security posture against increasingly sophisticated cyberattacks. Mastery of this skill ensures that security operations teams can keep pace with evolving threats, reduce false positives, and optimize resource allocation in today's dynamic threat landscape.

0aaac3f9-f0e7-4517-954e-c56e96fa4b61.name: Machine Leraning (ML)
0aaac3f9-f0e7-4517-954e-c56e96fa4b61.description:
Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalize to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions. Recently, artificial neural networks have been able to surpass many previous approaches in performance.

Machine learning approaches have been applied to many fields including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine. ML is known in its application across business problems under the name predictive analytics. Although not all machine learning is statistically based, computational statistics is an important source of the field's methods. (From wikipedia)

It can be used for high-availability transaction data, analytics, as an embedded server, and a wide range of tooling and applications support MariaDB Server.

0c418222-7925-40a2-a820-a31a1538d03a.name: Marketing technology Architecture
0c418222-7925-40a2-a820-a31a1538d03a.description:
Marketing technology (MarTech) architecture refers to the design, structure, and integration of technology systems and tools that enable businesses to manage and execute their marketing strategies efficiently. A well-designed MarTech architecture provides a framework for how different marketing technologies interact with each other to support a company's marketing goals.

MarTech architecture is a critical component of any successful marketing strategy. It provides a framework for how different marketing technologies work together to support a company's marketing goals, improve efficiency, and drive ROI. By investing in a well-designed MarTech architecture, businesses can stay agile and responsive to changing market conditions, improve collaboration and communication among stakeholders, and create more targeted and personalized marketing campaigns.

bd25c127-d57d-4454-a358-506b3e1a31b9.name: Marketing
bd25c127-d57d-4454-a358-506b3e1a31b9.description: Marketing is the process of exploring, creating, and delivering value to meet the needs of a target market in terms of goods and services;[1][2] potentially including selection of a target audience; selection of certain attributes or themes to emphasize in advertising; operation of advertising campaigns; attendance at trade shows and public events; design of products and packaging attractive to buyers; defining the terms of sale, such as price, discounts, warranty, and return policy; product placement in media or with people believed to influence the buying habits of others; agreements with retailers, wholesale distributors, or resellers; and attempts to create awareness of, loyalty to, and positive feelings about a brand.

f34f2702-7e0b-4706-9e4f-baba4614f608.name: Media Strategy
f34f2702-7e0b-4706-9e4f-baba4614f608.description: Media strategy, as used in the advertising or content delivery (online broadcasting) industries, is concerned with how messages will be delivered to consumers or niche markets. It involves: identifying the characteristics of the target audience or market, who should receive messages and defining the characteristics of the media that will be used for the delivery of the messages, with the intent being to influence the behavior of the target audience or market pertinent to the initial brief. Examples of such strategies today have revolved around an Integrated Marketing Communications approach whereby multiple channels of media are used i.e. advertising, public relations, events, direct response media, etc.

7a331b46-6a46-4c98-8cdf-638e9a071520.name: Media studies
7a331b46-6a46-4c98-8cdf-638e9a071520.description: Media studies is a discipline and field of study that deals with the content, history, and effects of various media; in particular, the mass media. Media Studies may draw on traditions from both the social sciences and the humanities, but mostly from its core disciplines of mass communication, communication, communication sciences, and communication studies.

4520bd58-35f6-4ad3-bf92-9b6d30b932ab.name: Microsoft Azure
4520bd58-35f6-4ad3-bf92-9b6d30b932ab.description:
Azure is Microsoft's public cloud platform. Azure offers a large collection of services, which includes platform as a service (PaaS), infrastructure as a service (IaaS), and managed database service capabilities. However, what exactly is Azure, and how does it work?

Azure, like other cloud platforms, relies on a technology known as virtualization. Most computer hardware can be emulated in software. Computer hardware is simply a set of instructions, which are permanently, or semi-permanently, encoded in silicon. Emulation layers are used to map software instructions to hardware instructions. Emulation layers allow virtualized hardware to execute in software like the actual hardware itself.

Essentially, the cloud is a set of physical servers in one or more datacenters. The datacenters execute virtualized hardware for customers. So how does the cloud create, start, stop, and delete millions of instances of virtualized hardware for millions of customers simultaneously?

To understand the servers, let's look at the architecture of hardware in the datacenter. Inside each datacenter, there's a collection of servers sitting in server racks. Each server rack contains many server blades, and a network switch. These provide network connectivity and a power distribution unit (PDU), which creates power. Racks are sometimes grouped together in larger units known as clusters.

The server racks, or clusters, are chosen to run virtualized hardware instances for the user. However, some servers run cloud management software, known as a fabric controller. The fabric controller is a distributed application with many responsibilities. It allocates services, monitors the health of the server and the services running on it, and heals servers when they fail.

Each instance of the fabric controller is connected to another set of servers running cloud orchestration software, typically known as the front end. The front end hosts the web services, RESTful APIs, and internal Azure databases, which are used for all functions in the cloud.

For example, the front end hosts the services that handle customer requests. The requests allocate Azure resources and services such as virtual machines, and Azure Cosmos DB. First, the front end validates and verifies if the user is authorized to allocate the requested resources. If so, the front end checks a database to locate a server rack with sufficient capacity, which instructs the fabric controller to allocate the resource.

Azure is a huge collection of servers and networking hardware, which runs a complex set of distributed applications. These applications orchestrate the configuration and operation of virtualized hardware and software on those servers. The orchestration of these servers is what makes Azure so powerful. With Azure, users don't have to maintain and upgrade their hardware as Azure does this behind the scenes.

fbe6cf9d-dbfe-4459-bf80-de896043cfa7.name: Microsoft Defender
fbe6cf9d-dbfe-4459-bf80-de896043cfa7.description:
Microsoft Defender for Cloud plays an important part in your governance strategy. It helps you stay on top of security, because it:

Provides a unified view of security across your workloads
Collects, searches, and analyzes security data from various sources, which includes firewalls and other partner solutions
Provides actionable security recommendations to fix issues before they can be exploited
Applies security policies across your hybrid cloud workloads to ensure compliance with security standards
Many security features, like security policy and recommendations, are available for free. Some of the more advanced features, like just-in-time VM access and hybrid workload support, are available under the Defender for Cloud Standard tier. Just-in-time VM access can help reduce the network attack surface by controlling access to management ports on Azure VMs.

The platform is built on a foundation of Software as a Service (SaaS), which takes simplicity and integration to a whole new level.  Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/get-started/microsoft-fabric-overview

614492bb-10ad-403f-be4d-8f17e2fa96f9.name: Microsoft Project
614492bb-10ad-403f-be4d-8f17e2fa96f9.description:
Microsoft Project is project management software product, developed and sold by Microsoft. It is designed to assist a project manager in developing a schedule, assigning resources to tasks, tracking progress, managing the budget, and analyzing workloads.

Microsoft Project was the company's third Microsoft Windows-based application. Within a few years after its launch, it became the dominant PC-based project management software.[citation needed] From 2015 to 2020 it was the most popular application for project management according to Project Management Zone.[6]

It is part of the Microsoft 365 family but has never been included in any of the suites of Microsoft Office or Microsoft 365. It is available currently as a cloud-based solution with three price levels (Plan 1, Plan 3, or Plan 5): or as a on-premises solution with three editions (Standard, Professional, and Server). Microsoft Project's proprietary file format is .mpp.

Microsoft Project and Microsoft Project Server are the cornerstones of the Microsoft Office enterprise project management (EPM) product. Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Project

049f1b28-4525-4657-8d5b-fe75be3e2681.name: Multi-Stakeholder Sales Communication
049f1b28-4525-4657-8d5b-fe75be3e2681.description:
Multi-Stakeholder Sales Communication is the ability to effectively craft, adapt, and deliver sales messages to diverse groups of stakeholders involved in complex purchasing decisions. In today’s business environment, sales cycles often involve multiple decision-makers, influencers, and gatekeepers, each with distinct priorities, concerns, and levels of authority. This skill requires the communicator to identify and understand the unique perspectives and motivations of each stakeholder group—such as executives, technical evaluators, procurement officers, and end-users—and to tailor messaging accordingly. Practitioners must synthesize business value propositions, technical details, and ROI arguments into coherent narratives that resonate with each audience, while maintaining consistency and alignment with the overall sales strategy. Immediate applications include facilitating consensus in B2B sales, managing cross-functional buying committees, and navigating enterprise procurement processes. The skill is crucial for sales professionals, account managers, and business development leaders who must build trust, address objections, and drive alignment among stakeholders with competing interests. Mastery of Multi-Stakeholder Sales Communication leads to higher win rates, shorter sales cycles, and stronger client relationships by ensuring that all parties feel heard and understood. In the current business landscape, where buying decisions are increasingly collaborative and complex, this skill is essential for achieving sales success and organizational growth.

3811e82b-68ed-4684-b808-0144e7939a90.name: Multi-Stakeholder Sales Coordination
3811e82b-68ed-4684-b808-0144e7939a90.description:
Multi-Stakeholder Sales Coordination is a critical business skill focused on orchestrating and aligning the interests, actions, and communications of multiple internal and external stakeholders throughout the enterprise sales process. In today’s complex B2B environments, large-scale deals often involve diverse parties such as sales teams, technical experts, legal and compliance officers, procurement departments, executive sponsors, and client-side decision-makers. This skill ensures that all relevant stakeholders are engaged at the right stages, that their objectives and concerns are addressed, and that information flows seamlessly to prevent misalignment or delays. Effective Multi-Stakeholder Sales Coordination involves mapping stakeholder influence and decision-making authority, facilitating cross-functional collaboration, managing competing priorities, and maintaining transparency across all parties. It requires the ability to anticipate and resolve conflicts, adapt communication styles to different audiences, and drive consensus to keep the sales process moving forward. Typical use cases include coordinating product demonstrations with technical teams, aligning contract terms with legal and procurement, and ensuring executive buy-in on both sides of a transaction. The skill is currently indispensable for enterprise sales professionals, account managers, and business development leaders, as it directly impacts deal velocity, client satisfaction, and long-term partnership success. Mastery of this skill leads to smoother deal execution, reduced risk of misunderstandings, and stronger, trust-based client relationships.

e19e30b3-ede0-4082-b782-a03bb6f85f02.name: Multi-Stakeholder Sales Process Management
e19e30b3-ede0-4082-b782-a03bb6f85f02.description:
Multi-Stakeholder Sales Process Management is the strategic coordination and execution of sales cycles that involve multiple decision-makers, influencers, and internal teams. In today’s complex B2B environments, purchasing decisions are rarely made by a single individual; instead, they require consensus among diverse stakeholders such as technical evaluators, financial approvers, end-users, and executive sponsors. This skill encompasses the ability to identify, map, and engage all relevant buyer personas, understand their unique priorities and concerns, and tailor communications and value propositions accordingly. It also involves orchestrating internal resources—such as product specialists, legal advisors, and customer success teams—to address stakeholder needs and objections throughout the sales process. Effective practitioners leverage tools like stakeholder mapping, account-based selling strategies, and collaborative CRM platforms to track engagement, align messaging, and ensure seamless information flow. The skill is critical for navigating long, high-value sales cycles, reducing deal risk, and increasing win rates by building consensus and trust across complex buying committees. Typical use cases include enterprise software sales, large-scale service contracts, and any scenario where multiple departments or business units are involved in the purchasing decision. Mastery of Multi-Stakeholder Sales Process Management is essential for sales professionals aiming to drive successful outcomes in today’s interconnected and matrixed business environments.

deea24f0-94fd-4172-9f47-1db910e3205f.name: Negotiation with Multiple Stakeholders
deea24f0-94fd-4172-9f47-1db910e3205f.description:
Negotiation with Multiple Stakeholders is a critical skill in the modern business and sales execution landscape, where deals and agreements often require the alignment of diverse interests from various parties. This skill involves managing and facilitating negotiations that include several stakeholders, each with their own objectives, priorities, and levels of influence. Sales professionals must be adept at identifying and mapping stakeholder interests, building consensus, and navigating complex interpersonal and organizational dynamics. The process requires advanced communication, empathy, and conflict resolution abilities, as well as a strategic mindset to balance competing demands and drive toward mutually beneficial outcomes. In present-day business environments—characterized by cross-functional teams, global supply chains, and intricate client organizations—this skill is essential for closing high-value deals, managing partnerships, and executing large-scale projects. Typical use cases include negotiating enterprise sales contracts, multi-party vendor agreements, or joint ventures where legal, financial, technical, and operational stakeholders must all be satisfied. Mastery of this skill enables professionals to anticipate objections, manage power dynamics, and maintain momentum throughout protracted negotiations. Its immediate value lies in reducing deal friction, accelerating sales cycles, and ensuring sustainable agreements that support long-term business relationships. As organizations increasingly operate in matrixed and collaborative structures, the ability to negotiate effectively with multiple stakeholders is indispensable for achieving sales success today.

In addition to the network itself, they also secure traffic and network-accessible assets at both the network edge and inside the perimeter.

c4b40c0c-cab8-4466-8339-65921ac88a38.name: Network security architecture
c4b40c0c-cab8-4466-8339-65921ac88a38.description: A network security architecture incorporates various security components and technologies to safeguard the network's data flow, detect intrusions, and mitigate vulnerabilities. To remain effective it should continuously adapt to evolving threats and new technologies.

e0a5cac7-45bd-4765-867b-612ccb1e6f37.name: Neuromorphic computing
e0a5cac7-45bd-4765-867b-612ccb1e6f37.description: Neuromorphic computing is an engineering approach in which components of a computer are designed to mimic the functions of systems in the human brain and nervous system.

960e3038-7260-4760-91ab-c0460671e9cc.name: New Relic
960e3038-7260-4760-91ab-c0460671e9cc.description: New Relic is a cloud-based observability platform designed to provide real-time insights into the performance and behavior of digital systems. It offers perspective on applications and infrastructure, allowing users to track various performance metrics.

44f467af-8a5c-43f3-a42a-0e497b4b106a.name: NextJs
44f467af-8a5c-43f3-a42a-0e497b4b106a.description: A powerful framework for building high-performance, server rendered web applications. The React Framework for the Web. Used by some of the world's largest companies, Next.js enables you to create high-quality web applications with the power of React components.

ef38176f-5ecb-436f-85f9-66f9d45198f9.name: Nexus IQ
ef38176f-5ecb-436f-85f9-66f9d45198f9.description: Nexus IQ is a software application by Sonatype that acts as a vulnerability scanner. It analyzes the components within your application, searching for known security weaknesses. Imagine it as a security inspector meticulously examining the building blocks of your software.

f0801d45-854d-4906-9ede-d75f22b0d2ff.name: Nmap
f0801d45-854d-4906-9ede-d75f22b0d2ff.description: Nmap, or "Network Mapper," is a free, open-source tool primarily used for network discovery and security, as well as auditing network inventory, managing service upgrade schedules, and monitoring host or service uptime.

1a2d7a6c-7f2b-4e17-af7e-a42883b82df1.name: No-code development platform
1a2d7a6c-7f2b-4e17-af7e-a42883b82df1.description:
No-code development platforms (NCDPs) allow creating application software through graphical user interfaces and configuration instead of traditional computer programming based on writing code.

No-code development platforms are closely related to low-code development platforms as both are designed to expedite the application development process. However, unlike low-code, no-code development platforms require no code writing at all, generally offering prebuilt templates that businesses can build apps with. In the 2010s, these platforms have both increased in popularity as companies deal with a limited supply of competent software developers.

No-code development platforms are closely related to visual programming languages.  Ref:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/No-code_development_platform

a92ef4e3-e522-48a5-8f43-a2a5a99bb12d.name: NoOps
a92ef4e3-e522-48a5-8f43-a2a5a99bb12d.description: NoOps (or No Operations) is an approach to software development that seeks to reduce the amount of manual operations required to maintain a software system. It focuses on automating the entire software lifecycle, from development to deployment and maintenance. NoOps is often used in custom software development to reduce the amount of time and effort required to maintain a system.

c89fae3f-da84-4928-8f77-92cbbcd37630.name: Node.js
c89fae3f-da84-4928-8f77-92cbbcd37630.description:
Node.js is a cross-platform, open-source JavaScript runtime environment that can run on Windows, Linux, Unix, macOS, and more. Node.js runs on the V8 JavaScript engine, and executes JavaScript code outside a web browser.

Node.js lets developers use JavaScript to write command line tools and for server-side scripting. The ability to run JavaScript code on the server is often used to generate dynamic web page content before the page is sent to the user's web browser. Consequently, Node.js represents a "JavaScript everywhere" paradigm, unifying web-application development around a single programming language, as opposed to using different languages for the server- versus client-side programming.

Node.js has an event-driven architecture capable of asynchronous I/O. These design choices aim to optimize throughput and scalability in web applications with many input/output operations, as well as for real-time Web applications (e.g., real-time communication programs and browser games).

The Node.js distributed development project was previously governed by the Node.js Foundation, and has now merged with the JS Foundation to form the OpenJS Foundation. OpenJS Foundation is facilitated by the Linux Foundation's Collaborative Projects program. Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Node.js

64cb521c-c8a2-444e-a923-cb182e40ca6d.name: Non-functional requirement
64cb521c-c8a2-444e-a923-cb182e40ca6d.description:
In systems engineering and requirements engineering, a non-functional requirement (NFR) is a requirement that specifies criteria that can be used to judge the operation of a system, rather than specific behaviours. They are contrasted with functional requirements that define specific behavior or functions. The plan for implementing functional requirements is detailed in the system design. The plan for implementing non-functional requirements is detailed in the system architecture, because they are usually architecturally significant requirements.

Definition
Broadly, functional requirements define what a system is supposed to do and non-functional requirements define how a system is supposed to be. Functional requirements are usually in the form of "system shall do <requirement>", an individual action or part of the system, perhaps explicitly in the sense of a mathematical function, a black box description input, output, process and control functional model or IPO Model. In contrast, non-functional requirements are in the form of "system shall be <requirement>", an overall property of the system as a whole or of a particular aspect and not a specific function. The system's overall properties commonly mark the difference between whether the development project has succeeded or failed.

Non-functional requirements are often called the "quality attributes" of a system. Other terms for non-functional requirements are "qualities", "quality goals", "quality of service requirements", "constraints", "non-behavioral requirements", or "technical requirements". Informally these are sometimes called the "ilities", from attributes like stability and portability. Qualities—that is non-functional requirements—can be divided into two main categories:

Execution qualities, such as safety, security and usability, which are observable during operation (at run time).
Evolution qualities, such as testability, maintainability, extensibility and scalability, which are embodied in the static structure of the system.
It is important to specify non-functional requirements in a specific and measurable way.  Ref:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-functional_requirement

78ffb21e-b566-4786-a0b4-8fd3dbd84276.name: Nuxt
78ffb21e-b566-4786-a0b4-8fd3dbd84276.description:
The Intuitive Vue
Framework
Build your next Vue.js application with confidence using Nuxt.
An open source framework making web development simple and powerful.

494c9cae-ab32-4602-ba01-2ebe8b49084a.name: OIDC
494c9cae-ab32-4602-ba01-2ebe8b49084a.description: OIDC stands for OpenID Connect protocol, which is an identity authentication protocol used to enable two unrelated applications to share user profile information without compromising user credentials.

e66f5ea0-1d1c-4564-a76c-98d2963f6db1.name: OLAP cubes
e66f5ea0-1d1c-4564-a76c-98d2963f6db1.description: In traditional OLAP systems, OLAP cubes serve as multidimensional staging platforms that allow users to combine data into organized structures for more efficient analysis. OLAP cubes are usually grouped by business function, so teams can easily find the data sets relevant to their business questions.

e498c6e3-ec53-476b-9613-dba6af258a9e.name: ORM (Object-Relational Mapping)
e498c6e3-ec53-476b-9613-dba6af258a9e.description: Object-relational mapping (ORM) is a way to align programming code with database structures. ORM uses metadata descriptors to create a layer between the programming language and a relational database. It thus connects object-oriented program (OOP) code with the database and simplifies the interaction between relational databases and OOP languages.

db164f10-869a-4d03-b82d-a86b53c65a04.name: Objection handling
db164f10-869a-4d03-b82d-a86b53c65a04.description: Objection handling is when a prospect presents a concern about the product/service a salesperson is selling, and the salesperson responds in a way that alleviates those concerns and allows the deal to move forward. Objections are generally around price, product fit, or competitors.

32b139dd-cdd7-4e42-ba88-a84c02ba1e95.name: Objective-C
32b139dd-cdd7-4e42-ba88-a84c02ba1e95.description: Objective-C is an object-oriented programming language developers use to create applications for Apple's macOS, iOS, and iPad operating systems. Among computer programming languages, Objective-C is easy to understand, and is known for its dynamic binding and reflection capabilities.

037ed99b-9837-49a9-985c-ffa87660b93b.name: Occupational Personality Questionnaire (OPQ)
037ed99b-9837-49a9-985c-ffa87660b93b.description: The Occupational Personality Questionnaire (OPQ), also known as the SHL Personality Test or OPQ32, is a psychometric evaluation used to assess workplace characteristics and behavior. It is a widely used personality assessment tool designed to measure an individual's workplace-related personality traits and behavioral preferences. The OPQ test is used to assess all levels of employees, from graduate positions to top management. It provides detailed information on  specific personality characteristics proven to influence performance.

4c4478dc-f6a8-4d72-aa6b-8ccd6e4154a2.name: Offshoring
4c4478dc-f6a8-4d72-aa6b-8ccd6e4154a2.description: Offshoring is the transferring activities or ownership of a complete business process to a different country from the country (or countries) where the company receiving the services is located.

cbbc5de8-c079-4a17-94b1-0bb6c07e499a.name: Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP)
cbbc5de8-c079-4a17-94b1-0bb6c07e499a.description: The Open Web Application Security Project [7] (OWASP) is an online community that produces freely available articles, methodologies, documentation, tools, and technologies in the fields of IoT, system software and web application security.[8][9][10] The OWASP provides free and open resources. It is led by a non-profit called The OWASP Foundation. The OWASP Top 10 - 2021 is the published result of recent research based on comprehensive data compiled from over 40 partner organizations.  Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OWASP

e21479c2-03ef-4832-8f16-644afb566e91.name: OpenAI API
e21479c2-03ef-4832-8f16-644afb566e91.description: The OpenAI API can be applied to virtually any task that requires understanding or generating natural language and code. The OpenAI API can also be used to generate and edit images or convert speech into text. We offer a range of models with different capabilities and price points, as well as the ability to fine-tune custom models.

9998ede8-707c-4b8f-a354-7316f478e06e.name: OpenEJB
9998ede8-707c-4b8f-a354-7316f478e06e.description:
OpenEJB was founded by Richard Monson-Haefel and David Blevins in December 1999. At the time there were new vendors moving in the enterprise Java space seemingly every week. Rather than join the space as a competitor, the project was focused entirely on providing these new platforms with a way to quickly get EJB compliance via plugging OpenEJB into their application server.

The first to integrate OpenEJB in this fashion was Apple's WebObjects in late 2000, released in 2001. When the project moved to Source Forge in 2002 an Apache Tomcat integration was created. Again rather than follow what most in the industry were doing and putting Tomcat into OpenEJB, the project decided to follow its vision and provide an integration that allowed Tomcat users to plug in OpenEJB to gain EJB support in the Tomcat platform. It was in this same vein of putting an EJB container into a Web server that the project developed the Collapsed EAR concept of putting EJBs inside the .war file.

As part of the work that OpenEJB did to prepare for the integration with Apple's WebObjects, a very large integration test suite was developed. The test suite was developed as a generic application since it would need to be run against both WebObjects and other platforms that integrated OpenEJB. For simplicity in the build the test suite based on JUnit, was run with OpenEJB right inside the tests rather than as a separate process, which was easy to do as the container was designed to be plugged into other platforms and make as little assumptions about its environment as possible. It was from this work that the concept of combining an EJB application with plain unit tests and an embeddable EJB container was born. Originally referred to as a "local" EJB container and what lead the project to describe itself as being able to run in two modes: Local and Remote.

In August 2003 the project helped launch the Apache Geronimo application server. Originally a new version of OpenEJB was developed ground up based on Geronimo's GBean architecture and released as OpenEJB 2.0 which lived throughout the Geronimo 1.x cycle. In 2006 when EJB 3.0 was released which had a focus on simplicity, the project went back to its roots and revived the OpenEJB 1.0 codebase, ported select bits of the 2.0 codebase, and eventually brought it up to the EJB 3.0 spec level in what is now called OpenEJB 3.0.

adff1f8a-8dfe-48e8-8fb8-2ef72414b30b.name: OpenESB
adff1f8a-8dfe-48e8-8fb8-2ef72414b30b.description: OpenESB is a Java-based open-source enterprise service bus. It can be used as a platform for both enterprise application integration and service-oriented architecture. OpenESB allows developers to integrate legacy systems, external and internal partners and new development in business processes.

a41fb597-4907-4e96-a285-41e35416ddcd.name: OpenLDAP
a41fb597-4907-4e96-a285-41e35416ddcd.description: OpenLDAP is a free, open-source implementation of the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) developed by the OpenLDAP Project. It is released under its own BSD-style license called the OpenLDAP Public License.

15634462-40e1-4bbe-9ea2-0acec16b2897.name: OpenShift
15634462-40e1-4bbe-9ea2-0acec16b2897.description: OpenShift Container Platform is a Kubernetes environment for managing the lifecycle of container-based applications and their dependencies on various computing platforms, such as bare metal, virtualized, on-premise, and in cloud. OpenShift Container Platform deploys, configures and manages containers.

2ba1f28a-93bb-42cf-8f87-96831f114455.name: OpenVPN
2ba1f28a-93bb-42cf-8f87-96831f114455.description: OpenVPN, or Open Virtual Private Network, is an open-source system that creates a private and secure tunnel between networks. It refers to multiple different but related things: The open-source OpenVPN protocol used to create encrypted tunnels between networks and establish a VPN connection.

7c0fa258-948a-41e2-a941-d58e850af42c.name: Operating System
7c0fa258-948a-41e2-a941-d58e850af42c.description: An operating system is the most important software which runs on a computer. It controls the computer's memory, processes and all software and hardware. Several computer programs normally run at the same time, all of which need to access the computer's processor (CPU), memory, and storage.

aeda056a-2964-4900-bb50-81a06b7f4181.name: Operations management
aeda056a-2964-4900-bb50-81a06b7f4181.description: The ability to streamline operations and improve efficiency, including managing supply chains, logistics, and production processes.

c03e1e21-3920-46bd-9f99-c3e029a702bb.name: Optical Character Recognition (OCR)
c03e1e21-3920-46bd-9f99-c3e029a702bb.description: Optical Character Recognition (OCR) is the process that converts an image of text into a machine-readable text format. For example, if you scan a form or a receipt, your computer saves the scan as an image file. You cannot use a text editor to edit, search, or count the words in the image file.

c1438c9a-b31e-4b58-bc2d-6a334beb5997.name: Oracle Analytics Cloud (OAC)
c1438c9a-b31e-4b58-bc2d-6a334beb5997.description: Oracle Analytics Cloud (OAC) is a fully managed cloud-based BI and analytics platform from Oracle. It is designed as a single and complete platform that empowers business users and analysts to ask questions about their data — across any environment and from any device.

6c9f43cf-d929-4045-9c4a-3b1e80b3b0b3.name: Oracle Apex (Application Express)
6c9f43cf-d929-4045-9c4a-3b1e80b3b0b3.description: Oracle Application Express enables a single Oracle database to become a shared workgroup database service. Multiple users can access it using a Web browser without installing additional software.

d16184a9-aa8f-485a-ba8c-726d02350b9d.name: Oracle BI Publisher
d16184a9-aa8f-485a-ba8c-726d02350b9d.description: Oracle Business Intelligence Publisher (BI Publisher, formerly XML Publisher) is an enterprise reporting solution that streamlines report and form generation. A primary feature of Oracle's BI Publisher product is the separation of the data extraction process from the report layout.

3dcbd32f-0191-4507-b53c-84ca8f45242e.name: Oracle Big Data SQL
3dcbd32f-0191-4507-b53c-84ca8f45242e.description: Oracle Big Data SQL enables organizations to immediately analyze data across Apache Hadoop, Apache Kafka, NoSQL, object stores and Oracle Database leveraging their existing SQL skills, security policies and applications with extreme performance.

0822d677-f030-45f8-ae43-82fa1f7eee7f.name: Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI)
0822d677-f030-45f8-ae43-82fa1f7eee7f.description: Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) is a cloud computing platform that enables you to build and run a wide range of applications in a highly available, high-performance environment.

1ed52331-598a-48d0-84bc-db60f329f448.name: Oracle Cloud
1ed52331-598a-48d0-84bc-db60f329f448.description: Oracle Cloud is the database company's public cloud service offering. Oracle has positioned and tailored its cloud services as the best option to run Oracle databases. It is a competitor to the market-leading competitor, Amazon. Oracle has a global network of managed data centers set to run their cloud offerings.

99b33b49-9fa2-4dd0-8d23-de0f2a082676.name: Oracle Data Integrator
99b33b49-9fa2-4dd0-8d23-de0f2a082676.description: Oracle Data Integrator is an extract, load, transform tool produced by Oracle that offers a graphical environment to build, manage and maintain data integration processes in business intelligence systems.

74e89d85-bfa1-460c-ab12-78bb6fb54d30.name: Oracle E-Business Suite (EBS)
74e89d85-bfa1-460c-ab12-78bb6fb54d30.description: E-Business Suite is an integrated set of business applications for automating CRM, ERP and SCM processes. Other core functions and features include human capital management, asset lifecycle management, order management, procurement, project portfolio management, and business intelligence and analytics.

26f4c60e-71ee-42dd-854c-cf05138026b6.name: Oracle GoldenGate
26f4c60e-71ee-42dd-854c-cf05138026b6.description: Oracle GoldenGate is a software product that allows you to replicate, filter, and transform data from one database to another database. Using Oracle GoldenGate, you can move committed transactions across multiple heterogeneous systems in your enterprise.

70893504-a7d2-4a0e-8ffd-53481e3b46ac.name: Oracle PL/SQL
70893504-a7d2-4a0e-8ffd-53481e3b46ac.description: PL/SQL is a procedural language designed specifically to embrace SQL statements within its syntax. PL/SQL program units are compiled by the Oracle Database server and stored inside the database. And at run-time, both PL/SQL and SQL run within the same server process, bringing optimal efficiency. PL/SQL automatically inherits the robustness, security, and portability of the Oracle Database.

f52b8d3f-f4b3-443e-95d6-e40ed16877b8.name: Oracle RDBMS
f52b8d3f-f4b3-443e-95d6-e40ed16877b8.description: Oracle database, originally a relational DBMS, has evolved into a converged, multi-model DBMS, e.g. it supports multiple types of workload (OLTP, data warehouse, operational data store, data hub), it can manage and join together multiple types of data (relational, XML, JSON, spatial, property graph, RDF, text, binary) being stored inside or outside the database, it supports numerous deployment types (single instance, clustered shared everything, sharded shared-nothing, reader-farms, on-premises, public cloud, standard hardware, engineered system), and it can be accessed using multiple APIs (SQL, REST APIs, Simple Oracle Document Access, Property Graph Query Language, JDBC/ODBC drivers for multiple languages).

41c91a11-30e2-4a7e-990c-24fd84701b4d.name: Oracle's PeopleSoft
41c91a11-30e2-4a7e-990c-24fd84701b4d.description: Oracle's PeopleSoft is an industry leading, proven, functionally deep, full suite of integrated applications that can address your business needs for Human Capital Management (HCM) and Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP).

1b345412-d476-47d0-9001-f7964c378adb.name: Orchestrating Cross-Functional Sales Teams
1b345412-d476-47d0-9001-f7964c378adb.description:
Orchestrating Cross-Functional Sales Teams is a critical skill in the modern business and sales enablement landscape, where complex deals often require seamless collaboration between diverse functional groups. This skill involves coordinating and aligning the efforts of sales, technical, product, marketing, and customer support teams to deliver tailored solutions that address multifaceted client needs. Practitioners must possess a deep understanding of each team's unique contributions, workflows, and priorities, ensuring that communication is clear, objectives are aligned, and resources are efficiently allocated. The ability to facilitate cross-departmental meetings, manage interdependencies, and resolve conflicts is essential, as is the capacity to translate customer requirements into actionable tasks for each team. In today's fast-paced, customer-centric environment, orchestrating cross-functional sales teams enables organizations to respond rapidly to market opportunities, reduce sales cycle times, and improve win rates for complex deals. Typical use cases include managing enterprise sales opportunities, launching new products that require technical integration, or delivering customized solutions that span multiple business units. This skill is immediately relevant as organizations increasingly adopt matrix structures and collaborative selling models, making the ability to unify diverse expertise a key driver of sales success and customer satisfaction.

Domain: Marketing & Sales
Domain Description: Marketing, sales, customer acquisition, and retention
Skill Type: Transferable and Functional
Skill Areas: Experience, Technical, Process

bc456b25-9f9c-4f08-9c27-ea65f253aadd.name: Organizational Decision Mapping
bc456b25-9f9c-4f08-9c27-ea65f253aadd.description:
Organizational Decision Mapping is the systematic process of identifying, visualizing, and analyzing the decision-making structures within client organizations, with a particular focus on B2B environments. This skill involves mapping out key stakeholders, understanding their roles, influence, and interrelationships, and uncovering both formal and informal pathways through which decisions are made. In today’s complex business landscape, where purchasing decisions often involve multiple departments and layers of approval, the ability to accurately map these structures is crucial for sales professionals, account managers, consultants, and business development teams. By leveraging Organizational Decision Mapping, professionals can tailor their engagement strategies, anticipate objections, and align their value propositions with the interests and priorities of the true decision-makers. This skill is immediately relevant for increasing deal success rates, shortening sales cycles, and building stronger client relationships by ensuring that all influential parties are identified and appropriately engaged. Typical use cases include preparing for high-stakes sales pitches, navigating enterprise procurement processes, and managing complex stakeholder environments during mergers or strategic partnerships. Mastery of this skill requires a blend of analytical thinking, interpersonal communication, and organizational awareness, as well as the ability to synthesize information from various sources such as org charts, interviews, and digital footprints. Organizational Decision Mapping is a cornerstone capability for any business professional seeking to drive outcomes in multi-stakeholder, high-value engagements.

Domain: Business Strategy
Domain Description: Strategic planning, market analysis, and business development
Skill Type: Knowledge Based
Skill Areas: Organizational, Technical, Process
Relevance Score: 1.2

5cbb5001-2ba3-4e18-8c1f-1e1a18d00fc2.name: Organizational Decision-Maker Mapping
5cbb5001-2ba3-4e18-8c1f-1e1a18d00fc2.description:
Organizational Decision-Maker Mapping is the systematic process of identifying, analyzing, and documenting the individuals and groups within a client or partner organization who possess formal or informal decision-making authority. This skill is crucial in today’s complex business environments, where organizational structures are often matrixed, distributed, or otherwise non-hierarchical. Practitioners of this skill leverage a combination of research, stakeholder interviews, organizational chart analysis, and social network mapping to uncover both explicit and hidden power dynamics. The primary purpose is to enable targeted engagement strategies, ensuring that communications, proposals, and negotiations are directed toward those with the actual authority to approve, influence, or block key decisions. This skill is immediately relevant for sales professionals, consultants, account managers, and business development teams who must navigate intricate organizational landscapes to achieve buy-in, close deals, or drive change initiatives. Effective decision-maker mapping reduces wasted effort, shortens sales cycles, and increases the likelihood of successful outcomes by focusing resources on the right stakeholders. It also supports risk mitigation by revealing potential blockers or influencers early in the engagement process. In the context of Business / Organizational Dynamics, this skill is foundational for building trust, tailoring value propositions, and fostering long-term client relationships in a rapidly evolving, stakeholder-driven business world.

Domain: Business Strategy
Domain Description: Strategic planning, market analysis, and business development
Skill Type: Knowledge Based
Skill Areas: Organizational, Technical, Process
Relevance Score: 1.2
Generated by: Frøya v2.0.0

It also supports risk mitigation by revealing potential blockers or influencers early in the engagement process. In the context of Business / Organizational Dynamics, this skill is foundational for building trust, tailoring value propositions, and fostering long-term client relationships in a rapidly evolving, stakeholder-driven business world.

2b7fdac6-bc63-4b21-8717-903afd78796c.name: Organizational design

dbc3aecd-52b0-4ee1-afd9-d4a6104c628f.name: Organizational design

cbf75e73-aec8-4d36-a7aa-ab510cb7c829.name: Organizational storytelling
cbf75e73-aec8-4d36-a7aa-ab510cb7c829.description:
Organizational storytelling (also known as business storytelling) is a concept in management and organization studies. It recognises the special place of narration in human communication, making narration "the foundation of discursive thought and the possibility of acting in common.[1]" This follows the narrative paradigm, a view of human communication based on the conception of persons as homo narrans.[2]

Business organisations explicitly value "hard" knowledge that can be classified, categorized, calculated, analyzed, etc., practical know-how (explicit and tacit) and know-who (social connections). In contrast, storytelling employs ancient means of passing wisdom and culture through informal stories and anecdotes. The narrative is said to be more "synthetic" than "analytic", and help to: share norms and values, develop trust and commitment, share tacit knowledge, facilitate unlearning, and generate emotional connections.[3] Storytelling is an ingredient to make an idea "stick".[4]

While storytelling is a key ingredient in great advertising, organizational storytelling caters to a very different audience. It deals with human beings in organizations connecting, engaging and inspiring other stakeholders using stories and story structures in their communication.
Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_storytelling

7c532fba-9bdc-4f7d-8950-60eb7bcbcc74.name: Pentesting -  penetration testing
7c532fba-9bdc-4f7d-8950-60eb7bcbcc74.description:
A penetration test, colloquially known as a pentest, is an authorized simulated cyberattack on a computer system, performed to evaluate the security of the system; this is not to be confused with a vulnerability assessment. The test is performed to identify weaknesses (or vulnerabilities), including the potential for unauthorized parties to gain access to the system's features and data, as well as strengths, enabling a full risk assessment to be completed.

The process typically identifies the target systems and a particular goal, then reviews available information and undertakes various means to attain that goal. A penetration test target may be a white box (about which background and system information are provided in advance to the tester) or a black box (about which only basic information other than the company name is provided). A gray box penetration test is a combination of the two (where limited knowledge of the target is shared with the auditor). A penetration test can help identify a system's vulnerabilities to attack and estimate how vulnerable it is.

Security issues that the penetration test uncovers should be reported to the system owner. Penetration test reports may also assess potential impacts to the organization and suggest countermeasures to reduce the risk. Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penetration_test

af21d6fc-c9d5-4caf-a25a-2b4f75dcf368.name: Personalized Sales Messaging
af21d6fc-c9d5-4caf-a25a-2b4f75dcf368.description:
Personalized Sales Messaging is a creative skill that involves crafting tailored communications designed to resonate with individual buyers by addressing their unique needs, preferences, and contexts. In today's highly competitive and customer-centric marketplace, generic sales pitches are often ignored or dismissed. Instead, effective sales professionals leverage creativity and empathy to develop messages that speak directly to the recipient's situation, challenges, and aspirations. This skill requires a nuanced understanding of the target audience, including their industry, role, pain points, and motivations. Practitioners use a variety of data sources—such as buyer personas, behavioral analytics, and previous interactions—to inform their messaging strategies. The creative aspect lies in transforming these insights into compelling narratives, subject lines, and calls to action that feel authentic and relevant. Personalized Sales Messaging is immediately valuable in digital channels such as email, social media, and chat, as well as in traditional formats like phone calls and face-to-face meetings. It drives higher engagement rates, fosters trust, and significantly improves conversion by making each prospect feel understood and valued. Typical use cases include customizing outreach for account-based marketing, following up after a product demo with tailored value propositions, or adapting messaging for different stages of the buyer journey. Mastery of this skill is essential for sales professionals, marketers, and entrepreneurs seeking to differentiate their offerings and build lasting customer relationships in the current business landscape.

6b027177-a7a1-4f71-b70c-45342f2323aa.description:

Unlike generic messaging, this approach requires a deep understanding of the recipient's context, industry, challenges, and goals, enabling communicators to highlight the most relevant benefits and differentiators of their offerings.
