aa01408f-5b1f-4900-b5fe-8f04d9aa6d48.name: Responsive web design (RWD)
aa01408f-5b1f-4900-b5fe-8f04d9aa6d48.description: Responsive web design (RWD) or responsive design is an approach to web design that aims to make web pages render well on a variety of devices and window or screen sizes from minimum to maximum display size to ensure usability and satisfaction.

b49263bf-874f-4468-b8dd-13d144f25304.name: Retail
b49263bf-874f-4468-b8dd-13d144f25304.description: Retail is the sale of goods and services to consumers, in contrast to wholesaling, which is the sale to business or institutional customers. A retailer purchases goods in large quantities from manufacturers, directly or through a wholesaler, and then sells in smaller quantities to consumers for a profit.

b3a29088-4561-40bc-906a-0c4b89c54ee5.name: Retrieval augmented generation (RAG)
b3a29088-4561-40bc-906a-0c4b89c54ee5.description:
RAG is an AI framework for retrieving facts from an external knowledge base to ground large language models (LLMs) on the most accurate, up-to-date information and to give users insight into LLMs' generative process.

Blog_RAG post.jpg
Try RAG with watsonx

RAG is an AI framework for retrieving facts from an external knowledge base to ground large language models (LLMs) on the most accurate, up-to-date information and to give users insight into LLMs' generative process.

Large language models can be inconsistent. Sometimes they nail the answer to questions, other times they regurgitate random facts from their training data. If they occasionally sound like they have no idea what they’re saying, it’s because they don’t. LLMs know how words relate statistically, but not what they mean. (Reference: https://research.ibm.com/blog/retrieval-augmented-generation-RAG)

eb446a60-2d43-4302-b511-f1e6ab911728.name: Risk Assessment
eb446a60-2d43-4302-b511-f1e6ab911728.description: Risk assessment determines possible mishaps, their likelihood and consequences, and the tolerances for such events. The results of this process may be expressed in a quantitative or qualitative fashion.

c6449876-5e14-4ef7-b274-74227e436128.name: Risk analysis
c6449876-5e14-4ef7-b274-74227e436128.description:
Risk analysis is a technique used to identify and assess factors that may jeopardize the success of a project or achieving a goal.

This technique also helps to define preventive measures to reduce the probability of these factors from occurring and identify countermeasures to successfully deal with these constraints when they develop to avert possible negative effects on the competitiveness of the company.

One of the more popular methods to perform a risk analysis in the computer field is called facilitated risk analysis process (FRAP).  Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk_analysis_(business)

8a6dfb38-3cf3-4531-9280-e7f8729dca29.name: Risk management
8a6dfb38-3cf3-4531-9280-e7f8729dca29.description: Risk management is the identification, evaluation, and prioritization of risks (defined in ISO 31000 as the effect of uncertainty on objectives) followed by coordinated and economical application of resources to minimize, monitor, and control the probability or impact of unfortunate events[1] or to maximize the realization of opportunities.

fa282723-51b5-4e94-890d-4c970526a297.name: Robot Framework
fa282723-51b5-4e94-890d-4c970526a297.description: Robot Framework is an open source automation framework for test automation and robotic process automation (RPA).

533f6297-cb85-47d2-8cef-15537d21ba37.name: Robotics
533f6297-cb85-47d2-8cef-15537d21ba37.description: Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots. Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms.

7acf4685-699b-45ff-8c57-cd1ecc43ad42.name: Robustness
7acf4685-699b-45ff-8c57-cd1ecc43ad42.description: Robustness is the capability of performing without failure under a wide range of possible conditions.

b78ea50f-ec34-4821-bf05-d6fe22047c75.name: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
b78ea50f-ec34-4821-bf05-d6fe22047c75.description: Role-based access control allows organizations to assign one or more roles to each user or assign permissions individually. The goal is to define permissions that allow users to perform their tasks without further changes. Organizations use Identity and Access Management (IAM) systems to implement and monitor RBAC.

4fdb89c4-7057-46db-ae1c-b558a1fd1f8f.name: Routing
4fdb89c4-7057-46db-ae1c-b558a1fd1f8f.description:
Routing is the process of selecting a path for traffic in a network or between or across multiple networks. Broadly, routing is performed in many types of networks, including circuit-switched networks, such as the public switched telephone network (PSTN), and computer networks, such as the Internet.

In packet switching networks, routing is the higher-level decision making that directs network packets from their source toward their destination through intermediate network nodes by specific packet forwarding mechanisms. Packet forwarding is the transit of network packets from one network interface to another. Intermediate nodes are typically network hardware devices such as routers, gateways, firewalls, or switches. General-purpose computers also forward packets and perform routing, although they have no specially optimized hardware for the task.

The routing process usually directs forwarding on the basis of routing tables. Routing tables maintain a record of the routes to various network destinations. Routing tables may be specified by an administrator, learned by observing network traffic or built with the assistance of routing protocols.

bf69a36b-4e26-41ff-b3ba-bc4416f53543.name: Ruby
bf69a36b-4e26-41ff-b3ba-bc4416f53543.description: Ruby is an open-source object-oriented scripting language invented in the mid-90s by Yukihiro Matsumoto. Unlike languages such as C and C++, a scripting language doesn't talk directly to hardware. It's written to a text file and then parsed by an interpreter and turned into code.

c9b04686-1e52-423b-bde5-7180066d1da8.name: Runtime
c9b04686-1e52-423b-bde5-7180066d1da8.description: The container runtime is the low-level component that creates and runs containers.

dd8b73b6-f534-48dd-be78-2aac27281d4f.name: Rust
dd8b73b6-f534-48dd-be78-2aac27281d4f.description: Rust is a multi-paradigm, general-purpose programming language that emphasizes performance, type safety, and concurrency. It enforces memory safety—meaning that all references point to valid memory—without a garbage collector.

8c14dadc-32da-4023-848b-e8bf62049152.name: SAML
8c14dadc-32da-4023-848b-e8bf62049152.description: Security Assertion Markup Language, or SAML, is a standardized way to tell external applications and services that a user is who they say they are. SAML makes single sign-on (SSO) technology possible by providing a way to authenticate a user once and then communicate that authentication to multiple applications.

cfc418fb-e30e-444d-9b23-f6516fe2bb85.name: SOA
cfc418fb-e30e-444d-9b23-f6516fe2bb85.description:
In software engineering, service-oriented architecture (SOA) is an architectural style that focuses on discrete services instead of a monolithic design.[1] By consequence, it is as well applied in the field of software design where services are provided to the other components by application components, through a communication protocol over a network. A service is a discrete unit of functionality that can be accessed remotely and acted upon and updated independently, such as retrieving a credit card statement online. SOA is also intended to be independent of vendors, products and technologies.[2]

Service orientation is a way of thinking in terms of services and service-based development and the outcomes of services.[1]

A service has four properties according to one of many definitions of SOA:[3]

    It logically represents a repeatable business activity with a specified outcome.
    It is self-contained.
    It is a black box for its consumers, meaning the consumer does not have to be aware of the service's inner workings.
    It may be composed of other services.[4]

Different services can be used in conjunction as a service mesh to provide the functionality of a large software application,[5] a principle SOA shares with modular programming. Service-oriented architecture integrates distributed, separately maintained and deployed software components. It is enabled by technologies and standards that facilitate components' communication and cooperation over a network, especially over an IP network.

SOA is related to the idea of an API (application programming interface), an interface or communication protocol between different parts of a computer program intended to simplify the implementation and maintenance of software. An API can be thought of as the service, and the SOA the architecture that allows the service to operate.

98336947-bd09-4979-9389-b418fe4808ae.name: SOAP
98336947-bd09-4979-9389-b418fe4808ae.description: SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) is a message protocol that enables the distributed elements of an application to communicate. SOAP can be carried over a variety of standard protocols, including the web-related Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP).

31262c76-94c2-41aa-834c-4cef1cc02461.name: SOAR (security orchestration, automation, and response).
31262c76-94c2-41aa-834c-4cef1cc02461.description: SOAR stands for security orchestration, automation, and response. SOAR seeks to alleviate the strain on IT teams by incorporating automated responses to a variety of events. A SOAR system can also be programmed to custom-fit an organization's needs.

008f331c-609c-4d24-977d-fcbcbb2a5051.name: SQL Server Analysis Services (SSAS)
008f331c-609c-4d24-977d-fcbcbb2a5051.description: Microsoft SQL Server Analysis Services is an online analytical processing and data mining tool in Microsoft SQL Server. SSAS is used as a tool by organizations to analyze and make sense of information possibly spread out across multiple databases, or in disparate tables or files.

eadb63fc-c64d-4944-ba13-10118104f41c.name: SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS)
eadb63fc-c64d-4944-ba13-10118104f41c.description:
SQL Server Integration Services is a platform for building enterprise-level data integration and data transformations solutions. Use Integration Services to solve complex business problems. 

For example:

Copy or download files
Load data warehouses
Cleanse and mine data
Manage SQL Server objects and data

fd9e84bc-b542-4883-9507-cba3e9d9bd29.name: SQL Server Reporting Services (SSRS)
fd9e84bc-b542-4883-9507-cba3e9d9bd29.description: SQL Server Reporting Services (SSRS) provides a set of on-premises tools and services to create, deploy, and manage paginated reports.

fdc6b4ce-fb9f-42a3-9c91-135e4d885d4c.name: SQLite
fdc6b4ce-fb9f-42a3-9c91-135e4d885d4c.description: SQLite is a C-language library that implements a small, fast, self-contained, high-reliability, full-featured, SQL database engine. SQLite is the most used database engine in the world. SQLite is built into all mobile phones and most computers and comes bundled inside countless other applications that people use every day. More Information...

8641750e-5405-49c4-829d-10b4c8acb993.name: SSL
8641750e-5405-49c4-829d-10b4c8acb993.description: SSL is standard technology for securing an internet connection by encrypting data sent between a website and a browser (or between two servers). It prevents hackers from seeing or stealing any information transferred, including personal or financial data.

5f2789f5-6bdc-4b6c-85c8-cb9cb3759719.name: SSL/TLS
5f2789f5-6bdc-4b6c-85c8-cb9cb3759719.description: SSL/TLS stands for secure sockets layer and transport layer security. It is a protocol or communication rule that allows computer systems to talk to each other on the internet safely. SSL/TLS certificates allow web browsers to identify and establish encrypted network connections to web sites using the SSL/TLS protocol.

91ad771a-6855-4dbf-9cc8-4cfd790a0e8b.name: Saas Founder
91ad771a-6855-4dbf-9cc8-4cfd790a0e8b.description: SaaS founder is one that founds or establishes a software delivery model in which software is provided on a subscription basis and centrally hosted.

56ae52a5-0d1a-4f32-8229-983b4bda4615.name: Salary negotiation
56ae52a5-0d1a-4f32-8229-983b4bda4615.description: Salary negotiation is a process where one party negotiates the amount of their pay, income, earnings, commission, salary, wages, wage remuneration, annual review, or salary raise with another party.

95920fc0-f04f-4fb6-8cbc-1fcebf60b5fe.name: Sales Coaching and Mentoring
95920fc0-f04f-4fb6-8cbc-1fcebf60b5fe.description:
Sales Coaching and Mentoring is a critical leadership skill focused on developing, guiding, and empowering sales professionals to achieve their highest potential and drive organizational success. This skill involves a structured, ongoing process where leaders provide individualized feedback, set clear performance expectations, and foster a culture of continuous learning within sales teams. Effective sales coaching and mentoring require leaders to assess team members’ strengths and areas for improvement, deliver actionable insights, and model best practices in sales techniques, negotiation, and customer relationship management. Leaders practicing this skill use real-time data, role-playing, and scenario-based learning to address immediate challenges and reinforce effective behaviors. They also act as mentors, offering career guidance, emotional support, and motivation, which helps build trust and loyalty within the team. In today’s rapidly evolving sales environment—marked by digital transformation, increased competition, and shifting customer expectations—sales coaching and mentoring are essential for maintaining agility, resilience, and high performance. Leaders who excel in this skill not only improve individual and team sales results but also contribute to talent retention and the development of future leaders. 102b1793-8051-47e0-b7b8-2d856d010e2c.name: Sales Communication for Technical Products
102b1793-8051-47e0-b7b8-2d856d010e2c.description:
Sales Communication for Technical Products is the specialized ability to effectively convey the value, functionality, and differentiation of complex technical solutions to diverse audiences, particularly prospective customers and stakeholders who may not possess deep technical expertise. This skill is critical in today's technology-driven markets, where products often involve intricate features, architectures, or integrations that can be difficult for non-technical buyers to fully grasp. Practitioners must bridge the gap between technical complexity and customer understanding, translating technical jargon into clear, benefit-focused language that addresses customer pain points and business objectives. Key aspects include active listening to uncover customer needs, tailoring messaging to various decision-makers (from technical evaluators to business executives), and using analogies, demonstrations, and data-driven evidence to build trust and credibility. The skill also encompasses handling objections, clarifying misconceptions, and facilitating informed decision-making through clear, concise, and persuasive communication. In the current landscape, where solution sales cycles are often consultative and involve multiple stakeholders, this skill is essential for differentiating offerings, shortening sales cycles, and driving adoption of technical products. Typical use cases include presenting software platforms to enterprise clients, explaining hardware capabilities to procurement teams, or guiding customers through technical proofs-of-concept. Mastery of this skill directly impacts sales success, customer satisfaction, and long-term business relationships in technical domains.

81c6e391-393a-4356-8fde-4e2b22c4a7f2.description:

It is also essential for onboarding and ongoing training, enabling sales teams to stay informed about new products, market trends, and best practices. Ultimately, Sales Enablement Content Creation bridges the gap between marketing and sales, driving revenue growth and customer satisfaction.

dc1853b0-c223-4071-a8cd-d08de56825f9.name: Sales Ethics and Compliance
dc1853b0-c223-4071-a8cd-d08de56825f9.description:
Sales Ethics and Compliance is the practice of ensuring that all sales activities, processes, and decisions adhere strictly to both legal requirements and ethical standards within the context of modern business. This skill is crucial in today's complex, high-stakes sales environments, where organizations face increasing scrutiny from regulators, customers, and the public. It involves a deep understanding of relevant laws (such as anti-bribery, anti-corruption, data privacy, and fair competition regulations), as well as internal codes of conduct and industry best practices. Practitioners must be able to identify and mitigate risks related to unethical behavior, such as misrepresentation, undue influence, or conflicts of interest, and ensure that all sales communications and transactions are transparent and honest. The skill also encompasses the ability to train and guide sales teams on compliance protocols, conduct internal audits, and respond appropriately to potential violations. In addition, Sales Ethics and Compliance requires ongoing monitoring of regulatory changes and adapting sales strategies to maintain alignment with evolving standards. Immediate applications include vetting sales proposals for compliance, managing third-party relationships, and fostering a culture of integrity that protects organizational reputation and builds long-term customer trust. In the current business climate, this skill is indispensable for avoiding legal penalties, maintaining competitive advantage, and upholding stakeholder confidence.

1da9ca01-b5ff-4ffb-89a4-f50bcdd7bc48.name: Sales Forecasting Accuracy
1da9ca01-b5ff-4ffb-89a4-f50bcdd7bc48.description:
Sales Forecasting Accuracy is a critical skill within Business and Sales Operations that focuses on the precision and reliability of predicting future sales volumes, revenues, or units sold over a defined period. This skill involves not only the use of quantitative methods—such as statistical modeling, historical data analysis, and trend identification—but also the integration of qualitative insights from market intelligence, sales team input, and customer feedback. High sales forecasting accuracy enables organizations to make informed decisions regarding inventory management, staffing, budgeting, and production planning. In today’s fast-paced business environment, where market conditions and consumer behaviors can shift rapidly, the ability to generate accurate sales forecasts is essential for minimizing financial risk, optimizing resource allocation, and maintaining a competitive edge. This skill is immediately relevant as businesses increasingly rely on real-time data analytics and advanced forecasting tools to respond to market volatility and customer demand fluctuations. Typical use cases include setting realistic sales targets, aligning supply chain operations, managing cash flow, and supporting strategic planning initiatives. Mastery of sales forecasting accuracy requires a blend of analytical proficiency, attention to detail, and the ability to interpret complex data sets, making it indispensable for sales operations professionals seeking to drive organizational efficiency and profitability.

e2877171-0ce9-438c-8f43-70a054c9dddc.name: Sales Funnel Optimization
e2877171-0ce9-438c-8f43-70a054c9dddc.description:
Sales Funnel Optimization is the strategic process of analyzing, refining, and enhancing each stage of the sales funnel to maximize conversion rates and revenue generation. In today's highly competitive business environment, this skill is crucial for organizations seeking to streamline their sales processes, reduce customer acquisition costs, and improve overall profitability. Sales Funnel Optimization involves a data-driven approach to identifying bottlenecks, drop-off points, and inefficiencies within the funnel, from initial lead generation through to final purchase and post-sale engagement. Practitioners leverage tools such as CRM systems, analytics platforms, and A/B testing to monitor user behavior, segment audiences, and tailor messaging or offers to specific customer personas. Key activities include mapping the customer journey, optimizing landing pages, refining lead nurturing workflows, and implementing retargeting strategies. The skill also requires close collaboration with marketing, sales, and customer success teams to ensure alignment and consistency across touchpoints. Effective Sales Funnel Optimization leads to increased lead quality, higher conversion rates, shorter sales cycles, and improved customer lifetime value. It is immediately relevant for businesses of all sizes, especially those operating in digital or omnichannel environments, as it directly impacts revenue growth and competitive advantage in the current marketplace.

20a9517b-72b9-4529-b811-87fb028cf4ea.name: Sales Gamification Strategy
20a9517b-72b9-4529-b811-87fb028cf4ea.description:
Sales Gamification Strategy is the creative design and implementation of game-inspired elements within sales processes to drive motivation, engagement, and performance among sales teams. This skill involves conceptualizing and deploying innovative incentive programs that leverage principles from game design—such as points, leaderboards, challenges, badges, and rewards—to transform routine sales activities into dynamic, interactive experiences. In the current business landscape, where remote and hybrid work environments are prevalent and competition for talent is high, sales gamification provides immediate value by fostering a sense of achievement, healthy competition, and collaboration. Practitioners of this skill must understand both the psychological drivers of motivation and the unique culture of their sales teams, tailoring gamified experiences to align with organizational goals and individual aspirations. Effective sales gamification strategies require a blend of creativity, data-driven insight, and empathy, ensuring that incentives are meaningful and that progress is transparent and measurable. Typical use cases include launching quarterly sales competitions, integrating real-time feedback systems, and designing digital platforms that visualize progress and celebrate milestones. This skill is crucial for sales leaders, HR professionals, and creative strategists seeking to boost productivity, reduce turnover, and cultivate a high-performance sales culture. Its relevance is underscored by the growing demand for innovative employee engagement solutions and the proven impact of gamification on sales outcomes.

47a003c1-5e5f-4ac2-8ed6-abfc68000764.name: Sales Knowledge Management
47a003c1-5e5f-4ac2-8ed6-abfc68000764.description:
Sales Knowledge Management is the systematic process of capturing, organizing, sharing, and leveraging critical sales-related information, best practices, and insights across an organization to drive sales effectiveness and competitive advantage. In today’s fast-paced business environment, sales teams must rapidly adapt to changing markets, customer needs, and product offerings. This skill ensures that valuable institutional knowledge—such as successful sales strategies, objection handling techniques, customer profiles, product updates, and competitive intelligence—is not lost but instead made accessible to all relevant stakeholders. Effective Sales Knowledge Management involves the use of digital platforms (such as CRM systems, knowledge bases, and collaboration tools), standardized documentation practices, and structured onboarding and training programs. It also requires fostering a culture of knowledge sharing, where sales professionals are encouraged to contribute their experiences and learnings. By enabling quick access to up-to-date information and proven methodologies, organizations can reduce ramp-up time for new hires, improve sales consistency, and respond more effectively to customer inquiries. Typical use cases include creating a centralized repository of sales playbooks, facilitating peer-to-peer learning sessions, and integrating real-time feedback loops to continuously refine sales processes. This skill is currently essential for organizations seeking to maintain agility, ensure alignment across distributed teams, and maximize the impact of their sales efforts in a highly competitive marketplace.

e3319e75-e7c7-4dd3-a78d-c279fc2772b1.name: Sales Opportunity Profitability Analysis
e3319e75-e7c7-4dd3-a78d-c279fc2772b1.description:
Sales Opportunity Profitability Analysis is the systematic evaluation of potential sales deals to determine their expected financial contribution to an organization’s bottom line. This skill involves analyzing the direct and indirect costs, projected revenues, resource allocation, and risk factors associated with each sales opportunity. Practitioners use a combination of quantitative financial modeling, margin analysis, and qualitative assessment of customer fit, competitive landscape, and deal structure. The goal is to ensure that sales teams prioritize and pursue opportunities that align with strategic objectives and deliver sustainable profit, rather than simply maximizing top-line revenue. In today’s business environment, where margins are under constant pressure and resources are limited, this skill is crucial for making informed go/no-go decisions, optimizing pricing strategies, and negotiating terms that protect profitability. Typical use cases include evaluating large enterprise deals, assessing the impact of discounts or incentives, and forecasting the profitability of new market segments or product lines. Sales Opportunity Profitability Analysis is closely integrated with CRM systems and sales pipeline management, enabling real-time decision-making and continuous improvement. Mastery of this skill empowers sales leaders and account managers to focus efforts on high-value deals, avoid unprofitable engagements, and contribute directly to organizational financial health.

14575b74-2c86-4615-b190-e9cc7fdf99a7.name: Sales Pipeline Risk Assessment
14575b74-2c86-4615-b190-e9cc7fdf99a7.description:
Sales Pipeline Risk Assessment is a critical skill within Business and Sales Operations that focuses on systematically identifying, evaluating, and prioritizing potential risks that could impact the progression of deals through the sales pipeline. This skill involves analyzing each stage of the pipeline to detect obstacles such as stalled deals, low engagement, inaccurate forecasting, resource constraints, or shifts in customer needs. Practitioners use a combination of quantitative data (e.g., conversion rates, deal velocity, historical win/loss analysis) and qualitative insights (e.g., sales rep feedback, customer sentiment) to assess the likelihood and potential impact of risks. The primary value of this skill lies in its ability to enable sales teams and management to proactively address issues before they escalate, ensuring a healthier pipeline, more accurate revenue forecasting, and improved quota attainment. Typical applications include regular pipeline reviews, risk scoring of opportunities, and the development of mitigation strategies such as targeted coaching, process adjustments, or resource reallocation. Sales Pipeline Risk Assessment is especially relevant today as organizations face rapidly changing markets, increased competition, and heightened pressure to deliver predictable results. Mastery of this skill empowers sales operations professionals to drive data-driven decision-making, optimize sales processes, and maintain organizational agility in the face of uncertainty.

c4df7984-2999-4758-b496-c05acaeefd7f.name: Sales Pipeline Risk Assessment
c4df7984-2999-4758-b496-c05acaeefd7f.description:
Sales Pipeline Risk Assessment is the systematic process of identifying, evaluating, and mitigating potential risks that could impact the progression and successful closure of deals within a sales pipeline. This skill is crucial in today's dynamic business environment, where sales cycles are increasingly complex and subject to a variety of internal and external uncertainties. Practitioners of this skill leverage data-driven analysis, qualitative judgment, and domain expertise to pinpoint vulnerabilities such as stalled deals, inaccurate forecasting, customer indecision, competitive threats, and resource constraints. By proactively assessing these risks, organizations can prioritize high-probability opportunities, allocate resources more effectively, and implement contingency plans to address potential obstacles before they escalate. 5bc895d5-5920-464d-adda-ce33dff2b6c5.name: Sales Playbook Development
5bc895d5-5920-464d-adda-ce33dff2b6c5.description:
Sales Playbook Development is the process of designing, organizing, and documenting a comprehensive set of guidelines, best practices, strategies, and resources that standardize the sales process within an organization. This skill is crucial in today's fast-paced business environment, where consistency, scalability, and rapid onboarding are essential for sales team effectiveness. A well-crafted sales playbook provides sales representatives with clear instructions on prospecting, qualifying leads, handling objections, closing deals, and leveraging sales tools and technologies. It typically includes detailed buyer personas, messaging frameworks, objection handling scripts, competitive positioning, and step-by-step workflows for each stage of the sales funnel. The development process requires close collaboration with sales leaders, marketing teams, and subject matter experts to ensure alignment with business objectives and market realities. Sales Playbook Development accelerates the onboarding of new sales team members by providing them with a structured roadmap, reducing ramp-up time and minimizing errors. It also enables ongoing performance improvement by serving as a living document that can be updated with new insights, tactics, and market changes. In the current business landscape, where remote and hybrid teams are common, a standardized playbook ensures that all team members operate with the same knowledge base and approach, driving higher win rates and customer satisfaction. Typical use cases include launching new products, entering new markets, or scaling sales operations across multiple regions.

39ca720f-1d2f-4ae1-9845-8e741ab734e1.name: Sales Process Automation
39ca720f-1d2f-4ae1-9845-8e741ab734e1.description:
Sales Process Automation is the technical skill of designing, implementing, and managing automated workflows that streamline and optimize the various stages of the sales cycle. This skill involves leveraging software platforms, such as Customer Relationship Management (CRM) systems, workflow automation tools, and integration platforms, to reduce manual intervention, minimize errors, and accelerate repetitive sales tasks. Key aspects include automating lead capture and qualification, follow-up communications, pipeline management, quote generation, contract management, and reporting. Practitioners must understand both the technical capabilities of automation tools and the business logic of sales processes to ensure seamless integration with existing systems and alignment with organizational goals. Sales Process Automation is crucial for increasing efficiency, scalability, and consistency in sales operations, enabling sales teams to focus on high-value activities such as relationship building and closing deals. Typical use cases include setting up automated email sequences for nurturing leads, integrating sales data across platforms for real-time analytics, and triggering alerts or tasks based on customer interactions. This skill is highly relevant today as organizations seek to remain competitive by reducing sales cycle times, improving data accuracy, and providing a better customer experience through timely and personalized engagement. Mastery of Sales Process Automation requires a blend of technical proficiency, process analysis, and change management.

3446fe0b-c388-47c4-bf2c-8b329c927b52.name: Sales Process Compliance Monitoring
3446fe0b-c388-47c4-bf2c-8b329c927b52.description:
Sales Process Compliance Monitoring is a critical skill within the Business / Sales Governance domain, focused on ensuring that enterprise sales teams adhere strictly to established sales processes, policies, and regulatory standards. This skill involves the systematic observation, assessment, and reporting of sales activities to verify alignment with organizational guidelines and industry regulations. Practitioners of this skill utilize a combination of process audits, data analytics, and real-time monitoring tools to identify deviations, gaps, or risks in the sales process. They collaborate closely with sales leadership, compliance officers, and quality assurance teams to implement corrective actions and continuous improvements. The immediate value of this skill lies in its ability to mitigate compliance risks, prevent costly errors, and uphold the integrity of the sales function, which is especially vital in highly regulated industries or large-scale enterprise environments. Typical use cases include monitoring adherence to anti-bribery and anti-corruption policies, verifying accurate documentation of customer interactions, and ensuring that all sales stages—from lead qualification to contract closure—are executed according to defined protocols. By maintaining rigorous oversight, Sales Process Compliance Monitoring supports transparency, fosters trust with clients and stakeholders, and enables organizations to pass internal and external audits with confidence. In today’s business landscape, where regulatory scrutiny and reputational risks are high, this skill is indispensable for safeguarding organizational interests and sustaining long-term growth.

88847175-5d02-463a-82aa-e7a77ea8edcb.name: Sales Process Compliance
88847175-5d02-463a-82aa-e7a77ea8edcb.description:
Sales Process Compliance is the disciplined adherence to established legal, regulatory, and organizational standards throughout all stages of the sales cycle. In today's business environment, where regulatory scrutiny and complex contractual obligations are increasingly prevalent, this skill ensures that sales professionals and organizations operate within defined boundaries, reducing legal and financial risk. It encompasses understanding and applying relevant laws (such as anti-bribery, data privacy, and industry-specific regulations), following internal policies (including documentation, approval workflows, and pricing controls), and maintaining accurate records for audit purposes. Sales Process Compliance is critical in regulated industries like pharmaceuticals, finance, and technology, where non-compliance can result in severe penalties, reputational damage, or loss of business licenses. Practitioners must be vigilant in monitoring changes to regulations, training teams on compliance requirements, and integrating compliance checkpoints into CRM systems and sales enablement tools. Immediate applications include ensuring that contracts are reviewed for legal sufficiency, that customer data is handled according to privacy laws, and that sales incentives do not violate ethical standards. This skill also supports consistency and fairness in customer interactions, fostering trust and long-term relationships. Effective Sales Process Compliance requires collaboration with legal, finance, and operations teams, and is often assessed through audits, compliance training completion, and incident tracking. Its present-day value lies in safeguarding organizations against costly violations while enabling scalable, repeatable, and ethical sales practices.

40eafaea-0416-4920-ac27-6bf429662da5.name: Sales Process Digital Transformation
40eafaea-0416-4920-ac27-6bf429662da5.description:
Sales Process Digital Transformation is the technical skill of leveraging digital technologies to redesign, automate, and optimize the end-to-end sales process within an organization. This skill involves the integration of digital tools such as Customer Relationship Management (CRM) systems, sales analytics platforms, artificial intelligence (AI)-driven lead scoring, and automated communication workflows to streamline sales operations. Practitioners must understand how to assess existing sales processes, identify bottlenecks or inefficiencies, and implement digital solutions that enhance agility, scalability, and customer engagement. Key aspects include data migration and integration, process mapping, change management, and ensuring data security and compliance throughout the transformation. Sales Process Digital Transformation is immediately relevant as organizations face rapidly changing market conditions, increased competition, and evolving customer expectations. It enables sales teams to respond faster to leads, personalize customer interactions, and make data-driven decisions that improve conversion rates and revenue growth. Typical use cases include automating lead qualification, integrating sales and marketing data for unified reporting, and deploying digital sales enablement tools. This skill is critical for technical professionals tasked with modernizing sales infrastructure, ensuring that sales operations remain competitive and aligned with current digital best practices.

d74c589a-ebb4-493b-bac8-f222be844745.name: Sales Process Mapping
d74c589a-ebb4-493b-bac8-f222be844745.description:
Sales Process Mapping is the systematic practice of visually documenting and analyzing each stage of a sales workflow to enhance clarity, efficiency, and effectiveness in business operations. This skill involves identifying, outlining, and representing the sequential steps, decision points, roles, and interactions that occur from initial lead generation through to deal closure and post-sale follow-up. By mapping the sales process, organizations can pinpoint bottlenecks, redundancies, and opportunities for improvement, enabling data-driven optimization and alignment with broader business objectives. Sales Process Mapping is especially critical in today’s fast-paced, customer-centric business environment, where complex sales cycles, multiple touchpoints, and cross-functional collaboration are the norm. It supports sales teams in standardizing best practices, ensuring compliance, and facilitating onboarding and training. Additionally, it provides a foundation for implementing sales technologies such as CRM systems, automating repetitive tasks, and integrating analytics for performance measurement. Typical use cases include redesigning sales workflows to reduce cycle times, clarifying handoffs between marketing and sales, and supporting change management initiatives during organizational growth or digital transformation. Mastery of Sales Process Mapping empowers professionals to drive continuous improvement, foster transparency, and deliver a consistent customer experience, making it a highly relevant and valuable skill in contemporary business settings.

a06b36b1-cd9d-4609-8936-15bd739bc66c.description:

487523f3-a9f5-4ce8-80f8-6f1d64ca51ae.name: Sales Training Program Design
487523f3-a9f5-4ce8-80f8-6f1d64ca51ae.description:
Sales Training Program Design is a critical leadership skill focused on developing, implementing, and refining structured learning initiatives that enhance the capabilities and performance of sales teams. Leaders skilled in this area conduct thorough needs assessments to identify skill gaps, align training objectives with organizational goals, and tailor content to diverse learning styles and sales roles. They leverage modern instructional design principles, incorporate digital learning platforms, and utilize real-world scenarios to maximize engagement and retention. Ongoing evaluation and feedback mechanisms are integral, enabling continuous improvement and adaptation to market changes. The immediate value of this skill lies in its ability to drive sales effectiveness, foster a culture of continuous learning, and ensure readiness for evolving customer expectations and competitive pressures. Leaders who excel in Sales Training Program Design not only boost individual and team performance but also contribute to higher employee satisfaction, lower turnover, and sustained revenue growth. Typical use cases include onboarding new sales hires, upskilling existing teams on new products or markets, and addressing performance gaps through targeted interventions.

7700078a-5a90-432b-b9db-591cb1caed3e.name: Sales and marketing

a603ce78-f176-4056-9bac-d44acfa94afc.name: Sales discovery questions
a603ce78-f176-4056-9bac-d44acfa94afc.description: Discovery questions are questions you ask a prospect to gauge whether or not they are a good fit for your product or service. These questions should be open-ended and focus on the prospect's obstacles, processes, and goals as they relate to the product or service you are offering.

776929b2-e216-4967-9cc1-d93fb41b326d.name: Sales presentation skills
776929b2-e216-4967-9cc1-d93fb41b326d.description: Sales presentation and negotiation skills is the capability to communicate effectively and persuade potential customers to purchase the business's products or services.

281e2b79-8f00-4fbe-a032-c625230bfecd.name: Sales proposals
281e2b79-8f00-4fbe-a032-c625230bfecd.description: A sales proposal is a paper or digital document used to pitch services or products to prospective clients and current customers. Different companies and professionals have different names for them, so you might also hear them called “business proposals” or “product proposals”—they're all the same thing.

72a048fc-2faa-4c07-b4e7-c7651d112db2.name: Sales prospecting
72a048fc-2faa-4c07-b4e7-c7651d112db2.description: The process of identifying and contacting potential customers in order to generate new business. Prospecting is the way sales reps find and engage with prospects (leads that are qualified) and set the sales process in motion.

5d52d62d-891a-44fc-8568-73f42e9349a0.name: Sales reporting and analysis
5d52d62d-891a-44fc-8568-73f42e9349a0.description: A sales report, also known as a sales analysis report, is a comprehensive record of all the sales activity taking place within a company over a certain period of time. Essentially, it provides sales managers with an overview of all the sales processes and operations carried out by the business.

59f112b8-a800-4e39-8a65-1054bb13f911.name: Salesforce AI
59f112b8-a800-4e39-8a65-1054bb13f911.description: Salesforce AI delivers trusted, extensible AI grounded in the fabric of our Einstein 1 Platform. Utilise our AI in your customer data to create customisable, predictive, and generative AI experiences to fit all your business needs safely. Bring conversational AI to any workflow, user, department, and industry with Einstein.

9ad2c70b-41d0-426a-90e8-45271322668f.name: Salesforce CPQ
9ad2c70b-41d0-426a-90e8-45271322668f.description: Salesforce CPQ (Configure, Price, Quote) is a tool that helps sales teams quickly generate accurate quotes for complex products or services by automating the quoting process.

637b6b54-7b13-4457-acc2-5c0c84864a88.name: Salesforce DX (SFDX)
637b6b54-7b13-4457-acc2-5c0c84864a88.description: Salesforce Developer Experience (Salesforce DX) is a set of software development tools that lets developers build, test and ship many kinds of applications on Salesforce Platform (formerly called Force.com). 95e1f00e-a642-46af-8de7-398aee0f1d67.name: Salesforce Flow Builder
95e1f00e-a642-46af-8de7-398aee0f1d67.description: Flow Builder is a declarative interface used to build individual flows in Salesforce. Flow Builder provides a user-friendly, drag-and-drop interface that allows users to design and construct flows visually.

bdc733aa-e54d-47d3-9726-d5eb4dc1cfe3.name: Salesforce Integration Cloud
bdc733aa-e54d-47d3-9726-d5eb4dc1cfe3.description: Salesforce Integration Cloud allows you to integrate business apps and access data on varied platforms. As you respond to your customers in time and resolve their difficulties, you experience an improved customer experience.

3f8a8f58-a846-4047-b190-3c7fa9626997.name: Salesforce Journey Builder
3f8a8f58-a846-4047-b190-3c7fa9626997.description: Journey Builder is a Marketing Cloud Engagement application used for creating responsive automated multichannel campaigns. Use Journey Builder to design a communication plan that reaches customers at every stage of their journey with your brand.

f7e2116c-9b41-4ab3-93ac-f074a1f73488.name: Salesforce Marketing Cloud
f7e2116c-9b41-4ab3-93ac-f074a1f73488.description: Salesforce Marketing Cloud is an AI-powered, cloud-based digital marketing platform within the Salesforce Customer 360 ecosystem. Marketers can segment their audience, deliver personalised messages, track campaign performance, engage leads and accounts, and optimise strategies based on real-time insights.

c1fc2d2d-5834-4f34-bb61-c39aecf63970.name: Salesforce Object Query Language (SOQL)
c1fc2d2d-5834-4f34-bb61-c39aecf63970.description: Salesforce Object Query Language (SOQL) is used to search your Salesforce data for specific records. SOQL is similar to the SELECT statement in the widely used Structured Query Language (SQL) but is designed specifically for Salesforce data.

ae588307-4302-40a9-901a-3693b92fff33.name: Salesforce configuration
ae588307-4302-40a9-901a-3693b92fff33.description: Configuration refers to the process of setting up and modifying Salesforce using its built-in tools and features without altering its underlying code. It involves using point-and-click tools to modify the system behavior. Examples of Configuration: Creating and customizing objects, fields, and page layouts.

d7a4820a-ac4a-4fca-aa86-1b5ea5cb67b9.name: Salesforce customization
d7a4820a-ac4a-4fca-aa86-1b5ea5cb67b9.description: Salesforce customization is adding a function or feature that isn't already available in the application. In other words, you're developing and coding new functionality into the CRM. You may need to customize Salesforce if the packaged version doesn't allow you to do what you need.

50569a3d-83c4-454f-8718-f7827ca360b8.name: Salesforce streaming API
50569a3d-83c4-454f-8718-f7827ca360b8.description: Streaming API enables streaming of events using push technology and provides a subscription mechanism for receiving events in near real time. The Streaming API subscription mechanism supports multiple types of events, including PushTopic events, generic events, platform events, and change data capture events.

c17a93eb-319b-4d1f-9700-3cbb7b6f5dd4.name: Salesforce
c17a93eb-319b-4d1f-9700-3cbb7b6f5dd4.description: Salesforce is the world's leading customer relationship management technology (What is CRM?), helping you build and improve your customer relationships. In 1999 we pioneered cloud-based CRM and today we're helping organisations of all sizes re-imagine their business for the world of AI.

a6068b77-106b-4024-9327-dc52275c228d.name: Sass
a6068b77-106b-4024-9327-dc52275c228d.description: Sass is a preprocessor language that's interpreted into CSS. A preprocessor language takes input data and converts it to an output that's used as input by another program. This means when you run Sass code, you're actually converting your code to CSS. That CSS code output is then used directly by a browser.

ae88952f-ecbd-4be0-ab83-21b83e09aa20.name: Scaling businesses
ae88952f-ecbd-4be0-ab83-21b83e09aa20.description: In business, the definition of “scale” is to increase revenue at a faster rate than costs. Businesses achieve this in a number of ways, from adopting new technologies to finding “gaps” in their operations that can be streamlined.

c4a53436-ad15-4516-93d4-1fd810d39fe5.name: Scenario Planning for Food Supply Chain Resilience
c4a53436-ad15-4516-93d4-1fd810d39fe5.name_en: Scenario Planning for Food Supply Chain Resilience
c4a53436-ad15-4516-93d4-1fd810d39fe5.description:
Scenario Planning for Food Supply Chain Resilience is a critical leadership skill that involves proactively identifying, analyzing, and preparing for potential disruptions within the food supply chain. In today’s volatile global environment, leaders must anticipate risks such as pandemics, geopolitical tensions, climate change, cyber-attacks, and logistical failures that can impact the availability, safety, and affordability of food. This skill requires leaders to facilitate cross-functional collaboration, gather and interpret relevant data, and construct plausible scenarios that reflect a range of possible threats and opportunities. Leaders then use these scenarios to stress-test existing supply chain strategies, identify vulnerabilities, and develop robust contingency plans. Immediate applications include conducting tabletop exercises, engaging stakeholders across the supply chain, and integrating scenario outcomes into decision-making processes to ensure business continuity and food security. The skill also encompasses the ability to communicate complex risks and mitigation strategies to diverse audiences, foster a culture of resilience, and drive continuous improvement based on lessons learned from scenario exercises. By mastering scenario planning for food supply chain resilience, leaders enable their organizations to respond swiftly and effectively to disruptions, maintain stakeholder trust, and safeguard both public health and organizational viability in the face of uncertainty.

7e8ce03b-bcd1-4a0a-8c17-cd21270c8b23.name: Scheme
7e8ce03b-bcd1-4a0a-8c17-cd21270c8b23.description: Scheme is a dialect of the Lisp family of programming languages. Scheme was created during the 1970s at the MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (MIT AI Lab) and released by its developers, Guy L. Steele and Gerald Jay Sussman, via a series of memos now known as the Lambda Papers. It was the first dialect of Lisp to choose lexical scope and the first to require implementations to perform tail-call optimization, giving stronger support for functional programming and associated techniques such as recursive algorithms. It was also one of the first programming languages to support first-class continuations. It had a significant influence on the effort that led to the development of Common Lisp. Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scheme_(programming_language)

aa43ecd2-d719-4415-8273-e0a5a655a997.name: Scratch
aa43ecd2-d719-4415-8273-e0a5a655a997.description:
Scratch is the world’s largest coding community for children and a coding language with a simple visual interface that allows young people to create digital stories, games, and animations. Scratch is designed, developed, and moderated by the Scratch Foundation, a nonprofit organization.

Scratch promotes computational thinking and problem solving skills; creative teaching and learning; self-expression and collaboration; and equity in computing.  Ref: https://scratch.mit.edu/about

e6abe91a-9b8e-4c7d-8a1a-1ae7312ce720.name: Search Engine Optimization (SEO)
e6abe91a-9b8e-4c7d-8a1a-1ae7312ce720.description: This involves optimizing your website for search engines to improve visibility in search results and attract organic traffic.

db422686-d2ee-4701-8fc9-8b26b2fb442e.name: Search configurations
db422686-d2ee-4701-8fc9-8b26b2fb442e.description: Search configurations are sets of rules that affect the display of search results. When a site visitor issues a search query on the Commerce site, ATG platform components determine which search configuration to associate with the query, based on the visitor's language and the user segments he or she is a member of.

ccb2af8e-0a25-4ad4-8075-d0fcd7f296de.name: Secure Coding
ccb2af8e-0a25-4ad4-8075-d0fcd7f296de.description:
Secure coding is the practice of developing computer software in such a way that guards against the accidental introduction of security vulnerabilities. Defects, bugs and logic flaws are consistently the primary cause of commonly exploited software vulnerabilities. Through the analysis of thousands of reported vulnerabilities, security professionals have discovered that most vulnerabilities stem from a relatively small number of common software programming errors. By identifying the insecure coding practices that lead to these errors and educating developers on secure alternatives, organizations can take proactive steps to help significantly reduce or eliminate vulnerabilities in software before deployment.

Some scholars have suggested that in order to effectively confront threats related to cybersecurity, proper security should be coded or “baked in” to the systems. With security being designed into the software, this ensures that there will be protection against insider attacks and reduces the threat to application security. Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_coding

ba520815-9871-4fcc-9c81-b32353ebff75.name: Secure Hash Algorithm (SHA)
ba520815-9871-4fcc-9c81-b32353ebff75.description: SHA stands for Secure Hash Algorithm, and it is a family of standards developed by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST).

59bd3878-1482-4c62-bb8f-9ec202baa816.name: Security automation
59bd3878-1482-4c62-bb8f-9ec202baa816.description: Security automation is the process of automatically preventing, detecting, identifying and eliminating cyberthreats. It can be effective even without human intervention but typically acts as a complement to the SOC team.

f900db48-bf69-4a29-a5d6-9f3e2637d95d.name: Security awareness training
f900db48-bf69-4a29-a5d6-9f3e2637d95d.description: Security awareness training teaches employees how to protect their organization's assets, data and financial resources. By reducing the likelihood of security incidents and breaches, organizations can minimize their financial losses and maintain a more secure and resilient environment. Minimizes the risk of incidents.

d44368ef-b377-4eb4-8943-3188d93af294.name: Security information and event management (SIEM) solutions
d44368ef-b377-4eb4-8943-3188d93af294.description: Security information and event management, or SIEM, is a security solution that helps organizations recognize and address potential security threats and vulnerabilities before they have a chance to disrupt business operations.
d44368ef-b377-4eb4-8943-3188d93af294.description_en: Security information and event management (SIEM) solutions

897f38e4-f247-4bd2-bd4c-624b1d74a816.name: Seismic
897f38e4-f247-4bd2-bd4c-624b1d74a816.description: These waves of energy move through the Earth, just as sound waves move through the air. In oil and gas exploration, seismic waves are sent deep into the Earth and allowed to bounce back. Geophysicists record the waves to learn about oil and gas reservoirs located beneath Earth's surface.

e671d194-0ffe-4961-9ac0-f0c67253c3b8.name: Selenium
e671d194-0ffe-4961-9ac0-f0c67253c3b8.description: Selenium is an open-source suite of tools and libraries that is used for browser automation. Selenium us used to: It allows users to test their websites functionally on different browsers. Perform Cross browser testing to check if the website functions consistently across different browsers.

392dd07c-27c4-474c-9fa1-b56120fa015d.name: Sencha Touch
392dd07c-27c4-474c-9fa1-b56120fa015d.description: Sencha Touch is a popular framework of Sencha for creating a user interface for mobile applications. It helps the developer create a mobile app using simple HTML, CSS, JS which supports many mobile devices such as android, IOS, BlackBerry, and Windows. It is based on MVC architecture.

232f75dd-0cb6-455c-822f-7ed79f2dd70a.name: Sensemaking
232f75dd-0cb6-455c-822f-7ed79f2dd70a.description: Sensemaking is a term that refers to reacting to, making sense of, and acting upon the environment and events around us, especially new and unknown stimuli. In business organizations, this helps people prepare for the future, or react to events for which there are no established rules or policies.

37048824-6619-4c2a-b321-39b2dacb74a2.name: Service design
37048824-6619-4c2a-b321-39b2dacb74a2.description: Service design practice is the specification and construction of processes which deliver valuable capacities for action to a particular user. Service design practice can be both tangible and intangible, and can involve artifacts or other elements such as communication, environment and behaviour

aee8295a-c3e5-4f0c-b768-d2afc9cc21a2.name: ServiceNow
aee8295a-c3e5-4f0c-b768-d2afc9cc21a2.description: Established in 2003, ServiceNow is a cloud-based workflow automation platform for enterprise organisations. What does that mean? Well, think of it as a single platform to connect every element of your IT network, marry it up with business and employee requirements, and manage it all in one place

97ca00b7-c922-4d85-8a43-1aaeb02a5d4b.name: SharePoint Designer
97ca00b7-c922-4d85-8a43-1aaeb02a5d4b.description: SharePoint Designer is Microsoft's home-grown web and application design program. Its goal is to help people build custom, data-rich SharePoint sites and applications without writing code. Its features also allow people to create workflows to automate tasks and processes in any organization.

fd6cdd87-be45-418c-9190-182c96584341.name: SharePoint Framework (SPFx)
fd6cdd87-be45-418c-9190-182c96584341.description: SharePoint Framework (SPFx) is a model for building customizations on the SharePoint platform. The Framework is based on the concept of building client-side solutions which integrate with the modern SharePoint UX.

73fe9e80-d2e8-4fe4-8faa-06099d600554.name: Shareholder agreements
73fe9e80-d2e8-4fe4-8faa-06099d600554.description: The skill of setting up shareholderagreements for a group of owners/shareholders in a business.

2eda58a0-758e-4152-b8f7-4295c7e06c54.name: Sidekiq
2eda58a0-758e-4152-b8f7-4295c7e06c54.description: Sidekiq is one of the most popular open-source background job libraries for Ruby. As one of ActiveJob's most popular backends, it's often used to run asynchronous jobs in Rails applications. It leans on Redis to manage queues and jobs, which makes it fast.

cf4c8fd4-2c11-44e2-9e32-d9e8109d67ee.name: Sigrid
cf4c8fd4-2c11-44e2-9e32-d9e8109d67ee.description: Sigrid delivers an in-depth cybersecurity risk assessment at both a portfolio and system level. Its comprehensive dashboards offer a complete overview of your security posture, giving you a detailed analysis of vulnerabilities, changes over time, severity ratings, and other key trends.

2cc884f7-ec64-4f0f-8f83-332d6eaa8857.name: Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP)
2cc884f7-ec64-4f0f-8f83-332d6eaa8857.description:
The Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) is an Internet standard communication protocol for electronic mail transmission. Mail servers and other message transfer agents use SMTP to send and receive mail messages. User-level email clients typically use SMTP only for sending messages to a mail server for relaying, and typically submit outgoing email to the mail server on port 587 or 465 per RFC 8314. For retrieving messages, IMAP (which replaced the older POP3) is standard, but proprietary servers also often implement proprietary protocols, e.g., Exchange ActiveSync.

SMTP's origins began in 1980, building on concepts implemented on the ARPANET since 1971. It has been updated, modified and extended multiple times. The protocol version in common use today has extensible structure with various extensions for authentication, encryption, binary data transfer, and internationalized email addresses. SMTP servers commonly use the Transmission Control Protocol on port number 25 (for plaintext) and 587 (for encrypted communications).   Ref:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Mail_Transfer_Protocol

2cee5140-a119-48f7-b719-44d6358d9a17.name: Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP)
2cee5140-a119-48f7-b719-44d6358d9a17.description:
Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) is an Internet Standard protocol for collecting and organizing information about managed devices on IP networks and for modifying that information to change device behavior. Devices that typically support SNMP include cable modems, routers, switches, servers, workstations, printers, and more.

SNMP is widely used in network management for network monitoring. SNMP exposes management data in the form of variables on the managed systems organized in a management information base (MIB), which describes the system status and configuration. These variables can then be remotely queried (and, in some circumstances, manipulated) by managing applications.

Three significant versions of SNMP have been developed and deployed. SNMPv1 is the original version of the protocol. More recent versions, SNMPv2c and SNMPv3, feature improvements in performance, flexibility and security.

SNMP is a component of the Internet Protocol Suite as defined by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF). It consists of a set of standards for network management, including an application layer protocol, a database schema, and a set of data objects.  Ref:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol

23f2e66b-1f0c-4506-9e9f-13d31ffd1ef0.name: Single sign-on (SSO)
23f2e66b-1f0c-4506-9e9f-13d31ffd1ef0.description:
Single sign-on (SSO) is an authentication scheme that allows a user to log in with a single ID to any of several related, yet independent, software systems.

True single sign-on allows the user to log in once and access services without re-entering authentication factors.

It should not be confused with same-sign on (Directory Server Authentication), often accomplished by using the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) and stored LDAP databases on (directory) servers.[1][2]

A simple version of single sign-on can be achieved over IP networks using cookies but only if the sites share a common DNS parent domain.[3]

For clarity, a distinction is made between Directory Server Authentication (same-sign on) and single sign-on: Directory Server Authentication refers to systems requiring authentication for each application but using the same credentials from a directory server, whereas single sign-on refers to systems where a single authentication provides access to multiple applications by passing the authentication token seamlessly to configured applications.

Conversely, single sign-off or single log-out (SLO) is the property whereby a single action of signing out terminates access to multiple software systems.

As different applications and resources support different authentication mechanisms, single sign-on must internally store the credentials used for initial authentication and translate them to the credentials required for the different mechanisms.

Other shared authentication schemes, such as OpenID and OpenID Connect, offer other services that may require users to make choices during a sign-on to a resource, but can be configured for single sign-on if those other services (such as user consent) are disabled.[4] An increasing number of federated social logons, like Facebook Connect, do require the user to enter consent choices upon first registration with a new resource, and so are not always single sign-on in the strictest sense.

4fc13022-9e8d-4a68-bed8-35bb18545926.name: Skill Mapping (competency mapping)
4fc13022-9e8d-4a68-bed8-35bb18545926.description:
Skills mapping is a visual representation of all the skills employees have within a department or organization. It involves analyzing each employee's competency related to a particular skill, especially abilities that relate to specific projects, roles and tasks. This technique allows you to understand the abilities of employees and the value that each of them provides. It can reveal the strengths and weaknesses of each employee.
Some people may also refer to skills mapping as competency mapping. Note that skills and competencies differ slightly from each other. While a skill is a single ability to perform a task successfully, a competency is a combination of attitudes, knowledge, skills and traits necessary to perform a task.  Ref: https://www.indeed.com/career-advice/career-development/skills-mapping

ffd30ccd-024a-4d42-9ee3-12fe34500f89.name: Smalltalk
ffd30ccd-024a-4d42-9ee3-12fe34500f89.description:
Smalltalk is a purely object oriented programming language (OOP) that was originally created in the 1970s for educational use, specifically for constructionist learning, but later found use in business. It was created at Xerox PARC by Learning Research Group (LRG) scientists, including Alan Kay, Dan Ingalls, Adele Goldberg, Ted Kaehler, Diana Merry, and Scott Wallace.

In Smalltalk, executing programs are built of opaque, atomic, so-called objects, which are instances of template code stored in classes. These objects intercommunicate by passing of messages, via an intermediary virtual machine environment (VM). A relatively small number of objects, called primitives, are not amenable to live redefinition, sometimes being defined independently of the Smalltalk programming environment.  Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smalltalk

5939a83e-bfff-46a7-9136-363dfd28607f.name: Smart Contracts for Food Supply Chain Automation
5939a83e-bfff-46a7-9136-363dfd28607f.name_en: Smart Contracts for Food Supply Chain Automation
5939a83e-bfff-46a7-9136-363dfd28607f.description:
Smart Contracts for Food Supply Chain Automation is a technical skill focused on the design, development, and deployment of self-executing digital contracts that automate transactions, compliance checks, and data sharing across the food supply chain. Leveraging blockchain technology, this skill enables the creation of tamper-proof, transparent, and programmable agreements between producers, processors, distributors, retailers, and regulatory bodies. By embedding business logic and regulatory requirements directly into code, smart contracts ensure that critical supply chain events—such as shipment arrivals, quality inspections, temperature monitoring, and payment releases—are automatically validated and executed without manual intervention. This automation reduces the risk of human error, fraud, and delays, while enhancing traceability and accountability throughout the supply chain. Immediate applications include real-time tracking of food provenance, automated recall processes, compliance with food safety standards, and streamlined settlement of payments upon delivery confirmation. The skill requires a strong understanding of blockchain platforms (such as Ethereum or Hyperledger), supply chain processes, and regulatory frameworks relevant to food safety and quality. As food supply chains become increasingly complex and globalized, the ability to implement and manage smart contracts is currently vital for organizations seeking to improve operational efficiency, regulatory compliance, and consumer trust.

ae5549fe-39b7-42a3-b858-0e01d3033135.name: Smart contract
ae5549fe-39b7-42a3-b858-0e01d3033135.description:
A smart contract is a computer program or a transaction protocol that is intended to automatically execute, control or document events and actions according to the terms of a contract or an agreement. The objectives of smart contracts are the reduction of need for trusted intermediators, arbitration costs, and fraud losses, as well as the reduction of malicious and accidental exceptions. Smart contracts are commonly associated with cryptocurrencies, and the smart contracts introduced by Ethereum are generally considered a fundamental building block for decentralized finance (DeFi) and NFT applications.

The original Ethereum white paper by Vitalik Buterin in 2014 describes the Bitcoin protocol as a weak version of the smart contract concept as originally defined by Nick Szabo, and proposed a stronger version based on the Solidity language, which is Turing complete. Since Bitcoin,[clarification needed] various cryptocurrencies have supported programming languages which allow for more advanced smart contracts between untrusted parties.  Ref:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_contract

2d65d7b7-8e65-4406-8b1e-9772d7b62d90.name: Social Coding
2d65d7b7-8e65-4406-8b1e-9772d7b62d90.description:
Social coding empowers knowledge exchange. Software engineers have ideas all day long. Through social coding, they can discover and reuse code or solutions that they might otherwise unnecessarily duplicate. With social coding, you can discover, share, and implement new ideas with friends, and even with strangers!

Social coding can also increase the quality of your software. All developers can see and comment on the code changes. When you know that your code is going to be viewed by a wide audience, you have an added incentive to get it right. As the size of the audience increases, so does the likelihood that someone in the group knows the answer to a problem.

Not only can you learn from social coding, but it can be fun. Social coding fosters a fun work environment, encourages peer recognition, and promotes meritocracy, all of which are important to the DevOps culture.  Ref: https://github.com/Cantara/maven-infrastructure/blob/107ecff0adbbbb91069e8fb9bf871d7335a33d10/social%20coding.adoc#L26

It can then be viewed as a combination of roles, processes and documentation that are intended to address specific business needs, requirements or problems through the design and development of applications and information systems.

7b51fc41-fcec-4ae7-9110-c2269fd0d057.name: Stakeholder Conflict Resolution in Sales
7b51fc41-fcec-4ae7-9110-c2269fd0d057.description:
Stakeholder Conflict Resolution in Sales is the ability to identify, address, and resolve disagreements or competing interests among various stakeholders involved in the sales process, such as clients, internal teams, decision-makers, and external partners. In today’s complex business environment, sales professionals frequently encounter situations where stakeholders have differing priorities, expectations, or risk tolerances that can impede deal progress or jeopardize relationships. This skill involves actively listening to all parties, understanding the root causes of conflict, and facilitating open, constructive dialogue to find mutually acceptable solutions. It requires a nuanced understanding of negotiation tactics, emotional intelligence, and the ability to balance organizational objectives with stakeholder satisfaction. Effective conflict resolution minimizes deal friction, accelerates sales cycles, and fosters long-term trust, which is critical for repeat business and positive brand reputation. Typical use cases include mediating between a client’s procurement team and internal product managers over contract terms, resolving disputes about pricing or delivery timelines, and aligning cross-functional teams on sales strategy. Mastery of this skill enables sales professionals to turn potential deal-breakers into opportunities for collaboration, ensuring that all parties feel heard and valued. In the current business climate, where deals often involve multiple influencers and complex buying committees, the ability to resolve stakeholder conflict is essential for maintaining momentum and achieving successful sales outcomes.

4841c56f-bbbc-4202-957c-e2e58c3341b6.name: Stakeholder Engagement for Food System Innovation
4841c56f-bbbc-4202-957c-e2e58c3341b6.name_en: Stakeholder Engagement for Food System Innovation
4841c56f-bbbc-4202-957c-e2e58c3341b6.description:
Stakeholder Engagement for Food System Innovation is a critical leadership skill focused on actively identifying, connecting, and collaborating with a diverse array of stakeholders—including farmers, food manufacturers, distributors, policymakers, researchers, consumers, and advocacy groups—to drive transformative change within contemporary food systems. This skill involves understanding the complex interdependencies and interests that shape the food ecosystem, and leveraging these relationships to foster innovation, sustainability, and resilience. Effective stakeholder engagement requires leaders to facilitate open dialogue, build trust, and align disparate goals to co-create solutions for pressing challenges such as food security, climate impact, supply chain disruptions, and equitable access to nutrition. In today’s rapidly evolving food landscape, this skill is essential for navigating regulatory environments, integrating technological advancements, and responding to shifting consumer demands. Leaders must employ inclusive communication strategies, mediate conflicts, and ensure that all voices—especially those of marginalized or underrepresented groups—are heard and valued in the innovation process. Typical use cases include convening multi-stakeholder forums to develop sustainable sourcing strategies, leading cross-sector partnerships for food waste reduction, and coordinating public-private initiatives to accelerate the adoption of novel food technologies. By mastering this skill, leaders can catalyze collaborative action, unlock new opportunities, and drive systemic innovation that benefits both people and the planet.

52bceb7d-2674-4921-a7ba-e10285c50b37.name: Stakeholder Influence Mapping
52bceb7d-2674-4921-a7ba-e10285c50b37.description:
Stakeholder Influence Mapping is a critical business skill that involves systematically identifying, analyzing, and visually representing the individuals, groups, or organizations that have the power to affect or be affected by a business initiative, project, or decision. This process enables professionals to understand the formal and informal networks of influence within and outside an organization, pinpointing key decision-makers, gatekeepers, champions, and potential detractors. By mapping out the relative influence, interests, and interrelationships of stakeholders, business professionals can develop targeted engagement strategies that maximize support, mitigate resistance, and accelerate outcomes in sales, partnerships, change management, and project delivery. In today's fast-paced and interconnected business environment, the ability to quickly and accurately map stakeholder influence is essential for navigating complex organizational dynamics, securing buy-in, and driving initiatives forward. Typical use cases include preparing for high-stakes negotiations, launching new products, managing organizational change, or entering new markets. The skill requires a blend of analytical thinking, interpersonal awareness, and strategic communication, often leveraging tools such as influence diagrams, power-interest grids, and stakeholder matrices. Mastery of Stakeholder Influence Mapping empowers professionals to proactively manage relationships, anticipate challenges, and align resources for maximum impact, making it a highly relevant and immediately valuable capability in contemporary business practice.

28ab674e-6eef-4df5-8c1a-0ad1b16e6122.name: Statistics
28ab674e-6eef-4df5-8c1a-0ad1b16e6122.description: Statistics is the discipline that concerns the collection, organization, analysis, interpretation, and presentation of data. In applying statistics to a scientific, industrial, or social problem, it is conventional to begin with a statistical population or a statistical model to be studied. Populations can be diverse groups of people or objects such as "all people living in a country" or "every atom composing a crystal". Statistics deals with every aspect of data, including the planning of data collection in terms of the design of surveys and experiments.

e7dec59d-cfee-473c-bdab-7c97dfcf535c.description: Steel Design, or more specifically, Structural Steel Design, is an area of structural engineering used to design steel structures. e06e67bd-f67e-4aec-ba4a-7fc9c700018e.description: Stencil.js is a web component compiler built by the Ionic framework team. It allows developers to create reusable web components.

7e75982b-3e50-4965-9ab5-27d5a3b3bcb6.description: Storytelling is a process used by product marketers to communicate a message to their audience, via the combination of fact and narrative. 2c2e47b6-9574-4bbd-82bb-d79445288127.name: Strategic Account Mapping
2c2e47b6-9574-4bbd-82bb-d79445288127.description:
Strategic Account Mapping is a critical skill in the Business and Enterprise Sales domain that involves systematically identifying, visualizing, and analyzing the key stakeholders, decision-makers, influencers, and organizational structures within large enterprise accounts. This skill enables sales professionals and account teams to develop a deep understanding of the internal dynamics, power structures, and business priorities of their target accounts. By creating detailed account maps, sales teams can uncover hidden relationships, identify champions and blockers, and align their engagement strategies with the client’s business objectives. Strategic Account Mapping is essential for orchestrating complex sales cycles, especially in today’s environment where buying decisions are made by cross-functional teams and involve multiple layers of approval. The skill encompasses the use of digital tools and CRM platforms to document and update account intelligence, as well as the ability to synthesize information from various sources such as LinkedIn, company reports, and direct client interactions. Its immediate value lies in enabling sales teams to prioritize opportunities, allocate resources effectively, and tailor value propositions to the right stakeholders, thereby increasing win rates and accelerating deal velocity. Typical use cases include planning multi-threaded outreach, preparing for executive meetings, and supporting account-based marketing initiatives. In a competitive, relationship-driven sales landscape, Strategic Account Mapping is indispensable for driving growth, expanding footprint within key accounts, and building long-term client partnerships.
